Happy birthday Apple 




Apple Computer is 30 years-old today

<http://www.apple.com/>Apple celebrates its 30th birthday today. 

The company was founded on 1 April 1976 by <http://www.apple.com/pr/bios/jobs.html>Steve Jobs, <http://www.woz.org/>Steve Wozniak and <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Wayne>Ronald Wayne and originally operated out of Jobs's garage.

Apple's first offering was the Apple I personal computer, which sold for $666.66 and was showed off at the now-famous Homebrew Computing Club.



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"Venus: Goddess of Love"

>From the crystal blue depths
of sun splashed ocean waves,
a vision of purest beauty emerges,
her birth heralded by the excited voices of sea gulls.
The Goddess Venus,
poised upon an ivory seashell
and borne upon the winds,
brings us love, beauty, sensuality & desire.
Her gifts compel us to fulfill our creative
& procreative needs.
She invokes enchantment, magnetic beauty,
& sexual awareness.

>From the Blue Depths of the Deep
You were born of the challenges, we are bound to keep
Great Mother of love and lust and delight
Who teachs us how to love and live right
Rest quietly sweet Mother
>From your labors of bringing the light
While the passions sing
Of the storm of joy you bring
Lighting up the lovers night

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Last Call! Max/MSP Workshop @ Robotspeak

There are only a few spots still available.

- matt

-----------------------------------------------------------
Robotspeak Announces:

Max/MSP Beginner Workshop
taught by Matthew Ganucheau
$200 per person
4 classes
Sundays April 2 - 23,
7 pm - 9 pm

Max/MSP is a graphical programming environment, where you create your  
own software using a visual toolkit of objects, and connect them  
together with patch cords. This introductory course includes MIDI,  
alternative controllers, user interfaces, and timing objects, as well  
as controlling audio samples and hard disk recording with MSP.   This  
is an introductory course, and no prior experience with MAX/MSP or  
computer programing is required.

Some of the topics that will be covered include:
	- Navigating the Max/MSP user interface
	- Handling MIDI Data
	- Making a performance Environment
	- Using Alternate Controllers (Joysticks, Dance-pads, Photosensors)
	- Signals and basic signal processing
	- Basic Synthesis
	- Sampling
	- External objects and sub patches
	- Using VST plugins.
	- Saving as a standalone.
	- Designing an Interface.

Registering for this course will make you eligible for the max/msp  
student discount.  Other discounts will be included as well.

Spaces are limited and filing fast.  For reservations, email:   
info@robotspeak.com

Robotspeak
589 1/2 Haight St. @ Steiner
San Francisco, CA 94117
ph 415.554.1977

- matt

--=====================_41433765==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

DISKOTRONIK 4.8.06

SATURDAY APRIL 8th 2006


BLASTHAUS & DISKOTRONIK

welcome the one & only...

THOMAS
(Rub-n-Tug, Map of Africa, Bobbie Marie, Whatever We Want Records  
N.Y.C., Wicked)

with residents..

BIRTHDAY BOY ML TRONIK!!!!!!!!!!!! & TRAVIS TK(and other surprises!)

RX Gallery
132 Eddy St
San Francisco
9pm ­ 2am
$10.00

BIO

Thomas began DJing as a teenager in the eighties along-side friend and
collaborator DJ Harvey at 'Tonka Hi-FI'.

In '91 he moved to California and helped to form the 'Wicked Crew'  
which helped to define the West Coast club sound; a powerfull influence on  
America's club scene for years to come.

In '96 he relocated to New York and formed 'A.R.E. Weapons': a  
Science-Fiction Punk Rock band that ushered in the Electro Clash movement.

After being 'discovered' by Jarvis Cocker they signed to Rough Trade  
Records in London and cut chart hits and an album. Unable to keep still in the scene he  
helped create, he returned to NY and to DJing and formed 'Rub n Tug' with partner Eric D. The  
Rub n Tug parties and it's off-shoot Campfire are now somewhat legendary around the world. Under  
this handle the boys have done remixes for such heavy-hitters as The Beastie Boys,  
Coldplay and Roxy Music as well as more underground acts as !!! and LCD Soundsystem. Rub n Tug have  
brought something new back to disco; as I-D Magazine put it : ' In there hands the disco  
ball has regained consciousness . . . '.

As well as all this, Thomas has started a label in New York called  'Whatever We Want Records' with
partner Carlos Arias, a band with DJ Harvey called 'Map Of Africa'  that has an LP coming out in July
and a Electronic Rockabilly outfit with San Francisco party darling  Rene Peraz called 'Bobbie Marie'.
He also may or may not be responsible for the 'Otter Man Empire' re- edit series.
_______________________________________________


MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_41433765==.ALT--

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 03 Apr 2006 17:15:43.0648 (UTC) FILETIME=[3D6A6A00:01C65742]

Subject: [sfraves] Brief weekend review...

------=_NextPart_000_00F4_01C65707.973E2DE0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

So, after what was yet another fairly crap week, I managed to have a =
pretty decent weekend.=20

HUUUUUUUUUUUUGE thanks to Adrianna for taking me to the Stanton Warriors =
at 1015 Friday night. Hands down one of the most fun events I've been to =
in a while. There was a nice diverse crowd, people were friendly, the =
music was poppin' for the most part. Stanton Warriors were simply off =
the freakin' chain - so much energy and vibe in that set, it was =
awesome. There was also some girl named Laura spinning hip-hop =
and....BALTIMORE CLUB in the front room!!! I about peed myself when I =
heard the familiar and very specific beats that are present in most =
Bmore club, and I saw the crowd just going off to it. Now that I know =
that San Fran can get down to the Bmore sound, I'll be figuring a way to =
get my boy Jesse Tittsworth out here to drop it like only a true Bmore =
club dj/producer can do it.

Saturday night...I reallllly wanted to go to the Evil Breaks thing, but =
no $$ and no ride =3D no Evil Breaks. So, since I was guestlisted for =
Collective 4.0, and I could get a ride, that's where I ended up. Oasis =
is the venue that it was held at in Oakland, and despite the run down =
front room, the back porch/room in was going off, and has MAD potential =
for a poppin' East Bay party. Highlights of the night were Jim Hopkins & =
Angel Alanis. I have never actually seen Jim perform before, and it's =
been YEARS since I've seen Angel Alanis. Both were realllllllly fun, and =
mixed up styles quite a bit. You could totally see the old school mixing =
style in all it's glory. BIG BUG UPS to Otherworld & the Collective crew =
for a nice lowkey Saturday night. Looks like this is gonna wind up being =
a monthly deal, so keep your eyes peeled for more info on that!

To everyone I saw out and about - thanks for being part of a much needed =
fun weekend!!!
------=_NextPart_000_00F4_01C65707.973E2DE0--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Undercover

Whisper is a kewl freakin place.. mellow security, great vibe, real 
warehouse space.. just brings ya back to Breakfast of Champions every time I 
go.  I was pretty impressed with Chris Carter's set.. nice guy too.. but 
what a playa.. every time I went to say hi there was another hottie just 
hangin on em.. some guys get it all.  Then there was Kid Kenobe, that boy 
could do no wrong.  His set was was so slammin, I saw three girls speaker 
humpin on the same stack.. oh lucky stack!  But we should all pay homage at 
least once or twice a year to the Space Cowboys.. few crews on the scene 
roll the way they do: in a UniMog with 10,000 watts of portable 4-wheel 
drive playa dust kicken sound!  Kapt'n Kirk, Mancub, Ernie Travino, Brad 
Robinson, Murpstar & 8-Ball are just a few of the peeps I am fortunate to 
have as friends.

I hope to see everyone at Shine in Two weeks for what is destined to be one 
of the best breaks parties of the year!


SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

Subject: Re: [sfraves] STANTIN WARRIORS & KLUTE 

Now this was an amazing night of music.  I have never heard a better Lorin 
set (in my limited Lorin experience) than the one he put down Friday night.  
Amazing shit.. only to be followed by Stantin Warriors.. Hello.. I still 
think that the UK has a hot angle on so many new flavs of breaks these 
days.. mixing in some hip-hop and litt R&B and then back into tribal.. it 
was all over the place.. and each track more hard hittin than the last.  
Then upstairs for Klute.. I love D&B and Jungle but rarely are they in the 
same place as the breaks I go to hear.. so when you get a chance to hear the 
top DJ's in their game, and tboth genres are at the same place.. well had I 
known that before I went.. I would have never questioned.  Klute was 
amazing.. I was so lost just standing there with everyone else going wtf?  
people were so blown away by that set, kewl as f&*K!

I still like to bag on 1015.. but thanks to Lorin, who brought the crowd.. 
omg what beautiful people they are.. I felt like I was back on the playa and 
was inspired again to make more outfits for clubbin in SF - playa style!  
See ya in my new fur soon!

From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>

for those that know anything about breaks, you know that the Stanton
Warriors have been at the top of their game for years.

really, really fucking good production.  i have probably played more
stanton warriors tracks and remixes than any other group or producer.
their stuff always works the dancefloor.

their Stanton Session mix cd was in my car cd deck for months.
literally.  months.  i couldn't stop listening to it.

check out their myspace:
http://myspace.com/stantonwarriors

click on the mini mix.  hot shit!


On 3/29/06, Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:
 > Here's the linkie 2 the thread on Groundscore:
 > http://www.groundscore.net/board/viewtopic.php?t=19900
 >
 > THE COMMERCIAL SUICIDE TOUR, featuring:
 >
 > KLUTE
 > [COMMERCIAL SUICIDE/METALHEADZ/BBS, UK]
 > HTTP://WWW.COMMERCIALSUICIDE.ORG
 > Tom Withers, aka Klute, has been a fixture on the Drum and Bass scene for
 > over ten years, lending his creativity to the likes of Metalheadz, 31
 > Records, Hospital Records and his early stable Certificate 18, 
responsible
 > for releasing his first two albums, "Casual Bodies" and "Fear of People".
 > In 2001 his own Commercial Suicide imprint was borne out of a necessity 
on
 > Klute's part to control his own releases as well as provide a support
 > network for the ever increasing new generation of like minded producers.
 > So far the label has seen releases by Klute himself, Calibre, Total
 > Science, Digital, and D.Kay. Previous to this much lauded and rebellious
 > electronic career, Klute fronted legendary Skate-Punk outfit, 'The
 > Stupids', an apt schooling for a producer with this unique level of
 > eclecticism.
 >
 > AMIT
 >
 > [COMMERCIAL SUICIDE/METALHEADZ, UK]
 > *LIVE PA PERFORMANCE* *U.S. DEBUT*
 > HTTP://WWW.COMMERCIALSUICIDE.ORG
 > Amit Kamboj, born and bred in Slough, is one of the fastest rising stars
 > in drum&bass. His music (influenced heavily by asian and middle-eastern
 > sounds as well us dub reggae, electro, acid-house and techno) has seen
 > releases on distinguished labels such as Metalheadz, Timeless, Function,
 > Inneractive and Commercial Suicide. Touring in support of his forthcoming
 > album, "Never Ending" on Commercial Suicide, Amit's performance will be a
 > live PA.
 >
 > This performance is one of the most highly anticipated events of the 
year,
 > so don't miss it!

Sounds good! I ended up singing Karioki (sp?) with family on Friday and
found out I don't sing as bad as I thought I did.  Saturday hit up the loca=
l
SJ Studio 8 club, which is a typical SJ type club (which means shitty). The=
n
left there and went to a place called the temple, which was packed again
with the typical SJ club crowd. Danced to a to a ton of pop/top40 and hip
hop. Got drunk, threw up tons of times, ended up at my cousins house who
lives downtown and found out that someone had cut the back of my brand new
birthday slacks and tried stealing my wallet (which luckily they didn't
get). Also my cousin got her jacket stolen and we almost got into a fight
with some fobby clicky bitches that thought they were the shit cause they
have LV bags. Fuckin San Jose.

Anyway, good times, good times.

Subject: [sfraves] Please Help -- Seeking QA / Test Engineer Jobs

Please Help - if you know of someone looking for a QA engineer with a 
solid background, please refer them to me. This is very important. Thanks 
and hope you are all well.

<3 Karina

Request for Test and QA Opportunities

Request for QA Opportunities in Open Source Projects, Employment, 
Full-Time, Contract, Consulting

I'm seeking interesting Full Time, Contract, Consulting/Freelance 
Opportunities *and* Open Source Projects that are looking for a QA 
engineer with a solid background and diverse technical skillset. I've been 
in Software / Hardware Quality Assurance for 13 years and am seeking 
projects to contribute towards the quality of the Gnu Public license 
and/or any Open Source model. I also am interested in Full-time 
employment, contract/consulting roles, as well as part-time/freelance work 
on any projects that seek a stellar QA engineer. If you know of someone 
who needs help or is looking for a tester with a technical edge, please 
feel free to refer them to me.

Roles: Full-time employment, contract, freelance, W2 opportunities in the 
QA field.

Objective: Senior QA Engineer, Lead Quality Assurance Engineer or QA 
Manager role
Summary & Qualifications: 13 years experience in Hardware/Software QA 
Engineering
- 6 years experience managing Quality Assurance organizations, leading 
multiple QA engineers and projects.
- 8 years experience in a Product Support and Technical Support 
Engineering role.
- 12 years experience in a Senior QA Engineer and Lead QA Engineer role.
- 12 years experience establishing various QA processes and procedures 
including: Product Development and Software LifeCycle, the QA Lifecycle 
process, Defect Submittal, Reporting, Tracking and Escalation Lifecycle, 
Product Validation, Certification and Release Lifecycle, QA Project 
Planning and QA Test Methodologies and Processes.
- 12 Years planning and executing Test Plans as part of the design, 
development and QA cycle of various projects.
- 12 years experience authoring and conducting Acceptance, Ad-Hoc, Black 
Box (Behavioral, Functional, Closed Box, Opaque box), GUI, Functional, 
Integration, Installation, Manual, Navigation, Module and Regression 
Tests.
- 11 Years performing release certification and validation, Unit and 
Integration Checks, Source Code Management.
- 10 years conducting White Box tests (Structural, Glassbox, Clearbox, 
System Internals, Branch/Path Coverage Tests).
- 12 years authoring and executing Performance, Database, Security, 
Smokescreen, Stress, Boundary, Load, Validation, SW & HW Compatibility 
Tests using advanced and innovative Test Methodologies in Macintosh, 
Windows, Unix, WAP, WML, Console game systems and Palm OS environments.
- 12 years authoring, documenting and defining standards for QA (Test 
Plans, Test Cases, Test Scripts and Test Procedures).
- 7 years experience administrating QA Lab Operations (Network/Test/Lab 
Environment), QA Release Cycle and QA Intranet website. Functions of this 
capacity included: QA Website Webmaster, QA Lab Administrator, QA 
Production Lab Administrator, QA Release certification and Defect Tracking 
Systems Administrator.

Resume and extensive references furnished upon request

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: The strange case of the man who took 40,000 ecstasy pills in nine years 

--0-1295044750-1144114050=:15330
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

The story of Mr. A:
   
  >>
   
  http://www.guardian.co.uk/drugs/Story/0,,1746333,00.html?gusrc=rss
   
  >>
   
  The strange case of the man who took 40,000 ecstasy pills in nine years 

· Usage increased to 25 tablets a day at peak
· Memory problems and paranoia may be lasting 

David McCandless
Tuesday April 4, 2006
The Guardian 

  Doctors from London University have revealed details of what they believe is the largest amount of ecstasy ever consumed by a single person. Consultants from the addiction centre at St George's Medical School, London, have published a case report of a British man estimated to have taken around 40,000 pills of MDMA, the active ingredient in ecstasy, over nine years. The heaviest previous lifetime intake on record is 2,000 pills.   Though the man, who is now 37, stopped taking the drug seven years ago, he still suffers from severe physical and mental health side-effects, including extreme memory problems, paranoia, hallucinations and depression. He also suffers from painful muscle rigidity around his neck and jaw which often prevents him from opening his mouth. The doctors believe many of these symptoms may be permanent.   The man, known as Mr A in the report in the scientific journal Psychosomatics, started using ecstasy at 21. For the first two years his use was an
 average of five pills per weekend. Gradually this escalated until he was taking around three and a half pills a day. At the peak, the man was taking an estimated 25 pills every day for four years. After several severe collapses at parties, Mr A decided to stop taking ecstasy. For several months, he still felt he was under the influence of the drug, despite being bedridden.   Hallucinations   His condition deteriorated and he began to experience recurrent tunnel vision and other problems including hallucinations, paranoia and muscle rigidity. "He came to us after deciding that he couldn't go on any more," said Dr Christos Kouimtsidis, the consultant psychiatrist at St George's Medical School in Tooting who treated him for five months. "He was having trouble functioning in everyday life."   The doctors discovered that the man was suffering from severe short-term memory problems of a type usually only seen in lifetime alcoholics. But evaluating the full extent of his
 condition was difficult as his concentration and attention was so impaired he was unable to follow the simple tasks involved in the test.   "This was an exceptional case. His long- term memory was fine but he could not remember day to day things - the time, the day, what was in his supermarket trolley," said Dr Kouimtsidis. "More worryingly, he did not seem aware himself that he had these memory problems."   With no mental illness in his family and no prior psychiatric history, the doctors concluded that his unique condition was direct result of his intense ecstasy use.   "This is obviously an extreme case so we should not blow any observations out of proportion," says Dr Kouimtsidis. "But if this is what is happening to very heavy users, it might be an indication that daily use of ecstasy over a long period of time can lead to irreversible memory problems and other cognitive deficits."   For 10 years, MDMA has been suspected of causing these kinds of effects in heavy
 users. It is thought to be due to its disruption of the regulation of serotonin, a brain chemical believed to play a role in mood and memory. It remains unclear whether these effects are the result of permanent neurotoxic damage or just temporary reversible alterations in the brain.   A study today in a special MDMA issue of the British Journal of Psychopharmacology, suggests long-term side-effects may be temporary. The researchers from the University Of Louisiana could find no significant relationship between depression and recreational ecstasy use.   In the case of Mr A, a structural MRI brain scan failed to show any obvious damage or atrophy in his brain. However, these results, says Dr Kouimtsidis, are difficult to interpret. "A scan of this type is not sensitive enough," he said.   Such limitations in brain scanning technology, along with ethical and legal barriers to giving MDMA to human test subjects, have limited direct observation of the drug's effects in humans. 
  Instead, scientists have had to use recreational drug users as subjects in their studies. Conclusions from this are often flawed because few, if any, drugs users use ecstasy in isolation.   Cannabis user   Mr A was also a heavy cannabis user, and when he was encouraged to decrease his use, his paranoia and hallucinations disappeared and his anxiety abated. But his memory and concentration problems remained, leading the doctors to suspect that these may be permanent disabilities.   When he was admitted to a specialist brain injury unit and put on anti-psychotic medication, he did start to show some improvement. "Unfortunately, he discharged himself before we were able to complete the assessment," says Dr Kouimtsidis. "We continued to support him. But he started to use cannabis again and he dropped out. We tried to re-engage him but we lost him about a year ago."   The Guardian made several attempts to find the man without success.   Effects of ecstasy   MDMA is one the
 most intensely studied recreational drugs in history. But despite thousands of research papers and studies, scientific evidence on the side-effects remains inconclusive.   Death by overdose   Undoubtedly, large amounts of ecstasy can lead to over-heating which in turn, in rare cases, can trigger fatal heat stroke. Many factors contribute: number and strength of pills taken, environment, alcohol-consumption, body weight - but women seem more at risk. The bulk of ecstasy-related deaths around the world have been young women.   Water-poisoning   Panicking users, fearing they are overdosing, drink too much water and provoke hyponaetraemia (water-poisoning). Leah Betts died after drinking 14 pints in just 90 minutes. The recommended amount of water to drink per hour is one pint.   Toxic reactions   Much of the reports of toxic reactions are muddled with overdose or water-poisoning deaths. There is no clear evidence that some people suffer allergic reactions to ecstasy. However,
 around 10% of Western users do lack a key liver enzyme CYP2D6 needed to break down MDMA. This may make them more sensitive to the effects and more prone to accidental overdose.   Depression   Many weekend users report a mid-week mood dip. This is suspected to be related MDMA's effect on serotonin, but hard evidence is lacking. In heavy users, dips can turn to crashes and depression. However studies suggest this effect reverses after a 2-3 month abstinence.   Positive effects   Users still claim "long lasting improvements in self-awareness, self-esteem, openness and insight into personal problems", reports the study from the University Of Louisiana. In the US, research continues into the use of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy to treat Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.




  
Special report
Drugs in Britain

Subject: [sfraves] Weekend Review: WOW.. Good Fuckin' Shit man!!  LMAO :)

So ok.. like yeah.. ummm... Friday was Dope!!! :)

Got out 2 BART, stopped over in Berkeley & picked up Gravie, went 2 Maz &
Al'z pad 4 a bit.. then got 2 1015 :)  Wow!  OK... so i was like upstairs
in the Jungle room mainly for the whole night.. like i rarely traveled out
of it
'cause well... ok...

DJ M opened up & lol.. I Love it.. I mean... I'm still always like kinda
always expecting his usual Atmo Jungle sets that  i always used 2 hear him
spin & stuff all the time like @ An Sabin & stuff... but yeah.. so i was
was hella buggin' when i got there & he was all on the hard dubby jungle
tip.. really fuckin' Sick for an opening set & seting the tone for the
night! :)

Genome went on next & continued the Groovy flow!!! Oh man... I mean... he
was seriously makin' me high when i was dancing... again... just gotta
love the hard cubby stuff :)

LoL.. it was during Genome's set when I saw this dude walk up to lke
behind the decks & like put his bag down... I was like thinkin' he look
familiar, so i went up 2 him.. then when he like turned around I like
pushed his shoulder & gave him a hug.. it was Klute!!!  LoL.. the 1st
thing he said to me was, "Oshbee, I read on the net somewhere that you
weren't goin' ta be here 2night"... then i told him that I only get 2 kick
it w/ him once a year.. twice if i'm lucky.. & we just had this mondo
catch  up chat.. LoL... OK.. so I made a deal w/ him that i wouldn't call
him Santa Klute anymore 'cause he lost alooooooooota weight!  YAY.. it was
Dope hangin with him & talking & stuff.. lol YAY!

ok.. Amit did his live dnb PA.. OK.. ya know.. like he opened w/ his this
1/2 step, Hip Hoppie song/ intro thingie that had this Male Vocal Sample
that said "Amit..... Commercial Suicide.... (repeat)" then that song
played like for i dunno.. 20 minutes- 1/2 hour.. I mean..i guess he needed
to set up the instruments on his lap top?  But I dunno.. it was like hella
exciting when he openedup & for a few minutes.. but yeah... i started
losing interest & ok.. that's wheni walked around... but yeah.. like when
i got back in the jungle room, he was playing like i dunno.. it was mellow
jungle stuff... like it was good.. & I danced.. but it wasn't really my
taste though honestly.. but Amit is a Duper nice guy.. we chatted for a
while & he's Awesome!  Hmmm...

OK.. Klute went on next & strait killed it!!!  He was playijng on the CD
decks & I guess he played alota unreleased & new stuff?  But yeah.. it was
just I mean.. hard ass fuckin' jungle...

Kinda left teh club early (danke Unka), but yeah.. it was a fun night...
granted i never left the top floor really & barely caught any of the
breaks sets reall.. well.. i was there 4 Smoove 4 like 5 minutes in the
main room...

Saturday Night:

After a loooooooooong task of like trying to saving some1... me & Unka
went 2 Whisper for the Evil Breaks/ Space Cowboys shindig... it was fun..
like when we just got there, Chris Carter was on the decks up stairs..
danced a lil.. ok... like there wre aloooooota Homies there that i ain't
seen in a long time.. so i mainly spent the night there in the patio
thingie talking & catching up w/ every1!  So Dope!

After like 2 hours, me & Unka went 2 the EGR 8 Yr Annv Loft Shindig!! 
WOW!!  So Dope!!!  LIke there was this mondo chill room & this mondo
techno room... wasn't able to catch all the DJs/ Live Performers, but did
catch Maz *& his Techno/ Electro/ Cheesey live Pa.. LoL.. Loved it! :)  Oh
ohoh.. & Family was there!!  It was soooooo nice & refreshing seeing my
family!!!  Love U Guys!  But yeah.. it was a good time there also..
dancing 2 yummy techno & catching up w/ like every1

oh oh oh.. i even saw 1 of the busdrivers in Hercules there!  Hello 2day..
LOLOLOLMAO.. it was So Dope!

I mean.. ok... so like this weekend meant alot 2 me... it did!!!  YAAAY!!

--- CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com> wrote:

> The story of Mr. A:
>    
>   >>
>    
>  
>
http://www.guardian.co.uk/drugs/Story/0,,1746333,00.html?gusrc=rss
>    
>   >>
>    
>   The strange case of the man who took 40,000
> ecstasy pills in nine years 
> 
> · Usage increased to 25 tablets a day at peak
> · Memory problems and paranoia may be lasting 
> 
> David McCandless
> Tuesday April 4, 2006
> The Guardian 
> 
>   Doctors from London University have revealed
> details of what they believe is the largest amount
> of ecstasy ever consumed by a single person.
> Consultants from the addiction centre at St George's
> Medical School, London, have published a case report
> of a British man estimated to have taken around
> 40,000 pills of MDMA, the active ingredient in
> ecstasy, over nine years. The heaviest previous
> lifetime intake on record is 2,000 pills.   Though
> the man, who is now 37, stopped taking the drug
> seven years ago, he still suffers from severe
> physical and mental health side-effects, including
> extreme memory problems, paranoia, hallucinations
> and depression. He also suffers from painful muscle
> rigidity around his neck and jaw which often
> prevents him from opening his mouth. The doctors
> believe many of these symptoms may be permanent.  
> The man, known as Mr A in the report in the
> scientific journal Psychosomatics, started using
> ecstasy at 21. For the first two years his use was
> an
>  average of five pills per weekend. Gradually this
> escalated until he was taking around three and a
> half pills a day. At the peak, the man was taking an
> estimated 25 pills every day for four years. After
> several severe collapses at parties, Mr A decided to
> stop taking ecstasy. For several months, he still
> felt he was under the influence of the drug, despite
> being bedridden.   Hallucinations   His condition
> deteriorated and he began to experience recurrent
> tunnel vision and other problems including
> hallucinations, paranoia and muscle rigidity. "He
> came to us after deciding that he couldn't go on any
> more," said Dr Christos Kouimtsidis, the consultant
> psychiatrist at St George's Medical School in
> Tooting who treated him for five months. "He was
> having trouble functioning in everyday life."   The
> doctors discovered that the man was suffering from
> severe short-term memory problems of a type usually
> only seen in lifetime alcoholics. But evaluating the
> full extent of his
>  condition was difficult as his concentration and
> attention was so impaired he was unable to follow
> the simple tasks involved in the test.   "This was
> an exceptional case. His long- term memory was fine
> but he could not remember day to day things - the
> time, the day, what was in his supermarket trolley,"
> said Dr Kouimtsidis. "More worryingly, he did not
> seem aware himself that he had these memory
> problems."   With no mental illness in his family
> and no prior psychiatric history, the doctors
> concluded that his unique condition was direct
> result of his intense ecstasy use.   "This is
> obviously an extreme case so we should not blow any
> observations out of proportion," says Dr
> Kouimtsidis. "But if this is what is happening to
> very heavy users, it might be an indication that
> daily use of ecstasy over a long period of time can
> lead to irreversible memory problems and other
> cognitive deficits."   For 10 years, MDMA has been
> suspected of causing these kinds of effects in heavy
>  users. It is thought to be due to its disruption of
> the regulation of serotonin, a brain chemical
> believed to play a role in mood and memory. It
> remains unclear whether these effects are the result
> of permanent neurotoxic damage or just temporary
> reversible alterations in the brain.   A study today
> in a special MDMA issue of the British Journal of
> Psychopharmacology, suggests long-term side-effects
> may be temporary. The researchers from the
> University Of Louisiana could find no significant
> relationship between depression and recreational
> ecstasy use.   In the case of Mr A, a structural MRI
> brain scan failed to show any obvious damage or
> atrophy in his brain. However, these results, says
> Dr Kouimtsidis, are difficult to interpret. "A scan
> of this type is not sensitive enough," he said.  
> Such limitations in brain scanning technology, along
> with ethical and legal barriers to giving MDMA to
> human test subjects, have limited direct observation
> of the drug's effects in humans. 
>   Instead, scientists have had to use recreational
> drug users as subjects in their studies. Conclusions
> from this are often flawed because few, if any,
> drugs users use ecstasy in isolation.   Cannabis
> user   Mr A was also a heavy cannabis user, and when
> he was encouraged to decrease his use, his paranoia
> and hallucinations disappeared and his anxiety
> abated. But his memory and concentration problems
> remained, leading the doctors to suspect that these
> may be permanent disabilities.   When he was
> admitted to a specialist brain injury unit and put
> on anti-psychotic medication, he did start to show
> some improvement. "Unfortunately, he discharged
> himself before we were able to complete the
> assessment," says Dr Kouimtsidis. "We continued to
> support him. But he started to use cannabis again
> and he dropped out. We tried to re-engage him but we
> lost him about a year ago."   The Guardian made
> several attempts to find the man without success.  
> Effects of ecstasy   MDMA is one the
>  most intensely studied recreational drugs in
> history. But despite thousands of research papers
> and studies, scientific evidence on the side-effects
> remains inconclusive.   Death by overdose  
> Undoubtedly, large amounts of ecstasy can lead to
> over-heating which in turn, in rare cases, can
> trigger fatal heat stroke. Many factors contribute:
> number and strength of pills taken, environment,
> alcohol-consumption, body weight - but women seem
> more at risk. The bulk of ecstasy-related deaths
> around the world have been young women.  
> Water-poisoning   Panicking users, fearing they are
> overdosing, drink too much water and provoke
> hyponaetraemia (water-poisoning). Leah Betts died
> after drinking 14 pints in just 90 minutes. The
> recommended amount of water to drink per hour is one
> pint.   Toxic reactions   Much of the reports of
> toxic reactions are muddled with overdose or
> water-poisoning deaths. There is no clear evidence
> that some people suffer allergic reactions to
> ecstasy. However,
>  around 10% of Western users do lack a key liver
> enzyme CYP2D6 needed to break down MDMA. This may
> make them more sensitive to the effects and more
> prone to accidental overdose.   Depression   Many
> weekend users report a mid-week mood dip. This is
> suspected to be related MDMA's effect on serotonin,
> but hard evidence is lacking. In heavy users, dips
> can turn to crashes and depression. However studies
> suggest this effect reverses after a 2-3 month
> abstinence.   Positive effects   Users still claim
> "long lasting improvements in self-awareness,
> self-esteem, openness and insight into personal
> problems", reports the study from the University Of
> Louisiana. In the US, research continues into the
> use of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy to treat Post
> Traumatic Stress Disorder.
> 
> 
> 
> 
>   
> Special report
> Drugs in Britain
>

On 4/4/06, Delia <velouria83@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> all i have to say is what a fucking idiot! i mean do
> you even feel it anymore after that prolonged of a
> use? thats absolutely ridiculous...
>
> -Delia
>
> --- CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> > The story of Mr. A:
> >
> >   >>
> >
> >
> >
> http://www.guardian.co.uk/drugs/Story/0,,1746333,00.html?gusrc=3Drss
> >
> >   >>
> >
> >   The strange case of the man who took 40,000
> > ecstasy pills in nine years
> >
> > =B7 Usage increased to 25 tablets a day at peak
> > =B7 Memory problems and paranoia may be lasting
> >
> > David McCandless
> > Tuesday April 4, 2006
> > The Guardian
> >
> >   Doctors from London University have revealed
> > details of what they believe is the largest amount
> > of ecstasy ever consumed by a single person.
> > Consultants from the addiction centre at St George's
> > Medical School, London, have published a case report
> > of a British man estimated to have taken around
> > 40,000 pills of MDMA, the active ingredient in
> > ecstasy, over nine years. The heaviest previous
> > lifetime intake on record is 2,000 pills.   Though
> > the man, who is now 37, stopped taking the drug
> > seven years ago, he still suffers from severe
> > physical and mental health side-effects, including
> > extreme memory problems, paranoia, hallucinations
> > and depression. He also suffers from painful muscle
> > rigidity around his neck and jaw which often
> > prevents him from opening his mouth. The doctors
> > believe many of these symptoms may be permanent.
> > The man, known as Mr A in the report in the
> > scientific journal Psychosomatics, started using
> > ecstasy at 21. For the first two years his use was
> > an
> >  average of five pills per weekend. Gradually this
> > escalated until he was taking around three and a
> > half pills a day. At the peak, the man was taking an
> > estimated 25 pills every day for four years. After
> > several severe collapses at parties, Mr A decided to
> > stop taking ecstasy. For several months, he still
> > felt he was under the influence of the drug, despite
> > being bedridden.   Hallucinations   His condition
> > deteriorated and he began to experience recurrent
> > tunnel vision and other problems including
> > hallucinations, paranoia and muscle rigidity. "He
> > came to us after deciding that he couldn't go on any
> > more," said Dr Christos Kouimtsidis, the consultant
> > psychiatrist at St George's Medical School in
> > Tooting who treated him for five months. "He was
> > having trouble functioning in everyday life."   The
> > doctors discovered that the man was suffering from
> > severe short-term memory problems of a type usually
> > only seen in lifetime alcoholics. But evaluating the
> > full extent of his
> >  condition was difficult as his concentration and
> > attention was so impaired he was unable to follow
> > the simple tasks involved in the test.   "This was
> > an exceptional case. His long- term memory was fine
> > but he could not remember day to day things - the
> > time, the day, what was in his supermarket trolley,"
> > said Dr Kouimtsidis. "More worryingly, he did not
> > seem aware himself that he had these memory
> > problems."   With no mental illness in his family
> > and no prior psychiatric history, the doctors
> > concluded that his unique condition was direct
> > result of his intense ecstasy use.   "This is
> > obviously an extreme case so we should not blow any
> > observations out of proportion," says Dr
> > Kouimtsidis. "But if this is what is happening to
> > very heavy users, it might be an indication that
> > daily use of ecstasy over a long period of time can
> > lead to irreversible memory problems and other
> > cognitive deficits."   For 10 years, MDMA has been
> > suspected of causing these kinds of effects in heavy
> >  users. It is thought to be due to its disruption of
> > the regulation of serotonin, a brain chemical
> > believed to play a role in mood and memory. It
> > remains unclear whether these effects are the result
> > of permanent neurotoxic damage or just temporary
> > reversible alterations in the brain.   A study today
> > in a special MDMA issue of the British Journal of
> > Psychopharmacology, suggests long-term side-effects
> > may be temporary. The researchers from the
> > University Of Louisiana could find no significant
> > relationship between depression and recreational
> > ecstasy use.   In the case of Mr A, a structural MRI
> > brain scan failed to show any obvious damage or
> > atrophy in his brain. However, these results, says
> > Dr Kouimtsidis, are difficult to interpret. "A scan
> > of this type is not sensitive enough," he said.
> > Such limitations in brain scanning technology, along
> > with ethical and legal barriers to giving MDMA to
> > human test subjects, have limited direct observation
> > of the drug's effects in humans.
> >   Instead, scientists have had to use recreational
> > drug users as subjects in their studies. Conclusions
> > from this are often flawed because few, if any,
> > drugs users use ecstasy in isolation.   Cannabis
> > user   Mr A was also a heavy cannabis user, and when
> > he was encouraged to decrease his use, his paranoia
> > and hallucinations disappeared and his anxiety
> > abated. But his memory and concentration problems
> > remained, leading the doctors to suspect that these
> > may be permanent disabilities.   When he was
> > admitted to a specialist brain injury unit and put
> > on anti-psychotic medication, he did start to show
> > some improvement. "Unfortunately, he discharged
> > himself before we were able to complete the
> > assessment," says Dr Kouimtsidis. "We continued to
> > support him. But he started to use cannabis again
> > and he dropped out. We tried to re-engage him but we
> > lost him about a year ago."   The Guardian made
> > several attempts to find the man without success.
> > Effects of ecstasy   MDMA is one the
> >  most intensely studied recreational drugs in
> > history. But despite thousands of research papers
> > and studies, scientific evidence on the side-effects
> > remains inconclusive.   Death by overdose
> > Undoubtedly, large amounts of ecstasy can lead to
> > over-heating which in turn, in rare cases, can
> > trigger fatal heat stroke. Many factors contribute:
> > number and strength of pills taken, environment,
> > alcohol-consumption, body weight - but women seem
> > more at risk. The bulk of ecstasy-related deaths
> > around the world have been young women.
> > Water-poisoning   Panicking users, fearing they are
> > overdosing, drink too much water and provoke
> > hyponaetraemia (water-poisoning). Leah Betts died
> > after drinking 14 pints in just 90 minutes. The
> > recommended amount of water to drink per hour is one
> > pint.   Toxic reactions   Much of the reports of
> > toxic reactions are muddled with overdose or
> > water-poisoning deaths. There is no clear evidence
> > that some people suffer allergic reactions to
> > ecstasy. However,
> >  around 10% of Western users do lack a key liver
> > enzyme CYP2D6 needed to break down MDMA. This may
> > make them more sensitive to the effects and more
> > prone to accidental overdose.   Depression   Many
> > weekend users report a mid-week mood dip. This is
> > suspected to be related MDMA's effect on serotonin,
> > but hard evidence is lacking. In heavy users, dips
> > can turn to crashes and depression. However studies
> > suggest this effect reverses after a 2-3 month
> > abstinence.   Positive effects   Users still claim
> > "long lasting improvements in self-awareness,
> > self-esteem, openness and insight into personal
> > problems", reports the study from the University Of
> > Louisiana. In the US, research continues into the
> > use of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy to treat Post
> > Traumatic Stress Disorder.

 From Jeno....

Monument, a tribute to WICKED - 9pm tonite on noisefromthevoid.com


Date & Time:
Tuesday, April 4, 2006
9:00 PM
Hello friends..

There will be no guest on noisefromthevoid this week..

Instead - as it's almost exactly 15 years since the first ever WICKED  
party - I will be presenting the first couple of hours of the show as  
a monument to it's memory. I'll be spinning a few classic Wicked  
tracks interspersed with some personal reflections, thoughts,  
feelings, maybe a story or two, and finally a look into the future.  
The second part of the show will be a more regular noisefromthevoid  
mix of old and new musical treats and suprises - from cosmic disco to  
punk rock fun..

9pm - very late. Tune in early to catch the Wickedness..

go to 90hz.org to LISTEN and CHAT..



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-3-519200770--

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Thurday 4/6 @ the Alpha Bar

Hi everyone! That's right, our monday night at the Alpha bar has officially moved to thursdays. Come check out some quality jams, and have some affordable drinks. We'll be rockin' out anything from techno to breaks to downtempo.

On Thursday 4/6 we are proud to present........

Praxis
(Omniscient / Intellihance Records)

Atom Weaver
(Omniscient / ASR)


And of course, your resident regulars are
Evinrude, Dirt, Nugz, Dru, m.d.K,
G.A.M.M.A., E-Rok, and DJ Jeremy.

@lpha bar is located at 3848 Geary, almost at the corner of 3rd Ave. It's a very relaxing, swanky, comfotable lounge-type club. We hope to see you!

Subject: [sfraves] Feat. Artist of the Month: DJ Brian - Moontribe

Hey everybody just thought I would pass on to you that on 
www.movementnow.com
we have started a new page (A featured artist page!) to help keep things 
fresh and showcase
people from around the country who are helping make things happen. We will 
be updating
it every month with a new artist, along with their bio and a tasty mix set. 
Yes that's right
more free music! I think we all know that we can't have enough of that.

So without further ado our first featured artist:

..::April::..
<<DJ Brian>>
aka Brian Seed (Moontribe, Ritual Sounds, Ball of Wax)

www.moontribe.org
www.ritualsounds.com
www.ballofwax.com

This month's artist is someone very special to all of us outdoor partiers. 
He's been
trailblazing new sounds from his amazing mix's on Moonshine's "Hard Desert 
Trance"
series in the late 90's, to his completely unbelievable live sets at events 
like Moontribe. Lately
he's immersed himself in the studio working with the likes of John Kelley, 
Amani vs. Teapot and
our very own Phokus on his label Ritual Sounds. It was our pleasure to 
showcase this
wonderful DJ at Nowloween and we are glad to be in his presence again.

Please check him out @ www.movementnow.com and download or stream his mix.

Also feel free to check out our other artist's and download all of the sets 
in our mixes section.

Thanks for your time and enjoy,

P 


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

venues though...

believe Saturday was the last night of its existence

haven't been since christmas time...

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "G.A.M.M.A." <gamma@techno-truth.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:07 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Feat. Artist of the Month: DJ Brian - Moontribe


> Hey everybody just thought I would pass on to you that on 
> www.movementnow.com
> we have started a new page (A featured artist page!) to help keep things 
> fresh and showcase
> people from around the country who are helping make things happen. We will 
> be updating
> it every month with a new artist, along with their bio and a tasty mix 
> set. Yes that's right
> more free music! I think we all know that we can't have enough of that.
>
> So without further ado our first featured artist:
>
> ..::April::..
> <<DJ Brian>>
> aka Brian Seed (Moontribe, Ritual Sounds, Ball of Wax)
>
> www.moontribe.org
> www.ritualsounds.com
> www.ballofwax.com
>
> This month's artist is someone very special to all of us outdoor partiers. 
> He's been
> trailblazing new sounds from his amazing mix's on Moonshine's "Hard Desert 
> Trance"
> series in the late 90's, to his completely unbelievable live sets at 
> events like Moontribe. Lately
> he's immersed himself in the studio working with the likes of John Kelley, 
> Amani vs. Teapot and
> our very own Phokus on his label Ritual Sounds. It was our pleasure to 
> showcase this
> wonderful DJ at Nowloween and we are glad to be in his presence again.
>
> Please check him out @ www.movementnow.com and download or stream his mix.
>
> Also feel free to check out our other artist's and download all of the 
> sets in our mixes section.
>
> Thanks for your time and enjoy,
>
> P
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] your favorite venues?

I like Mighty when the sound doesn't suck ass. But the whole liquor in 
plastic cups thing SUCKS ASS, and the drink prices are insane there (for the 
small amount of liquor u get).

Mezzanine can be cool too - the bar sure is better there (shaddap, I do rate 
clubs by bar too - it's a factor!).

Anu is always fun for a tiny spot, and so are the Sublounge and Amnesia.

I'm actually starting to kind of like 1015. It's not nearly as bad as folks 
out here made it to be when I 1st moved here. Sute the body cavity search 
sucks, but I am used to that from living back east so I know the routine and 
can get through it fast. They make STIFF fuckin' drinks there too - so 
despite the somewhat high prices, it's still worth it. More news about 1015 
later ;)

I like Mighty...I think they fit up to 500 or so...

Anu & Shine are cooler smaller venues...I guess they are more bars than
venues though...

Those are the 3 places I end up most regularly...sub lounge was cool, but I
believe Saturday was the last night of its existence

Smartbar in Chicago was always a favorite, but I heard they remodeled, and I
haven't been since christmas time...

>> partiers.

>> trailblazing new sounds from his amazing mix's on Moonshine's  
>> "Hard Desert
>> Trance"
>> series in the late 90's, to his completely unbelievable live sets at
>> events like Moontribe. Lately
>> he's immersed himself in the studio working with the likes of John  
>> Kelley,
>> Amani vs. Teapot and
>> our very own Phokus on his label Ritual Sounds. It was our  
>> pleasure to
>> showcase this
>> wonderful DJ at Nowloween and we are glad to be in his presence  
>> again.

>>> Hey everybody just thought I would pass on to you that on
>>> www.movementnow.com
>>> we have started a new page (A featured artist page!) to help keep  
>>> things
>>> fresh and showcase
>>> people from around the country who are helping make things happen.  
>>> We will
>>> be updating
>>> it every month with a new artist, along with their bio and a tasty  
>>> mix
>>> set. Yes that's right
>>> more free music! I think we all know that we can't have enough of  
>>> that.
>>>
>>> So without further ado our first featured artist:
>>>
>>> ..::April::..
>>> <<DJ Brian>>
>>> aka Brian Seed (Moontribe, Ritual Sounds, Ball of Wax)
>>>
>>> www.moontribe.org
>>> www.ritualsounds.com
>>> www.ballofwax.com
>>>
>>> This month's artist is someone very special to all of us outdoor  
>>> partiers.
>>> He's been
>>> trailblazing new sounds from his amazing mix's on Moonshine's  
>>> "Hard Desert
>>> Trance"
>>> series in the late 90's, to his completely unbelievable live sets at
>>> events like Moontribe. Lately
>>> he's immersed himself in the studio working with the likes of John  
>>> Kelley,
>>> Amani vs. Teapot and
>>> our very own Phokus on his label Ritual Sounds. It was our  
>>> pleasure to
>>> showcase this
>>> wonderful DJ at Nowloween and we are glad to be in his presence  
>>> again.
>>>
>>> Please check him out @ www.movementnow.com and download or stream  
>>> his mix.
>>>
>>> Also feel free to check out our other artist's and download all of  
>>> the
>>> sets in our mixes section.
>>>
>>> Thanks for your time and enjoy,
>>>
>>> P

--
1. Creativity and innovation always builds on the past.
2. The past always tries to control the creativity that builds on it.
3. Free societies enable the future by living in the past.
4. Ours is a less and less a free society.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno

--=====================_2708953==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Jeno has a poetic soul and it was in full effect last night on his special Wicked 15th anniversary radio show.  And so much excellent music from back in the Garden of Eden days of raving here in the Bay.  Good times;  extraordinary memories.

I'm listening to some of the recorded show now and I hear Jeno's comments on breaks:  "The only people who play breaks now are the burning man crowd....mostly white folks music these days."  LOL

Love,

Apollo

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_2708953==.ALT--

At 11:51 AM 4/5/2006, Bam wrote:
>hey, i'm not white!!!
>
>:(


I thought that comment would bring a reaction from you Bam :-)  The Wicked collective played lots of breaks in the early days, especially Garth.  Much respect for them.  Again, one hallmark of music in those days was diversity.  Many genres in a set.  

Love,

Apollo


>On 4/5/06, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
>> Jeno has a poetic soul and it was in full effect last night on his special Wicked 15th anniversary radio show.  And so much excellent music from back in the Garden of Eden days of raving here in the Bay.  Good times;  extraordinary memories.
>>
>> I'm listening to some of the recorded show now and I hear Jeno's comments on breaks:  "The only people who play breaks now are the burning man crowd....mostly white folks music these days."  LOL
>>
>> Love,
>>
>> Apollo
>>
>> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>>
>> Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>>
>> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>>
>> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>>
>> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
>> -Don Juan
>>
>> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
>> -Edward R. Murrow
>>
>> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
>> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>>
>>
>>
>>
>
>

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

At 11:56 AM 4/5/2006, Ben Haus wrote:
>Hey Apollo, is last night's show archived anywhere online.  I missed it sadly. 

The server was full the first few times I tried to get on.  When I did get in I was so happy it didn't occur to me to record.  When I realized what I was missing he was about an hour and a half into the show.  I did manage to record about 3 1/2 hours.  I don't know right now if the full program is available anywhere else but I'll check.

Love,

Apollo

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno

well, i'll be the first to admit that i would like to see more
diversity in this scene.  and i mean diversity of all kinds.

age, self expression, race, culture, sexuality.

i don't like elitism and as much as Evil Breaks has gained support
from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever forget
that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the dance
community.

i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about breaks, but
i do understand why he would.

At 12:09 PM 4/5/2006, Bam wrote:
>well, i'll be the first to admit that i would like to see more
>diversity in this scene.  and i mean diversity of all kinds.
>
>age, self expression, race, culture, sexuality.
>
>i don't like elitism and as much as Evil Breaks has gained support
>from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever forget
>that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the dance
>community.
>
>i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about breaks, but
>i do understand why he would.

Breaks have changed since the late 80s early 90s.  As I recall there was an explosion of breakbeat at the time, along with house and hip hop.  There was more of a "soulful" quality to it all and Jeno's point was that house has maintained that soulfulness.  The musical landscape WAS very different back then.  He was comparing dance music then to dance music now and I might add Jeno followed with a comment that breaks have always been an integral part of dance music.  

In those days, however, one played "dance" music.  All these genres and subgenres now didn't exist.  The only radical division was between the trance ravers and the more downtempo, Wicked-style events.  The gay subculture was just beginning to introduce house in the big clubs.  Queer parties like Uranus did wild combos of punk, house, pop, industrial..anything danceable.  Again, diverse, free-form.

>> -Don Juan

>> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
>> -Edward R. Murrow
>>
>> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
>> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Funny post on thepoorman.net:

------=_Part_35699_17965326.1144266259395
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I actually read a recent article over a GNN.tv that has brought some of the
lesser talked about issues surrounding the  illegal immigration debate.
Although I don't believe we should kick out every person that is here
illegally, we do need to come up with a plan to allow our government to
track and regulate who is within our country.


Here's the article from GNN

By Thom Hartmann
Labor is left behind

The corporatist Republicans ("amnesty!") are fighting with the racist
Republicans ("fence!"), and it provides an opportunity for progressives to
step forward with a clear solution to the immigration problem facing
America.

Both the corporatists and the racists are fond of the mantra, "There are
some jobs Americans won't do." It's a lie.

Americans will do virtually any job if they're paid a decent wage. This
isn't about immigration =96 it's about economics. Industry and agriculture
won't collapse without illegal labor, but the middle class is being crushed
by it.

The reason why thirty years ago United Farm Workers' Union (UFW) founder
Caesar Ch=E1vez fought against illegal immigration, and the UFW turned in
illegals during his tenure as president, was because Ch=E1vez, like
progressives since the 1870s, understood the simple reality that labor rise=
s
and falls in price as a function of availability.

As Wikipedia notes: "In 1969, Ch=E1vez and members of the UFW marched throu=
gh
the Imperial and Coachella Valley to the border of Mexico to protest
growers' use of illegal aliens as temporary replacement workers during a
strike. Joining him on the march were both the Reverend Ralph Abernathy and
U.S. Senator Walter Mondale. Ch=E1vez and the UFW would often report suspec=
ted
illegal aliens who served as temporary replacement workers as well as who
refused to unionize to the INS."

Working Americans have always known this simple equation: More workers,
lower wages. Fewer workers, higher wages.

Progressives fought =96 and many lost their lives in the battle =96 to limi=
t the
pool of "labor hours" available to the Robber Barons from the 1870s through
the 1930s and thus created the modern middle class. They limited labor-hour=
s
by pushing for the 50-hour week and the 10-hour day (and then later the
40-hour week and the 8-hour day). They limited labor-hours by pushing for
laws against child labor (which competed with adult labor). They limited
labor-hours by working for passage of the 1935 Wagner Act that provided for
union shops.

And they limited labor-hours by supporting laws that would regulate
immigration into the United States to a small enough flow that it wouldn't
dilute the unionized labor pool. As Wikipedia notes: "The first laws
creating a quota for immigrants were passed in the 1920s, in response to a
sense that the country could no longer absorb large numbers of unskilled
workers, despite pleas by big business that it wanted the new workers."

Do a little math. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says there are 7.6 million
unemployed Americans right now. Another 1.5 million Americans are no longer
counted because they've become "long term" or "discouraged" unemployed
workers. And although various groups have different ways of measuring it,
most agree that at least another five to ten million Americans are either
working part-time when they want to work full-time, or are "underemployed,"
doing jobs below their level of training, education, or experience. That's
between eight and twenty million un- and under-employed Americans, many
unable to find above-poverty-level work.

At the same time, there are between seven and fifteen million working
illegal immigrants diluting our labor pool.

If illegal immigrants could no longer work, unions would flourish, the
minimum wage would rise, and oligarchic nations to our south would have to
confront and fix their corrupt ways.

Between the Reagan years =96 when there were only around one to two million
illegal aliens in our workforce =96 and today, we've gone from about 25
percent of our private workforce being unionized to around seven percent.
Much of this is the direct result =96 as Caesar Ch=E1vez predicted =96 of i=
llegal
immigrants competing directly with unionized and legal labor. Although it's
most obvious in the construction trades over the past 30 years, it's hit al=
l
sectors of our economy.

Democratic Party strategist Ann Lewis just sent out a mass email on behalf
of former Wal-Mart Board of Directors member and now Senator Hillary Rodham
Clinton. In it, Lewis noted that Clinton suggests we should have: "An earne=
d
path to citizenship for those already here working hard, paying taxes,
respecting the law, and willing to meet a high bar for becoming a citizen."
Sounds nice. The same day, on his radio program, Rush Limbaugh told a woman
whose husband is an illegal immigrant that she had nothing to worry about
with regard to deportation of him or their children because all he'd have t=
o
do =96 under the new law under consideration =96 is pay a small fine and le=
arn
English.

The current directors of Wal-Mart are smiling.

Meanwhile, the millions of American citizens who came to this nation as
legal immigrants, who waited in line for years, who did the hard work to
become citizens, are feeling insulted, humiliated, and conned.

Shouldn't we be compassionate? Of course.

But there is nothing compassionate about driving down the wages of any
nation's middle class. It's the most cynical, self-serving, greedy, and
sociopathic behavior you'll see from our "conservatives."

There is nothing compassionate about being the national enabler of a
dysfunctional oligarchy like Mexico. An illegal workforce in the U.S.
sending an estimated $17 billion to Mexico every year =96 second only in
national income to that country's oil revenues =96 supports an antidemocrat=
ic,
anti-worker, hyperconservative administration there that gleefully ships ou=
t
of that nation the "troublesome" Mexican citizens =96 those lowest on the
economic food-chain and thus most likely to present "labor unrest" =96 to t=
he
USA. Mexico (and other "sending nations") need not deal with their own
social and economic problems so long as we're willing to solve them for the=
m
=96 at the expense of our middle class. Democracy in Central and South Amer=
ica
be damned =96 there are profits to be made for Wal-Mart!

Similarly, there is nothing compassionate about handing higher profits
(through a larger and thus cheaper work force) to the CEOs of America's
largest corporations and our now-experiencing-record-profits construction
and agriculture industries.

What about caring for people in need? Isn't that the universal
religious/ethical value? Of course.

A few years ago, when my family and I were visiting Europe, one of our
children fell sick. A doctor came to the home of the people we were staying
with, visited our child at 11 pm on a weeknight, left behind a course of
antibiotics, and charged nothing. It was paid for by that nation's universa=
l
health care system. We should offer the same to any human being in need of
medical care =96 a universal human right =96 in the United States.

But if I'd applied to that nation I was visiting for a monthly unemployment
or retirement check, I would have been laughed out of the local government
office. And if I'd been caught working there, I would have been deported
within a week. Caring for people in crisis/need is very different from
giving a job or a monthly welfare check to non-citizens. No nation =96 even
those in Central and South America =96 will do that. And neither should the
United States.

But if illegal immigrants won't pick our produce or bus our tables won't ou=
r
prices go up? (The most recent mass-emailed conservative variation of this
argument, targeting paranoid middle-class Americans says: "Do you want to
pay an extra $10,000 for your next house?") The answer is simple: Yes.

But wages would also go up, and even faster than housing or food prices. An=
d
CEO salaries, and corporate profits, might moderate back to the levels they
were during the "golden age of the American middle class" between the 1940s
and Reagan's declaration of war on the middle class in the 1980s.

We saw exactly this scenario played out in the U.S. fifty years ago, when
unions helped regulate entry into the workforce, 35 percent of American
workers had a union job, and 70 percent of Americans could raise a family o=
n
a single, 40-hour-week paycheck. All working Americans would gladly pay a
bit more for their food if their paychecks were both significantly higher
and more secure. (This would even allow for an increase in the minimum wage
=96 as it did from the 1930s to the 1980s.)

But what about repressive r=E9gimes? Aren't we denying entrance to this
generation's equivalent of the Jews fleeing Germany? This is the most tragi=
c
of all the arguments put forward by conservatives in the hopes compassionat=
e
progressives will bite. Our immigration policies already allow for refugees
=96 and should be expanded. It's an issue that needs more national discussi=
on
and action. But giving a free pass to former Coca-Cola executive Vincente
Fox to send workers to the US =96 and thus avoid having to deal with his ow=
n
corrupt oligarchy =96 and to equate this to the Holocaust is an insult to t=
he
memory of those who died in Hitler's death camps =96 and to those suffering=
 in
places like Darfur under truly repressive regimes. There is no equivalence.

It's frankly astonishing to hear "progressives" reciting
corporatist/racist/conservative talking points, recycled through
"conservative Democratic" politicians trying to pander to the relatively
small percentage of recently-legal (mostly through recent amnesties or
birth) immigrants who are trying to get their relatives into this country b=
y
means of Bush's proposed guest worker program or the many variations thereo=
f
being proposed.

It's equally astonishing to hear the few unions going along with this (in
the sad/desperate hope of picking up new members) turn their backs on Caesa=
r
Ch=E1vez and the traditions and history of America's Progressive and Union
movements by embracing illegal immigration.

Every nation has an obligation to limit immigration to a number that will
not dilute its workforce, but will maintain a stable middle class =96 if it
wants to have a stable democracy. This has nothing to do with race, nationa=
l
origin, or language (visit Switzerland with it's ethnic- and language-dived
areas!), and everything to do with economics.

Without a middle class, any democracy is doomed. And without labor having =
=96
through control of labor availability =96 power in relative balance to
capital/management, no middle class can emerge. America's early labor
leaders did not die to increase the labor pool for the Robber Barons or the
Walton family =96 they died fighting to give control of it to the workers o=
f
their era and in the hopes that we would continue to hold it =96 and infect
other nations with the same idea of democracy and a stable middle class.

The simple way to do this today is to require that all non-refugee
immigrants go through the same process to become American citizens or legal
workers in this country (no amnesties, no "guest workers," no
"legalizations") regardless of how they got here; to confront employers who
hire illegals with draconian financial and criminal penalties; and to affir=
m
that while health care (and the right to provide humanitarian care to all
humans) is an absolute right for all people within our boundaries regardles=
s
of status, a paycheck, education, or subsidy is not.

The Republican (and Democratic) corporatists who want a cheap labor force,
and the Republican (and Democratic) racists who want to build a fence and
punish humanitarian aid workers, are equally corrupt and anti-progressive.
As long as employers are willing and able (without severe penalties) to hir=
e
illegal workers, people will risk life and limb to grab at the America
Dream. When we stop hiring and paying them, most will leave of their own
volition over a few years, and the remaining few who are committed to the
U.S. will obtain citizenship through normal channels.

This is, after all, the middle-class "American Dream." And how much better
this hemisphere would be if Central and South Americans were motivated to
stay in their own nations (because no employer in the U.S. would dare hire
them) and fight there for a Mexican Dream and a Salvadoran Dream and a
Guatemalan Dream (and so on).

This is the historic Progressive vision for all of the Americas=85

Thom Hartmann <http://www.thomhartmann.com/> is a Project Censored
Award-winning best-selling author and host of a nationally syndicated daily
progressive talk show carried on the Air America Radio network and Sirius.
His most recent books include *What Would Jefferson
Do?*<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1400052092/commondreams-20/ref=
=3Dnosim/>and
*Ultimate Sacrifice* <http://www.ultimatesacrificethebook.com/> (co-authore=
d
with Lamar Waldron). His next book, due out this autumn, is *Screwed: The
Undeclared War on the Middle Class and What We Can Do About
It*<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1576754146/commondreams-20/ref=
=3Dnosim/>
.

I think you've all made valid points, but I have to agree with Apollo's
interpretation that breaks really doesn't have the amount of soul it used
to....  I love me some funky breaks and there's definitely a lack of them i=
n
the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th so I can get my
double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again
!

On 4/5/06, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> I know so many people of other races into breakbeats, it kind of (not
> much,
> but kind of) miffs me that he'd say that.
>
> I guess in comparison to the long standing house community, it IS a bit
> more
> of a caucasian genre, but the last few years the breaks community has had
> MORE diversity than any other I have experienced (and that applies to mor=
e
> than just ethnicity).
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
> To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> Cc: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 12:09 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno
>
>
> well, i'll be the first to admit that i would like to see more
> diversity in this scene.  and i mean diversity of all kinds.
>
> age, self expression, race, culture, sexuality.
>
> i don't like elitism and as much as Evil Breaks has gained support
> from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever forget
> that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the dance
> community.
>
> i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about breaks, but
> i do understand why he would.
>
>

> > >> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> > >>
> > >> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times
> as
> > >> you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one
> > >> question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My
> > >> benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was
> too
> > >> vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will
> tell
> > >> you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path
> is
> > >> good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
> > >> -Don Juan
> > >>
> > >> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> > >> -Edward R. Murrow
> > >>
> > >> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of
> > >> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually
> > >> become visible."
> > >> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>
