Thread-Index: AcZY66lxwK1vqz/qSiCM8iEC6hgMogAAZJNw
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno

Jeno - Energy

Look it up.  VERY hard to find mixtape from 1990.  My favorite mixtape of
ALL time.  A perfect representation of what Apollo is talking about and what
I believe Jeno was pointing out.  You don't happen to have this mix do you
Apollo??  If you do, or if anybody else does for that matter...PLEASE upload
it!!!!  

On a side note:  I think it's tough for folks who really weren't around back
then to feel "harshed" by his comments.  And no, I'm not trying to be and
elitist.  And no, early funky..non-breakbeat techno breaks tapes by DJ Dan
do NOT count.  He ripped off the early Wicked sound.


On another side note:  Who here has ever heard of Bills Hard to Find Records
in Texas??  I used to buy a LOT of recs from them...as well as sold quite a
few gems for WAY too much money.  Long story short:  As I did a ton of biz
with them, I got to know all the reps really well [I'm sure you break heads
know of Kelly Reverb] and they all told me that Dan would call in and
blatantly ask for what Garth and Jeno were buying/ playing.  Not cool.  But
I think Dan is an excellent DJ...maybe just not the evolutionist that some
may think..

CJ

I think you've all made valid points, but I have to agree with Apollo's
interpretation that breaks really doesn't have the amount of soul it used
to....  I love me some funky breaks and there's definitely a lack of them in
the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th so I can get my
double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again
!

Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky breaks to be =
found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so =
many people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle =
on 33". It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, =
but for some reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream. =


To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to *personally* =
play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' - =
but it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the =
one guy that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of =
breakbeat clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's =
charts.
  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: Ben Haus=20
  To: Marc(O)=20
  Cc: Bam ; Apollo ; SFRaves@hyperreal.org=20
  Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:00 PM
  Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


  I think you've all made valid points, but I have to agree with =
Apollo's interpretation that breaks really doesn't have the amount of =
soul it used to....  I love me some funky breaks and there's definitely =
a lack of them in the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th =
so I can get my double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again=20
  !

forget
    that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the dance
    community.

but
    i do understand why he would.

Plenty of funky breaks to be found....

James Brown is Dead!


On a serious tip....  I find myself ordering through vinyldj.com and gemm
when looking for funky breaks nowdays.  Where is this plethora of funky
breaks you speak of being put out in 2006?  I scour high and low on mp3
sites like beatport as well as a number of online stores, finding funky
breaks is a task, then finding something that is quality and that I like is
even harder!


On 4/5/06, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky breaks to be
> found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so man=
y
> people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle on 33=
".
> It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, but for so=
me
> reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream.
>
> To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to *personally*
> play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' - bu=
t
> it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the one =
guy
> that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of breakbeat
> clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's charts.

Depends on if you mean "funky breaks that sound just like that old skool =
stuff", or "funky ass breaks PERIOD". lol

Cuz honestly, I don't play TOO much stuff that sounds like recycled '95 =
beats. If I wanna play the old stuff, I'll dig throu my crates and play =
old stuff...

But if it's new and fresh and sleazy and funky...

www.streetwisemusic.co.uk=20

or www.dropshop.com=20

or www.dmswax.com=20

Of course these will have that "jungle on 33"  sound too, it IS popular, =
but if you are a sample digger like me, you can find PLENTY of funked =
out shit. It's all in how patient you are. I listen to HUNDREDS of =
samples when I'm record shopping, so I find a ton of stuff...
  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: Ben Haus=20
  To: Marc(O)=20
  Cc: Bam ; Apollo ; SFRaves@hyperreal.org=20
  Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:30 PM
  Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


  Plenty of funky breaks to be found....

  James Brown is Dead!


  On a serious tip....  I find myself ordering through vinyldj.com and =
gemm when looking for funky breaks nowdays.  Where is this plethora of =
funky breaks you speak of being put out in 2006?  I scour high and low =
on mp3 sites like beatport as well as a number of online stores, finding =
funky breaks is a task, then finding something that is quality and that =
I like is even harder!=20
   =20


  On 4/5/06, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
    Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky breaks to =
be found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so =
many people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle =
on 33". It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, =
but for some reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream. =


    To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to =
*personally* play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out =
and bangin' - but it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd =
rather be the one guy that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming =
in a sea of breakbeat clones, all playing the same top ten releases from =
this week's charts.

a lack of them in the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th =
so I can get my double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again=20
    !

but
      i do understand why he would.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
Cc: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>; "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>; 
<SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:40 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


Depends on if you mean "funky breaks that sound just like that old skool 
stuff", or "funky ass breaks PERIOD". lol

Cuz honestly, I don't play TOO much stuff that sounds like recycled '95 
beats. If I wanna play the old stuff, I'll dig throu my crates and play old 
stuff...

But if it's new and fresh and sleazy and funky...

www.streetwisemusic.co.uk

or www.dropshop.com

or www.dmswax.com

Of course these will have that "jungle on 33"  sound too, it IS popular, but 
if you are a sample digger like me, you can find PLENTY of funked out shit. 
It's all in how patient you are. I listen to HUNDREDS of samples when I'm 
record shopping, so I find a ton of stuff...
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Ben Haus
  To: Marc(O)
  Cc: Bam ; Apollo ; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
  Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:30 PM
  Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


  Plenty of funky breaks to be found....

  James Brown is Dead!


  On a serious tip....  I find myself ordering through vinyldj.com and gemm 
when looking for funky breaks nowdays.  Where is this plethora of funky 
breaks you speak of being put out in 2006?  I scour high and low on mp3 
sites like beatport as well as a number of online stores, finding funky 
breaks is a task, then finding something that is quality and that I like is 
even harder!



  On 4/5/06, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
    Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky breaks to be 
found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so many 
people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle on 33". 
It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, but for some 
reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream.

    To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to *personally* 
play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' - but 
it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the one guy 
that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of breakbeat 
clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's charts.
    ----- Original Message ----- 
    From: Ben Haus
    To: Marc(O)
    Cc: Bam ; Apollo ; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
    Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:00 PM
    Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


    I think you've all made valid points, but I have to agree with Apollo's 
interpretation that breaks really doesn't have the amount of soul it used 
to....  I love me some funky breaks and there's definitely a lack of them in 
the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th so I can get my 
double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again
    !


    On 4/5/06, Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
      I know so many people of other races into breakbeats, it kind of (not 
much,
      but kind of) miffs me that he'd say that.

      I guess in comparison to the long standing house community, it IS a 
bit more
      of a caucasian genre, but the last few years the breaks community has 
had
      MORE diversity than any other I have experienced (and that applies to 
more
      than just ethnicity).
      ----- Original Message -----
      From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
      To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
      Cc: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
      Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 12:09 PM
      Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno


      well, i'll be the first to admit that i would like to see more
      diversity in this scene.  and i mean diversity of all kinds.

      age, self expression, race, culture, sexuality.

      i don't like elitism and as much as Evil Breaks has gained support
      from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever forget
      that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the dance
      community.

      i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about breaks, but
      i do understand why he would.

      > >> question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.

      > >> benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood 
was too
      > >> vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I 
will tell
      > >> you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the 
path is
      > >> good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."

gradually

Mmm... any specific labels/producers?  You are giving me sites with
thousands of records!  But I have the feeling our interpretations of funky
breaks may differ.....  I'm looking for funky ass stuff like on the Fort
Knox Label.  Len Lewis' Label NuPoodle Breaks was putting out some more
tribally and tech house influenced breaks for a short period... but looks
like they went bust with that sublabel.

AHA!!!!

www.groovedis.com=20

It's FK5's distributor, and you can buy direct (and HELLA cheaper I =
might add). They have a TON of that funky sound....FK5, Allgood Funk =
Alliance, Dr. Rubberfunk, Citrona Records, Ursula 1000, etc.=20

I got like 15 records for under $90 there...just over $100 w/ shipping I =
think.=20

They don't have a ton of smaples, but they do have some, and other sites =
can provide the rest. ( I always keep a few diff. sites open to listen =
to samples when I'm shopping).=20

I highly suggest checking out that site if that's what you're looking =
for...and if you contact their online customer service, ask for Randall =
Van Kirk - he's SUPER helpful!!!

Happy shopping!

    Depends on if you mean "funky breaks that sound just like that old =
skool=20
    stuff", or "funky ass breaks PERIOD". lol

    Cuz honestly, I don't play TOO much stuff that sounds like recycled =
'95
    beats. If I wanna play the old stuff, I'll dig throu my crates and =
play old
    stuff...

    But if it's new and fresh and sleazy and funky...

    www.streetwisemusic.co.uk

    or www.dropshop.com

    or www.dmswax.com

    Of course these will have that "jungle on 33"  sound too, it IS =
popular, but
    if you are a sample digger like me, you can find PLENTY of funked =
out shit.=20
    It's all in how patient you are. I listen to HUNDREDS of samples =
when I'm
    record shopping, so I find a ton of stuff...

and gemm
    when looking for funky breaks nowdays.  Where is this plethora of =

    sites like beatport as well as a number of online stores, finding =
funky
    breaks is a task, then finding something that is quality and that I =
like is
    even harder!



      On 4/5/06, Marc(O) < electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
        Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky =
breaks to be
    found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), =
so many
    people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle =
on 33".=20
    It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, but =
for some
    reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream.

        To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to =
*personally*=20
    play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' =
- but
    it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the =
one guy
    that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of =
breakbeat=20
    clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's =
charts.

support=20
          from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever =
forget
          that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the =
dance
          community.

          i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about =
breaks, but=20
          i do understand why he would.

> > be
> > found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so
> > many
> > people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle on
> > 33".
> > It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, but for
> > some
> > reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream.
> >
> >     To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to
> > *personally*
> > play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' -
> > but
> > it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the on=
e
> > guy
> > that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of breakbeat
> > clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's charts.

On Mon, Apr 03, 2006 at 06:27:30PM -0700, CHUCK G wrote:
> The story of Mr. A:
>   =20
>   >>
>   =20
>   http://www.guardian.co.uk/drugs/Story/0,,1746333,00.html?gusrc=3Drss
>   =20
>   >>
>   =20
>   The strange case of the man who took 40,000 ecstasy pills in nine years=
=20
>=20
> ? Usage increased to 25 tablets a day at peak
> ? Memory problems and paranoia may be lasting=20
>=20
> David McCandless
> Tuesday April 4, 2006
> The Guardian=20
>=20
>   Doctors from London University have revealed details of what they belie=
ve is the largest amount of ecstasy ever consumed by a single person. Consu=
ltants from the addiction centre at St George's Medical School, London, hav=
e published a case report of a British man estimated to have taken around 4=
0,000 pills of MDMA, the active ingredient in ecstasy, over nine years. The=
 heaviest previous lifetime intake on record is 2,000 pills.   Though the m=
an, who is now 37, stopped taking the drug seven years ago, he still suffer=
s from severe physical and mental health side-effects, including extreme me=
mory problems, paranoia, hallucinations and depression. He also suffers fro=
m painful muscle rigidity around his neck and jaw which often prevents him =
=66rom opening his mouth. The doctors believe many of these symptoms may be=
 permanent.   The man, known as Mr A in the report in the scientific journa=
l Psychosomatics, started using ecstasy at 21. For the first two years his =
use was an
>  average of five pills per weekend. Gradually this escalated until he was=
 taking around three and a half pills a day. At the peak, the man was takin=
g an estimated 25 pills every day for four years. After several severe coll=
apses at parties, Mr A decided to stop taking ecstasy. For several months, =
he still felt he was under the influence of the drug, despite being bedridd=
en.   Hallucinations   His condition deteriorated and he began to experienc=
e recurrent tunnel vision and other problems including hallucinations, para=
noia and muscle rigidity. "He came to us after deciding that he couldn't go=
 on any more," said Dr Christos Kouimtsidis, the consultant psychiatrist at=
 St George's Medical School in Tooting who treated him for five months. "He=
 was having trouble functioning in everyday life."   The doctors discovered=
 that the man was suffering from severe short-term memory problems of a typ=
e usually only seen in lifetime alcoholics. But evaluating the full extent =
of his
>  condition was difficult as his concentration and attention was so impair=
ed he was unable to follow the simple tasks involved in the test.   "This w=
as an exceptional case. His long- term memory was fine but he could not rem=
ember day to day things - the time, the day, what was in his supermarket tr=
olley," said Dr Kouimtsidis. "More worryingly, he did not seem aware himsel=
f that he had these memory problems."   With no mental illness in his famil=
y and no prior psychiatric history, the doctors concluded that his unique c=
ondition was direct result of his intense ecstasy use.   "This is obviously=
 an extreme case so we should not blow any observations out of proportion,"=
 says Dr Kouimtsidis. "But if this is what is happening to very heavy users=
, it might be an indication that daily use of ecstasy over a long period of=
 time can lead to irreversible memory problems and other cognitive deficits=
=2E"   For 10 years, MDMA has been suspected of causing these kinds of effe=
cts in heavy
>  users. It is thought to be due to its disruption of the regulation of se=
rotonin, a brain chemical believed to play a role in mood and memory. It re=
mains unclear whether these effects are the result of permanent neurotoxic =
damage or just temporary reversible alterations in the brain.   A study tod=
ay in a special MDMA issue of the British Journal of Psychopharmacology, su=
ggests long-term side-effects may be temporary. The researchers from the Un=
iversity Of Louisiana could find no significant relationship between depres=
sion and recreational ecstasy use.   In the case of Mr A, a structural MRI =
brain scan failed to show any obvious damage or atrophy in his brain. Howev=
er, these results, says Dr Kouimtsidis, are difficult to interpret. "A scan=
 of this type is not sensitive enough," he said.   Such limitations in brai=
n scanning technology, along with ethical and legal barriers to giving MDMA=
 to human test subjects, have limited direct observation of the drug's effe=
cts in humans.=20
>   Instead, scientists have had to use recreational drug users as subjects=
 in their studies. Conclusions from this are often flawed because few, if a=
ny, drugs users use ecstasy in isolation.   Cannabis user   Mr A was also a=
 heavy cannabis user, and when he was encouraged to decrease his use, his p=
aranoia and hallucinations disappeared and his anxiety abated. But his memo=
ry and concentration problems remained, leading the doctors to suspect that=
 these may be permanent disabilities.   When he was admitted to a specialis=
t brain injury unit and put on anti-psychotic medication, he did start to s=
how some improvement. "Unfortunately, he discharged himself before we were =
able to complete the assessment," says Dr Kouimtsidis. "We continued to sup=
port him. But he started to use cannabis again and he dropped out. We tried=
 to re-engage him but we lost him about a year ago."   The Guardian made se=
veral attempts to find the man without success.   Effects of ecstasy   MDMA=
 is one the
>  most intensely studied recreational drugs in history. But despite thousa=
nds of research papers and studies, scientific evidence on the side-effects=
 remains inconclusive.   Death by overdose   Undoubtedly, large amounts of =
ecstasy can lead to over-heating which in turn, in rare cases, can trigger =
fatal heat stroke. Many factors contribute: number and strength of pills ta=
ken, environment, alcohol-consumption, body weight - but women seem more at=
 risk. The bulk of ecstasy-related deaths around the world have been young =
women.   Water-poisoning   Panicking users, fearing they are overdosing, dr=
ink too much water and provoke hyponaetraemia (water-poisoning). Leah Betts=
 died after drinking 14 pints in just 90 minutes. The recommended amount of=
 water to drink per hour is one pint.   Toxic reactions   Much of the repor=
ts of toxic reactions are muddled with overdose or water-poisoning deaths. =
There is no clear evidence that some people suffer allergic reactions to ec=
stasy. However,
>  around 10% of Western users do lack a key liver enzyme CYP2D6 needed to =
break down MDMA. This may make them more sensitive to the effects and more =
prone to accidental overdose.   Depression   Many weekend users report a mi=
d-week mood dip. This is suspected to be related MDMA's effect on serotonin=
, but hard evidence is lacking. In heavy users, dips can turn to crashes an=
d depression. However studies suggest this effect reverses after a 2-3 mont=
h abstinence.   Positive effects   Users still claim "long lasting improvem=
ents in self-awareness, self-esteem, openness and insight into personal pro=
blems", reports the study from the University Of Louisiana. In the US, rese=
arch continues into the use of MDMA-assisted psychotherapy to treat Post Tr=
aumatic Stress Disorder.

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Apr 2006 21:35:31.0355 (UTC) FILETIME=[DD3D3EB0:01C658F8]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno

Great commentary - in and out of the breaks scene.  I agree with Jeno.. it 
really is popularized with the BM crowd.. although it is growing for sure.  
Everyoone I know is saturated in breaks and gets tired of it for a short 
time, then they're back on it like white on rice!  I know why.. but I can't 
say.. cuz you have to be out there to feel it.  There is a flavor of breaks 
that can't be corrupted because it is rooted in a very unique experience, 
only played at BM - Dessert Breaks!  There something about competing 30,000 
watt sound systems, and furry party busses let loose on the open playa that 
just grounds you into the freak you are for being there in the first place.  
Bass echoing through your sole and vibrating beneath your feet.. beautiful 
stuff.  People live for that kind of experience.  DJ's produce their playa 
sets all year long, and year over year, and rarely ever play those tracks in 
clubs. The rest of the the breaks community seems to just occupy space and 
time untill they can get back to where it is reborn for yet another year.  
Just my opinion, but there is a reason Jeno said what he did.. and it is 
centered in the BM experience.



SFR: Ranger
San Francisco
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see





From: "Marc(O)" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
CC: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>,"Apollo" 
<apollo@speakeasy.org>,<SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno
Date: Wed, 5 Apr 2006 14:01:23 -0700

AHA!!!!

www.groovedis.com

It's FK5's distributor, and you can buy direct (and HELLA cheaper I might 
add). They have a TON of that funky sound....FK5, Allgood Funk Alliance, Dr. 
Rubberfunk, Citrona Records, Ursula 1000, etc.

I got like 15 records for under $90 there...just over $100 w/ shipping I 
think.

They don't have a ton of smaples, but they do have some, and other sites can 
provide the rest. ( I always keep a few diff. sites open to listen to 
samples when I'm shopping).

I highly suggest checking out that site if that's what you're looking 
for...and if you contact their online customer service, ask for Randall Van 
Kirk - he's SUPER helpful!!!

Happy shopping!
   ----- Original Message -----
   From: Ben Haus
   To: Marc(O)

   Mmm... any specific labels/producers?  You are giving me sites with

Knox Label.  Len Lewis' Label NuPoodle Breaks was putting out some more 
tribally and tech house influenced breaks for a short period... but looks 
like they went bust with that sublabel.

     Depends on if you mean "funky breaks that sound just like that old 
skool
     stuff", or "funky ass breaks PERIOD". lol

     Cuz honestly, I don't play TOO much stuff that sounds like recycled '95
     beats. If I wanna play the old stuff, I'll dig throu my crates and play 
old
     stuff...

     But if it's new and fresh and sleazy and funky...

     www.streetwisemusic.co.uk

     or www.dropshop.com

     or www.dmswax.com

     Of course these will have that "jungle on 33"  sound too, it IS 
popular, but
     if you are a sample digger like me, you can find PLENTY of funked out 
shit.
     It's all in how patient you are. I listen to HUNDREDS of samples when 
I'm
     record shopping, so I find a ton of stuff...

       James Brown is Dead!


       On a serious tip....  I find myself ordering through vinyldj.com and 
gemm
     when looking for funky breaks nowdays.  Where is this plethora of funky
     breaks you speak of being put out in 2006?  I scour high and low on mp3
     sites like beatport as well as a number of online stores, finding funky
     breaks is a task, then finding something that is quality and that I 
like is
     even harder!



       On 4/5/06, Marc(O) < electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
         Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit. There are PLENTY of funky breaks 
to be
     found. Problem is (and this is no diss on the local breaks scene), so 
many
     people play that crappy UK bassline breaks sound. I call it "jungle on 
33".
     It was played out about 10 minutes after it came on the scene, but for 
some
     reason, people around here eat that shit up like ice cream.

         To me, breakbeat is a party rockin' genre - and I tend to 
*personally*
     play more party rockin' beats. Some of it is slammed out and bangin' - 
but
     it's still all very funky and danceable. But hey - I'd rather be the 
one guy
     that sticks with that vibe/style then be swimming in a sea of breakbeat
     clones, all playing the same top ten releases from this week's charts.
         ----- Original Message -----
         From: Ben Haus
         To: Marc(O)
         Cc: Bam ; Apollo ; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
         Sent: Wednesday, April 05, 2006 1:00 PM
         Subject: Re: [sfraves] An Evening with Jeno

Apollo's
     interpretation that breaks really doesn't have the amount of soul it 
used
     to....  I love me some funky breaks and there's definitely a lack of 
them in
     the past couple of years!  Looking forward to the 14th so I can get my
     double dose of funky breaks with Jim Hopkins again
         !

           well, i'll be the first to admit that i would like to see more
           diversity in this scene.  and i mean diversity of all kinds.

           age, self expression, race, culture, sexuality.

           i don't like elitism and as much as Evil Breaks has gained 
support
           from the Burningman community (and we love it!)...i won't ever 
forget
           that i'm a raver and i have friends from all segments of the 
dance
           community.

           i guess i'm kinda surprised that Jeno would say that about 
breaks, but
           i do understand why he would.

At 01:22 PM 4/5/2006, Chris Jackson wrote:
>Jeno - Energy
>
>Look it up.  VERY hard to find mixtape from 1990.  My favorite mixtape of
>ALL time.  A perfect representation of what Apollo is talking about and what
>I believe Jeno was pointing out.  You don't happen to have this mix do you
>Apollo??  If you do, or if anybody else does for that matter...PLEASE upload
>it!!!!  

Actually I don't remember although I know the tape.  I have boxes of mixtapes from those days and one of my more immediate projects is to dig through them and pull out the irreplaceable stuff, then import and transfer it all to CDs.  Cassette tape deteriorates over time.  There are even some ancient sets I played at the End Up in there. :-)

So Chris, if I come across Energy or other Jeno tapes I'll let you know.

Love,

Apollo



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

        b=rJkpsu9KVNZ26WIdqW7r5xUyvrN+gCfhaQsPoqsZ6+DLADTrlSPprHJukzpM0LhUZ2VIbhyV8QN7ungSrh3twPJVkqQGH8xrA93T4LAFgKGyI3hr9QdzsVh4eMOXpCh1XRqAaSXnrbibtXvRJkM+vLRho02JRUTK5gT1Bxv45bs=

	boundary="----=_Part_6614_2654803.1144349253140"

Subject: [sfraves] Bush Authorized Leak to Times, Libby Told Grand Jury

------=_Part_6614_2654803.1144349253140
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I saw this about an hour ago on GNN, now CBS5.com, I wonder if anything wil=
l
become of it...

By JOSH GERSTEIN - Staff Reporter of the New York Sun
April 6, 2006 *updated 9:02 am EDT*

A former White House aide under indictment for obstructing a leak probe, I.
Lewis Libby, testified to a grand jury that he gave information from a
closely-guarded "National Intelligence Estimate" on Iraq to a New York Time=
s
reporter in 2003 with the specific permission of President Bush, according
to a new court filing from the special prosecutor in the case.

The court papers from the prosecutor, Patrick Fitzgerald, do not suggest
that Mr. Bush violated any law or rule. However, the new disclosure could b=
e
awkward for the president because it places him, for the first time,
directly in a chain of events that led to a meeting where prosecutors
contend the identity of a CIA employee, Valerie Plame, was provided to a
reporter.

Mr. Fitzgerald's inquiry initially focused on the alleged leak, which
occurred after a former ambassador who is Ms. Plame's husband, Joseph
Wilson, wrote an op-ed piece in the New York Times questioning the accuracy
of statements Mr. Bush made about Iraq's nuclear procurement efforts in
Africa.

No criminal charges have been brought for the leak itself, but Mr. Libby, a
former chief of staff to Vice President Cheney, was indicted in October on
charges that he obstructed the investigation, perjured himself in front of
the grand jury, and lied to FBI agents who interviewed him. Mr. Libby, who
resigned from the White House and pleaded not guilty, is scheduled to go on
trial in January 2007.

In a court filing late Wednesday responding to requests from Mr. Libby's
attorneys for government records that might aid his defense, Mr. Fitzgerald
shed new light on Mr. Libby's claims that he was authorized to provide
sensitive information to the Times reporter, Judith Miller, at a meeting on
July 8, 2003.

"Defendant testified that he was specifically authorized in advance of the
meeting to disclose the key judgments of the classified NIE to Miller on
that occasion because it was thought that the NIE was =D4pretty definitive'
against what Ambassador Wilson had said and that the vice president thought
that it was =D4very important' for the key judgments of the NIE to come out=
,"
Mr. Fitzgerald wrote.

Mr. Libby is said to have testified that "at first" he rebuffed Mr. Cheney'=
s
suggestion to release the information because the estimate was classified.
However, according to the vice presidential aide, Mr. Cheney subsequently
said he got permission for the release directly from Mr. Bush. "Defendant
testified that the vice president later advised him that the president had
authorized defendant to disclose the relevant portions of the NIE," the
prosecution filing said.

Mr. Libby told the grand jury that he also sought the advice of the legal
counsel to the vice president, David Addington, who indicated that Mr.
Bush's permission to disclose the estimate "amounted to a declassification
of the document," according to the new court papers.

One of the facts Mr. Libby said he planned to disclose to Ms. Miller was
that the estimate, produced in October 2002, concluded that Iraq was
"vigorously trying to procure uranium." This contention was sharply at odds
with Mr. Wilson's op-ed piece which argued there was no evidence of such a
procurement effort, at least on a trip he took to Africa at the CIA's
request.

Mr. Bush's alleged instruction to release the conclusions of the
intelligence estimate appears to have been squarely within his authority an=
d
Mr. Fitzgerald makes no argument that it was illegal. While Mr. Libby said
he gave that information "exclusively" to the Times reporter at their
breakfast meeting at the St. Regis Hotel in Washington, many of the finding=
s
of the estimate were formally declassified and discussed at a White House
press briefing ten days later, on July 18, 2003.

The court papers filed by Mr. Fitzgerald do not make clear whether Mr. Bush
knew the disclosure was destined for Ms. Miller, though they indicate Mr.
Cheney knew that fact. Mr. Libby is also said to have testified that five
days late Mr. Cheney authorized the release to the press of information
about a cable about Mr. Wilson's strip.

Messrs. Bush and Cheney have been interviewed by Mr. Fitzgerald and his
staff, but it is not known how their accounts of the events compared to tha=
t
of Mr. Libby.

In an interview with Fox News in February, Mr. Cheney, who has a reputation
for secrecy, acknowledged that he has sometimes pressed for the official
release of classified records.

"I've certainly advocated declassification and participated in
declassification decisions," he said.

Asked if he had ever "unilaterally" declassified material, Mr. Cheney
replied, "I don't want to get into that. There is an executive order that
specifies who has classification authority, and obviously focuses first and
foremost on the president, but also includes the vice president."

While prosecutors initially said Mr. Libby was the first government officia=
l
to disclose Ms. Plame's identity, it subsequently emerged that a Washington
Post reporter, Bob Woodward, learned earlier about her CIA employment from
another government official. Neither Mr. Woodward nor Ms. Miller wrote abou=
t
Ms. Plame at the time. Another journalist, Robert Novak, first disclosed th=
e
employment of Mr. Wilson's wife in a syndicated column released on July 14,
2003. The columnist based his story on interviews with Mr. Bush's top
political adviser, Karl Rove, and another official who has not been
officially identified.

Prosecutors argued that Mr. Libby covered up his role in the disclosures
because "he knew the White House had publicly staked its credibility on
there being no White House involvement in the leaking of information about
Ms. Wilson." They also noted that Mr. Bush publicly declared he would fire
anyone found to have leaked classified information.

The new court filing quotes from handwritten suggestions Mr. Libby gave to
the White House press secretary, Scott McClellan, urging the spokesman to
proclaim the vice presidential aide's innocence with the same vigor that th=
e
press secretary previously denounced as "ridiculous" suggestions that Mr.
Rove might have had a hand in leaking Ms. Plame's identity.

Mr. Libby's note, as typed up by the prosecution, reads like a stanza of
verse:

"People have made too much of the difference in
How I described Karl and Libby
I've talked to Libby.
I said it was ridiculous about Karl
And it is ridiculous about Libby.
Libby was not the source of the Novak story.
And he did not leak classified information."

Mr. McClellan did not adopt the talking points verbatim, but did tell
reporters later that Messrs. Rove and Libby "assured me that they were not
involved in this."

Mr. Rove has not been charged with a crime, but remains under investigation
by Mr. Fitzgerald's office.

Subject: [sfraves] The Morning Paper



             the morning paper               


It's easy to remember.  Its better to forget.
We're fucked but to recount these days and the hell we ain’t seen yet.

I rise up through the morning fog, try to beat the dawn
The whole world sleeps in cozy beds while I get my own shit on.

If I didn’t have to take these pills, I’d still be home in bed
One-a-these days in the morning paper they’re gonna find me dead.

Well it might be a pissed-off confidence man; it might be my own luck		
Or it might be my decision to just stay where I’ve been stuck


  
I stopped breathing on the day you left and I haven’t dared breathe since
It’s hard to find enlightenment if you don’t know what it is  

I’ll fit better in the morning papers than I ever fit in your head
I felt for you at the break of dawn, found emptiness instead

I sit still with my morning cup,    watch the colors rise
The silence of her ghost in here, the shadow in her eyes

Her cunt is like a flower, I don’t know what it’s for
The less I understand it, the more I want it more.




(c) 2006 boomfidget











---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> Hey everybody just thought I would pass on to you that on 
> www.movementnow.com
> we have started a new page (A featured artist page!) to help keep things 
> fresh and showcase
> people from around the country who are helping make things happen. We will 
> be updating
> it every month with a new artist, along with their bio and a tasty mix 
> set. Yes that's right
> more free music! I think we all know that we can't have enough of that.
>
> So without further ado our first featured artist:
>
> ..::April::..
> <<DJ Brian>>
> aka Brian Seed (Moontribe, Ritual Sounds, Ball of Wax)
>
> www.moontribe.org
> www.ritualsounds.com
> www.ballofwax.com
>
> This month's artist is someone very special to all of us outdoor partiers. 
> He's been
> trailblazing new sounds from his amazing mix's on Moonshine's "Hard Desert 
> Trance"
> series in the late 90's, to his completely unbelievable live sets at 
> events like Moontribe. Lately
> he's immersed himself in the studio working with the likes of John Kelley, 
> Amani vs. Teapot and
> our very own Phokus on his label Ritual Sounds. It was our pleasure to 
> showcase this
> wonderful DJ at Nowloween and we are glad to be in his presence again.
>
> Please check him out @ www.movementnow.com and download or stream his mix.
>
> Also feel free to check out our other artist's and download all of the 
> sets in our mixes section.
>
> Thanks for your time and enjoy,
>
> P

From: boomerang <petersandifer@sbcglobal.net>

Subject: [sfraves] Brand New Day


I started this one in 1997,  and just finished.  I think Andy used to be in it, but i lost a lot
of my notes in the fire.   But now it's got a real slowww house beat and orchestral strings.




U – N – D 
   E – R – G         
      R – O –U – N – D 
   
Michael’s got a tank & some 2-CB
Crack it open, baby, to see who we be.

This party’s jumpin off, kickin full throttle
Yo Jackson, pass the paper bag that holds the bottle
The chill room crew took the good champagne 
--- “Summon the butler for more cocaine!”
 
Keyed-up kids gonna have a heart attack
E’d up kids talking disco-smack
---“Boomerang!  Stop talking!”
---“Just slip another fifty in the stripper’s top stocking!”

Get off the wall, before the night’s a loss
Put your ass in the air like a Muslim in a mosque
“A’salaam aleikum,” and “Hum'di’allah”
When Armageddon comes,  baby:   God help us all.


   Guns at our heads, but we won’t be taken
   Sun comes up on a brand new day
   Golden clouds on the eastern horizon
   Sun comes up on a brand new day



Fartin’ around, scarin’ the cat,
Punch the 808.  Roll the DAT
Rollin like that, with your eyes rolled back
Trying to cut tracks on a midnight snack

We  get no rest til we’re back in the box
Black coffee, cigarettes and Jack on the rocks
Don’t be ringin on the phone,  ain’t nobody home
This headphone is a helmet when you’re deep in the zone

  
The musical organization of data cum religion
Program a pattern, kick back and just listen:
Make the sound final,  squash it down to vinyl 
Then Aaron swoop it up and it’s straight to your spinal

The fury of infinity made my senses bloom
First I fought it,  then I found I was finally finely tuned
But nothing we can see will ever satisfy:
Leave your record player spinning on the day you die


   Guns at our heads, but we won’t be taken
   Sun comes up on a brand new day
   Golden clouds on the eastern horizon
   Sun comes up on a brand new day





(c) me.  1997 - 2006


















---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> stocking!”

> Get off the wall, before the night’s a loss
> Put your ass in the air like a Muslim in a mosque
> “A’salaam aleikum,” and “Hum'di’allah”
> When Armageddon comes,  baby:   God help us all.
> 
> 
>    Guns at our heads, but we won’t be taken
>    Sun comes up on a brand new day
>    Golden clouds on the eastern horizon
>    Sun comes up on a brand new day
> 
> 
> 
> Fartin’ around, scarin’ the cat,
> Punch the 808.  Roll the DAT
> Rollin like that, with your eyes rolled back
> Trying to cut tracks on a midnight snack
> 
> We  get no rest til we’re back in the box
> Black coffee, cigarettes and Jack on the rocks
> Don’t be ringin on the phone,  ain’t nobody home
> This headphone is a helmet when you’re deep in the
> zone
> 
>   
> The musical organization of data cum religion
> Program a pattern, kick back and just listen:
> Make the sound final,  squash it down to vinyl 
> Then Aaron swoop it up and it’s straight to your
> spinal
> 
> The fury of infinity made my senses bloom
> First I fought it,  then I found I was finally
> finely tuned
> But nothing we can see will ever satisfy:
> Leave your record player spinning on the day you die
> 
> 
>    Guns at our heads, but we won’t be taken
>    Sun comes up on a brand new day
>    Golden clouds on the eastern horizon
>    Sun comes up on a brand new day
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> (c) me.  1997 - 2006

--- Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com> wrote:

> This has the same meter as an NWA track....
> "Dopeman"... I think...
> 
> E



hmmm... i wouldn't be surprised, Eric.  Straight Outta Compton was my second rap tape (Somehow,
"Eazy Duz It" was the first.)

I used to carry "Compton" around with me when I was a valet parker, jamming & ejecting it outta
every Oldsmobile / Reliant K / Cadillac tape deck I parked, hearing the tape in 2 minute snatches.

Until the day I couldn't get the tape out of a Porshce, 'cause the tape spools were so off their
orbits the tape wouldn't eject.

i always wondered what happened when those rich old fucks got their sportscar back to hear "...a
young nigga on the warpath!!!  and when I'm finished, there's gonna be a bloodbath!!!"


Oh yeah, by the way Eric, it's been almost seven years since Oakland's had 10,000 heads under one
roof, gangstas hugging candy kids and fucked up shit like that. 

Do come back.

peter

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

Well I had an interesting surprise last night ... I got home, cooked  
myself some dinner, cleaned up, and decided I was going for a walk.   
So I walked and walked and I came upon a local bookstore that's been  
open for about a year.  And on a sign outside the door was written in  
chalk "meet Clay Jenkinson".  Well, I'd be surprised if anyone on the  
list knew who Clay Jenkinson is, but he is well versed in the life of  
Thomas Jefferson and has a radio show called The Thomas Jefferson  
Hour, where he assumes the personna of our nation's second  
President.  I thought, what an interesting coincidence, because I was  
just listening to him on the radio the day before.

So I walked into the bookstore and he was doing a book signing and a  
short speak.  I caught the end of the discussion where he was  
starting to talk about the next personna he wants to assume, and that  
is Theodore Roosevelt.  And he told a great story about the time that  
Theodore was out in North Dakota on a boat, and someone stole his  
boat, he built another boat, caught up with the boat thieves, and  
marched them back to the authorities.

So anyway, now I have a signed copy of Becoming Jefferson's People:   
Re-Inventing the American Republic in the Twenty-first Century.  So I  
dedicate today's quote to one from the book I just bought.

--

Jefferson's unstated motto was that there is nothing magical in the  
way things are.  He believed that he stood at the dawn of a new era  
in which every institution, every habit, every system, every cultural  
code, every belief, and every received truth would be examined  
according to the dictates of reason and good sense, and its capacity  
to promote human dignity and happiness.

- Clay S. Jenkinson

hmmm... i wouldn't be surprised, Eric.  Straight Outta Compton was my second rap tape (Somehow,
"Eazy Duz It" was the first.)

I used to carry "Compton" around with me when I was a valet parker, jamming & ejecting it outta
every Oldsmobile / Reliant K / Cadillac tape deck I parked, hearing the tape in 2 minute snatches.

Until the day I couldn't get the tape out of a Porshce, 'cause the tape spools were so off their
orbits the tape wouldn't eject.

i always wondered what happened when those rich old fucks got their sportscar back to hear "...a
young nigga on the warpath!!!  and when I'm finished, there's gonna be a bloodbath!!!"


Oh yeah, by the way Eric, it's been almost seven years since Oakland's had 10,000 heads under one
roof, gangstas hugging candy kids and fucked up shit like that. 

Do come back.

peter

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

SFRAVES BDAY BASH and BENEFIT

Thursday, May 14, 2006

Gather with Love all as One, to celebrates on the decks and dancefloor, 
dancing evermore, a tribute towards the birth and life of SFRaves, for 
the past 14 years, now and to the future ...

SFRaves 14th BDAY ANNIVERSARY BASH

SFRaves Calendar 11th CELEBRATION

An epic tale of the history, present and future of SFRaves ...
A gift to and from the community..

Connect and dance, Beat Thumping
Feet jumping
Music pumping a heart beat
of the harmonic sonic treat
Bass thumping for years to come
Bumping Bass to meet and move us and then some.

Proceeds to be gifted to benefit a non-profit organization.

<3 xxoxooxo <3

Karina

SPECIAL NOTICE:

Interested in working on helping to fix the SFRaves Calendar? Do you 
know someone who is interested in becoming involved with the next 
generation of the SFRaves Calendar Project?

If you would like an event posted to the Calendar, please email me in 
the interim @ karina@hyperreal.org and I will make sure it is added to 
the Weekly Calendar Mailing.

The SFRaves Calendar is located @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

More information about Zope is located here: http://www.zope.org All 
interested parties should have a solid understanding of and development 
experience with authoring and building applications using the Zope 
application framework, ZPT, Python, PHP, MYSQL. Plone and other 
languages that might be used to enhance the SFR Calendar Application.

Please note if you are seeing issues with the current calendar 
incarnation (bugs, errors, etc) please note that I am aware of them and 
am currently in the process of addressing / fixing these issues.

Please send responses to karina@hyperreal.org

Alternative solutions are also being considered for the next generation 
of this codebase. This includes other languages specific to the 
development of applications in a web environment.

--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Friday, April 07, 2006 * FULL MELT *

  FULL MELT FRIDAY APRIL 7th 10 PM - 6 AM *All Ages $15 - Free before 
10:30 Prepare for complete meltdown as we present you with an all star 
line-up that includes BAOBINGA, direct from Manchester England! 
Producer and DJ extrodinaire, Baobinga's production style is a genre 
mashing dancefloor treat, mixing PHAT warped basslines, tear-out 
breakbeats & over-the-top digital trickery. BAOBINGA (Cyberfunk 
Records, Fusetrax, Vertical Sound, Plastic Raygun - UK) Additional 
beat-slingers for the evening: Atomikdog (369 Rekchordz) - Live 
Hardware Set DJ Ripple (BreaksFM, Subscience) Aaron Jae (XM Radio, Evil 
Breaks, SFBreaks.org) Hypnotech (Addictech.com) Soulsalaam (Hypnomadic) 
Satsi (Lush) - Live VJ / DJ set Mr. Rogers (Ooze System) Maebyn La Fey 
(Subscience) Kirill (Subscience) M.O.D. (Evil Breaks) Bertzerker 
(Ataraxia) Lud Dub (Pulse Radio) $15 - Free before 10:30 Friendly 
security by B&B. Projections by Satsi and Nuclear Dreamer. Lights by 
Eye & Eye. Extreme sound by Foundation. (Frost has added 15,000 more 
watts, this is the 1st time all of it will be in use - prepare for a 
Full Meltdown!) All this takes place at a new, virgin San Francisco 
venue. *Info line: 415-820-1625 (Call week of event) www.subscience.org 
- The Science of BASS

issue: Scene Gossip Crossword Puzzle! The Newsbreakz Guide to DJing 
Cracked Out! Kraddy's Guide to PORN! Snow vs MIA! And much, much MORE!

X , Happy-Star , Kid Krave And Spectra. This event will take place in a 
brand new ranch location complete with 160 free camp sites,clean 
bathrooms, friendly security. Located 45 min from LA. Ff you plan on 
camping arrive early. Infoline 323.404.5675

Monday, April 17, 2006 * GMHC 30th Anniversary Celebration!!! *

Date & Time:  Monday, April 17, 2006 more on this date 6:30 PM GAY 
MEN’S HEALTH COLLECTIVE of the Berkeley Free Clinic 30TH ANNIVERSARY 
CELEBRATION Monday, April 17, 2006 The oldest clinic in the nation 
devoted to gay men’s health, the GMHC is a volunteer-run free clinic 
providing non-judgmental, sex-positive, and free STD screening, 
diagnosis and treatment to men of all sexual orientations. 
www.gmhc30.org FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE February 25, 2006 Celebrating 30 
years of service to the Bay Area and beyond, the Gay Men's Health 
Collective (GMHC) of the Berkeley Free Clinic is hosting the gala event 
of the year, Exposure!, on Monday April 17, 2006 at 8:00PM. Hosted by 
the Bay Area's very own Juanita More, the night will feature burlesque, 
drag and hip-hop performers, a fashion show, and live music. Local wine 
and champagne will be poured before and after the live show which will 
take place on the Roda Stage at 2025 Addison Street (Berkeley Repertory 
Theater) in Berkeley. Founded in 1976 in response to blatant homophobia 
among the healthcare establishment, the GMHC consists of dedicated lay 
and professional healthcare volunteers who have been trained to screen 
men for the most common sexually transmitted infections, diagnose and 
treat those infections, and most importantly to educate men about 
sexual health. Volunteers identify as gay, bi, or queer. The drop-in 
clinic accepts new clients, regardless of sexual orientation, on Sunday 
evenings. Tickets range from $25-$150; $50-and-up tickets include a 
chocolate tasting and wine mixer in the Berkeley Repertory Theater's 
courtyard beginning at 6:30pm. Immediately following the show, 
champagne and cake will be served under the Berkeley sky. For more 
details or to purchase tickets online, go to the GMHC's 30th 
Anniversary Celebration website at www.gmhc30.org. The funds raised 
from the event will benefit the Berkeley Free Clinic. The event is 
wheelchair accessible. Please visit our websites: Event – 
www.gmhc30.org Clinic – www.berkeleyfreeclinic.org See you there! WHEN 
Monday, April 17, 2006 WHERE Roda Stage @ 2025 Addison Street (Berkeley 
Repertory Theater) Berkeley, CA 94704 TICKETS $25 and up For more 
information please contact us at: (415) 596-9736 gmhcbfc@gmail.com 
www.GMHC30.org

------------------------------------------------- 
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week. To subscribe to the
list, send a message to: sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please publish them by
Friday @ Noon to be included in the SFR Calendar Weekly Edition Mailing.

SFRaves is a not for profit entity serving the Bay Area & all forms of
electronic music for 14 years.

Gather with Love --

All as One, 
to celebrates on the decks and dancefloor, 
dancing evermore, 
a tribute towards the birth and life of SFRaves, 
for the past 14 years, now and to the future ...

** SFRaves 14th BDAY ANNIVERSARY BASH ** 
** SFRaves Calendar 11th ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION ** A Benefit --

An epic gift of the history, present and future of SFRaves ...
A gift to and from the community..

Connect and dance, Beat Thumping
Feet jumping
Music pumping a heart beat
of the harmonic sonic treat
Bass thumping for years to come
Bumping Bass to meet and move us and then some.

SPECIAL NOTICE:

Interested in working on helping to fix the SFRaves Calendar? Do you 
know someone who is interested in becoming involved with the next 
generation of the SFRaves Calendar Project?

If you would like an event posted to the Calendar, please email me in 
the interim @ karina@hyperreal.org and I will make sure it is added to 
the Weekly Calendar Mailing.

The SFRaves Calendar is located @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

More information about Zope is located here: http://www.zope.org All 
interested parties should have a solid understanding of and development 
experience with authoring and building applications using the Zope 
application framework, ZPT, Python, PHP, MYSQL. Plone and other 
languages that might be used to enhance the SFR Calendar Application.

Please note if you are seeing issues with the current calendar 
incarnation (bugs, errors, etc) please note that I am aware of them and 
am currently in the process of addressing / fixing these issues.

Please send responses to karina@hyperreal.org

Alternative solutions are also being considered for the next generation 
of this codebase. This includes other languages specific to the 
development of applications in a web environment.

--

the bar.... cya on the dancefloor!

Saturday, April 08, 2006 * NU-JIVE *

Date & Time:  Saturday, April 8, 2006 - Sunday, April 9, 2006 9:30 PM 
The scunderground presents: Nu-jive This month we have a very special 
guest: Dj Kiyoshi of KHDC! Listeners to the Chemistry show on KHDC 
90.9FM in Salinas, California will better know Will Kiyoshi DeVoe as 
just KiYoshi. Born in Mountain View, California, KiYoshi was raised in 
New Jersey, San Francisco, LA, San Diego and Santa Cruz. He is now a 
resident of Salinas, California. KiYoshi first got interested in being 
a dj when he was 10 years old, but says "I realised I could not 
recognize a single note". He was inspired by the Sugar Hill Gang's 
'Rapper's Delight' and got his break in the late 80's spinning Hip Hop 
and Electro at various parties. In 1985, KiYoshi started getting 
experience with radio whilst working at a record store in Santa Cruz. 
He started guesting on a radio station at a private school and then 
moved onto a college radio station at UCSC called KZSC 88.1FM. His 
break for "Chemistry" came when he was DJing at UCSC and some people 
from the local public station asked him whether he'd be interested in 
playing over the airwaves. His show on KHDC 90.9FM in Salinas, 
California was entitled "Chemistry" due to the fact that KiYoshi plays 
"all the elements past and present" that make up the music he is into. 
It is a non-commercial bi-lingual radio station and they do the work 
"for the love, not the money". People can pick up the station from 
Monterey to Santa Cruz and "Chemistry" airs on Wednesday nights from 
10pm until midnight. KiYoshi specialises in playing imports, 
underground, independent and up & coming artists as he says, "I 
realised at an early age how hard it is for artists/labels that were 
not on the mainstream thing to get heard". He decided to make it a 
focus of the program and plays all genres from House, Drum & Bass, to 
UK Garage, Broken Beat, Electro and more stating "anything with soul". 
It seems that KiYoshi has found a key to success in there somewhere as 
he has a lot of supporters including Tricksta at Wolftown Recordings, 
Kate at Urban Takeover, Adam at Giant Step, Pure Groove and many more. 
KiYoshi is currently producing his own tracks in the coming year. He 
advises up and coming DJs to "do things for the personal enjoyment of 
music" as he certainly does. You can catch his show on KHDC 90.9FM 
between the hours of 10pm and 12am each and every Wednesday. "Nu-jive" 
will be held at the all new Cardiff Lounge, 529 Seabright Ave., Santa 
Cruz, Cali. Second Saturdays of every month starting this Saturday 
night, April 8th, 2006. Continuing on second Saturdays: , May 13th, 
June 10th, ect. Dj ABC (scunderground) and Kiyoshi will spin a frenzy 
of freakified funk on the floor. So get ready for Broken-beats, bossa 
breaks, soulful/funked up housin', and eclectic afro-electronica. Free 
to all those 21+ who have soul. www.myspace.com/dj_abc 
groups.yahoo.com/group/SCunderground/ scunderground.tribe.net/

Monday, April 17, 2006 * GMHC 30th Anniversary Celebration!!! *

Date & Time:  Monday, April 17, 2006 more on this date 6:30 PM GAY 
MEN’S HEALTH COLLECTIVE of the Berkeley Free Clinic 30TH ANNIVERSARY 
CELEBRATION Monday, April 17, 2006 The oldest clinic in the nation 
devoted to gay men’s health, the GMHC is a volunteer-run free clinic 
providing non-judgmental, sex-positive, and free STD screening, 
diagnosis and treatment to men of all sexual orientations. 
www.gmhc30.org FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE February 25, 2006 Celebrating 30 
years of service to the Bay Area and beyond, the Gay Men's Health 
Collective (GMHC) of the Berkeley Free Clinic is hosting the gala event 
of the year, Exposure!, on Monday April 17, 2006 at 8:00PM. Hosted by 
the Bay Area's very own Juanita More, the night will feature burlesque, 
drag and hip-hop performers, a fashion show, and live music. Local wine 
and champagne will be poured before and after the live show which will 
take place on the Roda Stage at 2025 Addison Street (Berkeley Repertory 
Theater) in Berkeley. Founded in 1976 in response to blatant homophobia 
among the healthcare establishment, the GMHC consists of dedicated lay 
and professional healthcare volunteers who have been trained to screen 
men for the most common sexually transmitted infections, diagnose and 
treat those infections, and most importantly to educate men about 
sexual health. Volunteers identify as gay, bi, or queer. The drop-in 
clinic accepts new clients, regardless of sexual orientation, on Sunday 
evenings. Tickets range from $25-$150; $50-and-up tickets include a 
chocolate tasting and wine mixer in the Berkeley Repertory Theater's 
courtyard beginning at 6:30pm. Immediately following the show, 
champagne and cake will be served under the Berkeley sky. For more 
details or to purchase tickets online, go to the GMHC's 30th 
Anniversary Celebration website at www.gmhc30.org. The funds raised 
from the event will benefit the Berkeley Free Clinic. The event is 
wheelchair accessible. Please visit our websites: Event – 
www.gmhc30.org Clinic – www.berkeleyfreeclinic.org See you there! WHEN 
Monday, April 17, 2006 WHERE Roda Stage @ 2025 Addison Street (Berkeley 
Repertory Theater) Berkeley, CA 94704 TICKETS $25 and up For more 
information please contact us at: (415) 596-9736 gmhcbfc@gmail.com 
www.GMHC30.org

Wednesday, August 02, 2006 * BOOM FESTIVAL Magic *

Date & Time:  Wednesday, August 2, 2006 - Wednesday, August 9, 2006 
4:00 AM Heya, All! We would like to share with you information about a 
very special global arts, music and culture-gathering that incarnates 
biannually in Portugal. Boom Festival takes place in a stunning outdoor 
location on the shore of the Lake Idanha-a-Nova, approximately 2 hours 
North-West from Lisboa. Bringing together the latest in psychedelic 
sights & sounds, phantastic art installations & workshops, this 
week-long event is a harmonic convergence of people, energy, 
information, and philosophies, from planet Earth & beyond. Synchronized 
multi-dimensionally with the full moon of August, the next 
Boom-Festival is taking a bio-dynamic approach by incorporating a 
variety of sustainable techniques, and Earth-based forms throughout its 
infrastructure. Reflecting a harmonic balance of the organic and the 
cyber-technologic, Boom 2006 maps the metaphysical framework in 
accordance with Peace, Love, Unity and Respect. A very magical event 
indeed! 5000 BOOM Festival 2006 Early Bird Tickets are available now. 
They are only 70 Euro for 7 days. Getting there is no big deal. 
Reasonable flights to Lisboa can be purchased on most of the European 
Budget Airlines, and Transatlantic flights from America are also quite 
cheap. The Boom has organized busses that take you directly from the 
international airport to the sacred womb of the vacation party 
paradise. This year, Boom-festival has extended its length to ONE WEEK! 
Great news about the timing of BOOM 2006 is that it's not happening in 
conjunction with Burning Man, so the devoted "Burners" have a chance to 
partake on European creative community expression. BOOM is similar to 
Burning Man, but with a lake & great sounds! Not to be missed ... For 
more info, please visit: www.boomfestival.org

------------------------------------------------- 
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week. To subscribe to the
list, send a message to: sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please publish them by
Friday @ Noon to be included in the SFR Calendar Weekly Edition Mailing.

SFRaves is a not for profit entity serving the Bay Area & all forms of
electronic music for 14 years.

------=_Part_5626_13266733.1144637117628
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

What do you want to do? If you already have a synth all you need is a midi
adaptor and sequencer software. My personal favorite is Sonar 5.

Trying out software by downloading it illegally and then buying the stuff
you think is worth it is the way to go. Yeah, it's probably morally
incorrect, but if you have a concious and buy it at some point you are stil=
l
supporting the developer. I just spent $350 on the Spectrasonic's Atmospher=
e
plug-in. This thing is bad ass. Please don't just go download tons of shit
and never pay for it, that's just wrong.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what are the best studio programs?

------=_Part_5099_17963953.1144644710466
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

If you're just starting out in computer-based electronic music production,
Reason is going to be the most rewarding.  It has a touch and click
interface and good integration with inexpensive MIDI/USB devices like the
M-Audio keyboards. If you want something more advanced, go for the ProTools
MBox (*cough*  *awkward silence as Cochrane misses his cue*).  A lot of
folks seem to be gravitating towards Live 5 these days; some people find th=
e
interface inuitive, others do not.  There's also Logic Pro from Apple to
consider, which has a more "compositional" or "orchestra" feel to it; steep
learning cuve, but very rewarding once you master it.

As for the hardware component, I've had success with the M-Audio USB and
Firewire interfaces; they're inexpensive and sound decent, at least with th=
e
marginal speakers I was using them with at the time.  Speakerwise, Event
makes some nice sounding stuff that's pretty affordable, and if money is no
object, there's always the Mackie HR824.

I agree that there's not one program for everyone; it depends on your
creative process and budget and how you think about music.  Definitely,
check out a number of them, and find which one is right for you.  You don't
even have to break IP "law"; most companies provide demo versions for just
such purposes.

My experience was that the cost of software was neglible compared to the
investment in time and energy required to make something of real quality.
Computer-based music production has made making mediocre music easier, whic=
h
is no small accomplishment, but ultimately, a great musician (*pointed look
@ GC. and MK-S*) can make good music with nearly anything, just like a grea=
t
programmer can write code with nothing but vi.  I think a lot of learning
electronic music is similar in fashion to the method in which the Australia=
n
aboriginal peoples used to teach the didjeridoo; send the student out into
the wilderness with instructions to come back when he has learned how to
play it properly.



On 4/9/06, Steve Osteen <sosteen@gmail.com> wrote:

I went to see these guys in concert this weekend in Dirty Jersey.  I  
don't know, btw if that term refers to the entire state or a specific  
city - the actual city was Camden, right across from Philadephia.   
Anyway, they're all very talented and the instruments, the set  
design, and the lyrics were all very simple but effective.  Kind of  
reminds me of house music, though not in a literal sense.  I think  
this band could signal the beginning of a new cultural revolution  
we've really not had in at least 20, perhaps 30 years.  I hope this  
band will be around for a long time just like a lot of the 70's rock  
bands still are.

--

The Atlantic was born today, and I'll tell you how:
The clouds above opened up and let it out.

I was standing on the surface of a perforated sphere
When the water filled every hole.
And thousands upon thousands made an ocean,
Making islands where no island should go.
Oh no.

Most people were overjoyed; they took to their boats.
I thought it less like a lake and more like a moat.
The rhythm of my footsteps crossing flat lands to your door
Have been silenced forever more.
The distance is quite simply much too far for me to row
It seems farther than ever before
Oh no.

I need you so much closer [x8]

I need you so much closer [x4]

So come on, come on [x4]

- Death Cab For Cutie, "Transatlantacism"

CLUB 6

Friday, April 14th
Drive & Satellitesf presents
Global Underground artist,
Lostep

Lostep's Luke Chable and Phil K have each done some amazing work for  
the scene as solo artists, and together as Lostep they have released  
stormers such as "The Roots" and Burma" featured on Sasha's Involver  
CD. Their unforgettable remix of the Shpongle classic "Dorset  
Perception" blew crowds away across the globe whenever it was spun.  
Join us as we welcome these true pioneers of house and breaks in  
celebration of the release of their new artist album "Because We Can"  
on the Global Underground label.

Opening sets
Will Spencer
Scott Carrelli

CONTACT US:
http://clubsix1.com
415.531.6593
info@clubsix1.com
PRICE: $10 presale
snagtickets.com
$15 at the door
TIME: 10pm-3am



--Apple-Mail-1-1034110484--

Hi,

I will be playing a live performance (and a few mixed in songs by other
artists) this Saturday night in Oakland from 8-9PM at Where's Waldo. Come
check out my custom fucked up "Dex burn out" usb keyboard and listen to the
sounds of nature mixed with emotional ambience in a nice chilled out room. =
I
even have a couple of rare, old classics from the mid 90's rave/ambient
years that you may spot if you are well versed in rare electronic music. Yo=
u
will also hear some sounds from the Quiet American (
http://www.quietamerican.org/) if you listen closely.

**
*More info:*
*limited $10, $15, and $20 presale tickets / $25 @ the door

infoline 415.289.2002

www.groovetickets.com
Solid Grooves - San Jose - 408.608.8256
Reverb - San Francisco - 415.221.4142
Skills - Berkeley - 510.704.9876
Channelz - Sacramento

*Find the real Waldo during the night and win prizes!!!

Save $$ off the door cost by wearing Red and White Stripes or a Waldo
costume

Questions, info, comments, contact - Nocturnalism_entertainment@yahoo.com

Steve Osteen
http://www.tussinspace.com

Subject: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

All,
 
 I'm interested in writing a short blog piece about cooperation in the rave communtiy for http://www.cooperationcommons.com, a blog devoted to understanding human cooperation where I am a contributor.  I've written a couple of short pieces already and I am currently finishing up an article on "freeriding" on P2P networks.  
 
 I don't really have a focus yet for this piece on cooperation in the rave community, but I got the idea to write something after reading this blurb on Mithen's new book The Singing Neanderthals (see http://human-nature.com/ep/reviews/ep03375380.html)  Generally I'm intereted in the ways that cooperation has developed unique social forms within the rave community, or in which the music itself is a catalyst for cooperative behavior.  I'm not that interested in various retellings of the toll plaza scene from Groove however.  Well unless they are particularly cool or amusing ;)
 
 I'm reaching out to the list for any ideas, stories, anecdotes, or whatever else you've got related to cooperation in the rave scene.  Your contributions will be duly noted and attributed of course.
 
 Regards,
 
 Peter Rothman



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

One time this naked guy named Sticky asked me if I wanted anything hard. I
said "Sure" and next thing you know I was sharing a bottle of rum with a
whole group of people and we started talking like pirates and ran around in
circles chanting "yo ho ho HO a pirates life for me.." Too bad no HOs were
there, but I still managed to get a backwards fingercuff. Plurrrrrrrrr.
snore. pluuuuurrrrrr snore. Plurrrrrrr.

Ok, maybe things didn't happen like that, but it's a good dream nonetheless=
.

I said "Sure" and next thing you know I was sharing a bottle of rum with a whole group of people and we started talking like pirates and ran around in circles chanting "yo ho ho HO a pirates life for me.." Too bad no HOs were there, but I still managed to get a backwards fingercuff. Plurrrrrrrrr. snore. pluuuuurrrrrr snore. Plurrrrrrr. 
  
 Ok, maybe things didn't happen like that, but it's a good dream nonetheless.
  
  
 On 4/10/06, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:  That's a fascinating story.  Did she have sex with you out of gratitude?

Butt munch.

Double plus plur to you too ;) 

Peter

----- Original Message ----

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

one time i offered to share my bottle of water with a girl at a rave.

plur.
 
On 4/10/06, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> All,
>
>  I'm interested in writing a short blog piece about cooperation in the rave communtiy for  http://www.cooperationcommons.com, a blog devoted to understanding human cooperation where I am a contributor.  I've written a couple of short pieces already and I am currently finishing up an article on "freeriding" on P2P networks. 
>
>  I don't really have a focus yet for this piece on cooperation in the rave community, but I got the idea to write something after reading this blurb on Mithen's new book The Singing Neanderthals (see  http://human-nature.com/ep/reviews/ep03375380.html)  Generally I'm intereted in the ways that cooperation has developed unique social forms within the rave community, or in which the music itself is a catalyst for cooperative behavior.  I'm not that interested in various retellings of the toll plaza scene from Groove however.  Well unless they are particularly cool or amusing ;) 
>
>  I'm reaching out to the list for any ideas, stories, anecdotes, or whatever else you've got related to cooperation in the rave scene.  Your contributions will be duly noted and attributed of course.
> 
>  Regards,
>
>  Peter Rothman
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

i'm trying to figure out if i have a good story.

how about this.  at my first massive i was in a crowd up front during
the Chemical Brothers.  i was rocking out and having a blast and i
looked over and noticed this really short girl dancing.

i could tell she was trying to see the stage and was having no luck,
but she was still dancing and enjoying herself.

but i felt bad because she was surrounded by people that were a good
6-10 inches taller than her and she couldn't see a damn thing.  so i
introduced myself and asked if she wanted to get on my back so she
could see the Chems.  she jumped on my back and i held her up for a
good 5-10 minutes.  she thanked me and we went our separate ways.

does that count as rave induced cooperation?

To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>

In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c0604101524vac50ad0s35d98313c4694d42@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

Yes it does!  
 
 One thing that's interesting about this and other rave related stories of cooperation and altruism I've heard is that you had no real reason to help this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in contrast to most examples of cooperation in the literature where altruism is at least somewhat influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or future rewards.  See also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
 
 What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
 
 I'm also especially interested in cooperation among promoters and collectives.  Are there similar stories out there in relation to party production?  I hear a lot about hating and people sabotaging other people's events, but I am sure there are also some notable counterexamples where people cooperated to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't have happened at all.
 
 Keep the stories coming, I'm not sure yet where this leads...
 
 And thanks again Bam!
 
 Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

i remember thinking "i am having a great time.  i love the chemical
brothers and am super stoked that i am finally seeing them live.  this
girl would probably be having a much better time if she could see the
stage.  i'm having a good time and want to help her have a good time
too."

so i did.  to this day i've never run into her again (that i know of)
and can't even remember her name.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

I don't know if this is going to be any help at all.
But at parties I like to be a sort of karma patrol
person. Like for instance if I see someone who is
inebrated or on the floor, I ask if they are okay,
offer them water etc. If they are rolling I give them
candy, lightshows whatever lol. We all need to take an
active part in the vibe aspects of a party and
contribute to the overall good feel and love that a
party should have.

my .02,

Delia

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Yes it does!  
>  
>  One thing that's interesting about this and other
> rave related stories of cooperation and altruism
> I've heard is that you had no real reason to help
> this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of
> seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did
> held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in
> contrast to most examples of cooperation in the
> literature where altruism is at least somewhat
> influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or
> future rewards.  See also:
>
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
>  
>  What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
>  
>  I'm also especially interested in cooperation among
> promoters and collectives.  Are there similar
> stories out there in relation to party production? 
> I hear a lot about hating and people sabotaging
> other people's events, but I am sure there are also
> some notable counterexamples where people cooperated
> to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't
> have happened at all.
>  
>  Keep the stories coming, I'm not sure yet where
> this leads...
>  
>  And thanks again Bam!
>  
>  Peter 
>
