> i'm trying to figure out if i have a good story.
> 
> how about this.  at my first massive i was in a
> crowd up front during
> the Chemical Brothers.  i was rocking out and having
> a blast and i
> looked over and noticed this really short girl
> dancing.
> 
> i could tell she was trying to see the stage and was
> having no luck,
> but she was still dancing and enjoying herself.
> 
> but i felt bad because she was surrounded by people
> that were a good
> 6-10 inches taller than her and she couldn't see a
> damn thing.  so i
> introduced myself and asked if she wanted to get on
> my back so she
> could see the Chems.  she jumped on my back and i
> held her up for a
> good 5-10 minutes.  she thanked me and we went our
> separate ways.
> 
> does that count as rave induced cooperation?

From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.746.2)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

well, that's a good question.  here's my opinion.

there's a lot of negativity in popular culture and i see a lot of  
young people listening to music that has stood the test of time,  
1960's and 70's rock.  pink floyd, led zeppelin, etc.  sure, 80's  
rock is still popular, but it's not epic like the stuff from the 60's  
and 70's.

now i'm not necessarily saying this band will stand that same test of  
time, but it's got potential.  when you dust that cd off 20 years  
from now what will people think?  what will you think?

i think culturally, we need more music that defines the times we live  
in overall.  i just have a feeling we might be headed that way.   
something that will exist side by side with the rave music.

does this help?

> Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)
>
> I went to see these guys in concert this weekend in Dirty Jersey.  I
> don't know, btw if that term refers to the entire state or a specific
> city - the actual city was Camden, right across from Philadephia.
> Anyway, they're all very talented and the instruments, the set
> design, and the lyrics were all very simple but effective.  Kind of
> reminds me of house music, though not in a literal sense.  I think
> this band could signal the beginning of a new cultural revolution
> we've really not had in at least 20, perhaps 30 years.  I hope this
> band will be around for a long time just like a lot of the 70's rock
> bands still are.
>
> --
>
> The Atlantic was born today, and I'll tell you how:
> The clouds above opened up and let it out.
>
> I was standing on the surface of a perforated sphere
> When the water filled every hole.
> And thousands upon thousands made an ocean,
> Making islands where no island should go.
> Oh no.
>
> Most people were overjoyed; they took to their boats.
> I thought it less like a lake and more like a moat.
> The rhythm of my footsteps crossing flat lands to your door
> Have been silenced forever more.
> The distance is quite simply much too far for me to row
> It seems farther than ever before
> Oh no.
>
> I need you so much closer [x8]
>
> I need you so much closer [x4]
>
> So come on, come on [x4]
>
> - Death Cab For Cutie, "Transatlantacism"

Awwww!  I think that tag team set on his site (live at persistence) was 
his first time playing colloboratively with anybody aside from like joking 
around at house parties.  I threw that party and didn't book myself and he 
insisted I play with him.  Too bad the volume kinda goes up and down as we 
go between my abstract weirdness (most of it domestic "milder" pressings) 
and his nose-bleed volume british pressings, but still a fun little set.

To a decade of knowing a dj in the "might as well step on the gas and 
drive the bus off the cliff cause we're all on fire already" tradition...

respect,
andyw

stuff from the past five years.

On 4/10/06, Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com> wrote:
> well, that's a good question.  here's my opinion.
>
> there's a lot of negativity in popular culture and i see a lot of
> young people listening to music that has stood the test of time,
> 1960's and 70's rock.  pink floyd, led zeppelin, etc.  sure, 80's
> rock is still popular, but it's not epic like the stuff from the 60's
> and 70's.
>
> now i'm not necessarily saying this band will stand that same test of
> time, but it's got potential.  when you dust that cd off 20 years
> from now what will people think?  what will you think?
>
> i think culturally, we need more music that defines the times we live
> in overall.  i just have a feeling we might be headed that way.
> something that will exist side by side with the rave music.
>
> does this help?
>
>

----- Original Message ----
From: Delia <velouria83@yahoo.com>

Sent: Monday, April 10, 2006 5:10:47 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

I don't know if this is going to be any help at all.
But at parties I like to be a sort of karma patrol
person. Like for instance if I see someone who is
inebrated or on the floor, I ask if they are okay,
offer them water etc. If they are rolling I give them
candy, lightshows whatever lol. We all need to take an
active part in the vibe aspects of a party and
contribute to the overall good feel and love that a
party should have.

my .02,

Delia

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Yes it does!  
>  
>  One thing that's interesting about this and other
> rave related stories of cooperation and altruism
> I've heard is that you had no real reason to help
> this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of
> seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did
> held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in
> contrast to most examples of cooperation in the
> literature where altruism is at least somewhat
> influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or
> future rewards.  See also:
>
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
>  
>  What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
>  
>  I'm also especially interested in cooperation among
> promoters and collectives.  Are there similar
> stories out there in relation to party production? 
> I hear a lot about hating and people sabotaging
> other people's events, but I am sure there are also
> some notable counterexamples where people cooperated
> to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't
> have happened at all.

> this leads...

Message-ID: <20060411142835.99404.qmail@web32413.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 2006 07:28:35 -0700 (PDT)
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
Reply-To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <7a86c50c0604101621p585ef8h83c03a0364bdd306@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

The thing that's interesting about this story is that arguably you don't have any direct benefit from your actions.  This is contrary to the standard "rational actor" model typically considered in economics.  Of course an economist might argue that you benefit through the party being better or the potential of sex or some such thing.  But I think there is more going on here, where people are taking specific actions to improve the party, the scene, the vibe, etc. even though they probably will never be able to know that their efforts were successful and trully don't realize any direct benefit.  I've been delving into an area called behavioral or psychological game theory which purports to address some of these "irrational" sorts of actions by people, but most of that theory seems to be based around models of conflict rather than pure altruism.  
 
 Of course maybe you were really hoping to get a little somethin' somethin'...you tell me. ;)
 
 Peace,
 
 Peter
 
 

----- Original Message ----
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, April 10, 2006 4:21:21 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

i remember thinking "i am having a great time.  i love the chemical
brothers and am super stoked that i am finally seeing them live.  this
girl would probably be having a much better time if she could see the
stage.  i'm having a good time and want to help her have a good time
too."

so i did.  to this day i've never run into her again (that i know of)
and can't even remember her name.



On 4/10/06, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Yes it does!
>
>  One thing that's interesting about this and other rave related stories of cooperation and altruism I've heard is that you had no real reason to help this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in contrast to most examples of cooperation in the literature where altruism is at least somewhat influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or future rewards.  See also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
>
>  What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
>
>  I'm also especially interested in cooperation among promoters and collectives.  Are there similar stories out there in relation to party production?  I hear a lot about hating and people sabotaging other people's events, but I am sure there are also some notable counterexamples where people cooperated to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't have happened at all.
>
>  Keep the stories coming, I'm not sure yet where this leads...
>
>  And thanks again Bam!
>
>  Peter
>

> > >  I'm reaching out to the list for any ideas, stories, anecdotes, or whatever else you've got related to cooperation in the rave scene.  Your contributions will be duly noted and attributed of course.
> > >
> > >  Regards,
> > >
> > >  Peter Rothman
> > >
> > >

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 11 Apr 2006 15:30:05.0854 (UTC) FILETIME=[CF19CBE0:01C65D7C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

I have no specific stories - but I have played "rave daddy" to tons of 
friends and partiers throughout the years. Even when I'm at my most 
inebriated state, I have made sure to always dissuade people from jumping in 
cars when they're all fucked up, or cramming multitudes of drugs in their 
system without regard for consequences. I think that's one of the things 
that has consistantly kept me involved in the scene...that people, sometimes 
total strangers are willing to sit down and talk a person down, hug them, 
get them water, share a drink, share a smoke, and in general - look out for 
each other, regardless of social clique, etc. It's (by and large) a very 
symbiotic social scene.

> I don't know if this is going to be any help at all.
> But at parties I like to be a sort of karma patrol
> person. Like for instance if I see someone who is
> inebrated or on the floor, I ask if they are okay,
> offer them water etc. If they are rolling I give them
> candy, lightshows whatever lol. We all need to take an
> active part in the vibe aspects of a party and
> contribute to the overall good feel and love that a
> party should have.
>
> my .02,

> Delia
>
> --- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
>> Yes it does!
>>
>>  One thing that's interesting about this and other
>> rave related stories of cooperation and altruism
>> I've heard is that you had no real reason to help
>> this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of
>> seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did
>> held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in
>> contrast to most examples of cooperation in the
>> literature where altruism is at least somewhat
>> influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or
>> future rewards.  See also:
>>
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
>>
>>  What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
>>
>>  I'm also especially interested in cooperation among
>> promoters and collectives.  Are there similar
>> stories out there in relation to party production?
>> I hear a lot about hating and people sabotaging
>> other people's events, but I am sure there are also
>> some notable counterexamples where people cooperated
>> to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't
>> have happened at all.
>>
>>  Keep the stories coming, I'm not sure yet where
>> this leads...
>>
>>  And thanks again Bam!
>>
>>  Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] re: SFR 14th anniversary event?

I def. see 'Lida's point, especially did last year.  I guess there is a distinction/line to be drawn between the "San Francisco Raves List", which Karina could certainly be said to have played an integral part in over the years, and "SFRp", a rave crew that was assembled from people who were (at the time) subscribers and regulars on said list.  Most of SFRp as I know them have largely moved on from raving to new adventures.  I don't know that the majority of them would be too motivated to throw an umpteenth anniversary party at this point.  (I could be wrong, though)
 
 Why isn't Ryan on this list anymore?  We need somebody to interject "FCUKING DUMB SLUT STOP TRYING TO STEAL OUR STREET CRED, BITCH!" right now.

 Chester?  Wanna bring the heat?
 
 -gc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

Here's something a friend of mine Bill Benzon wrote about the book Singing =
Neanderthals which I mentioned earlier...
=20
 "Mithen begins developing his argument about music in groups with a variat=
ion on Miller's argument about sexual selection. Perhaps, argues Bj=C3=B6rn=
 Merker, males in one group would band together in choral musicking to attr=
act lone females wandering away from their groups. He rejects the idea, how=
ever, on the grounds that such musicking would also attract predators. He d=
oes suggest, however, that such activity might well build trust among the m=
ales, and females as well. From there he discusses the ideas of historian W=
illiam McNeill (1995), who emphasizes the value of dance and drill in creat=
ing cohesion within the group and talks as well how group musicking leads t=
o a blurring of personal boundaries and a consequent sense of merging with =
the group.
=20
=20
  Mithen then takes up a discussion of Robert Axelrod's classic work on the=
 prisoner's dilemma, which shows the value of cooperation, but also the dif=
ficulties of achieving it in a world where people's interests are neither c=
ompletely consonant nor opposed and where it is difficult to know one anoth=
er's intentions. Mithen (214) suggests that=20
          music-making is a cheap and easy form of interaction than     can=
 demonstrate a willingness to cooperate and hence may promote future     co=
operation when there are substantial gains to be made ... It can be     tho=
ught of as the first move of a 'TIT for TAT' strategy that is to always    =
 cooperate, one that can be undertaken at no risk because there is nothing =
to     lose if the other members defect - that is, if they do not join in t=
he song     or dance.=20
      The problem with this, Mithen notes, is that, because the costs are l=
ow and the benefits are high, such musicking could easily be exploited by f=
ree-riders. To the extent, however, that musicking leads to a merging of se=
lf with the group - McNeill's argument - this problem may be dissolved (215=
):=20
          Those who make music together will mould their own minds     and =
bodies into a shared emotional state, and with that will come a loss of    =
 self-identity and a concomitant increase in the ability to cooperate with =
    others. In fact, 'cooperate' is not quite correct, because as identitie=
s are     merged there is no 'other' with whom to cooperate, just one group=
 making     decisions about how to behave.=20
      Thus musicking leads to the formation of a group identity within the =
scope of which individuals will be strongly inclined toward cooperation to =
their mutual benefit."
=20
=20
 http://human-nature.com/nibbs/05/wlbenzon.html
=20
=20
=20
 This reminds me a lot of what I've experienced at raves and parties someho=
w, but I'm still missing how the music leads to where the real cooperation =
happens in the creation of events, musical recordings, art work, etc.  Goog=
ling raves and cooperation turns up an article about promoters cooperating =
with law enforcement which is a somewhat different twist on this theme perh=
aps.
=20
 Comments?
=20
 Regards,
=20
 Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Marc(O) <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; Delia <velouria83@yahoo.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.o=
rg
Sent: Tuesday, April 11, 2006 8:30:26 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cooperation in the rave community

I have no specific stories - but I have played "rave daddy" to tons of=20
friends and partiers throughout the years. Even when I'm at my most=20
inebriated state, I have made sure to always dissuade people from jumping i=
n=20
cars when they're all fucked up, or cramming multitudes of drugs in their=
=20
system without regard for consequences. I think that's one of the things=20
that has consistantly kept me involved in the scene...that people, sometime=
s=20
total strangers are willing to sit down and talk a person down, hug them,=
=20
get them water, share a drink, share a smoke, and in general - look out for=
=20
each other, regardless of social clique, etc. It's (by and large) a very=20
symbiotic social scene.

> --- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
>> Yes it does!
>>
>>  One thing that's interesting about this and other
>> rave related stories of cooperation and altruism
>> I've heard is that you had no real reason to help
>> this person.  You didn't benefit, and the odds of
>> seeing her again were small or zero.  But you did
>> held her up so she could see anyway.  This is in
>> contrast to most examples of cooperation in the
>> literature where altruism is at least somewhat
>> influenced by the potential for mutual benefit or
>> future rewards.  See also:
>>
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterated_Prisoners_Dilemma
>>
>>  What made you think of helping her?  Any idea?
>>
>>  I'm also especially interested in cooperation among
>> promoters and collectives.  Are there similar
>> stories out there in relation to party production?

>> to make parties happen when they otherwise wouldn't
>> have happened at all.

Subject: [sfraves] Eco-Factoids.  Things YOU can do.

--0-1661659015-1144779574=:67802
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=iso-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

Shamelessly stolen from another list.

QUICK FACTS ON BOTTLED WATER VERSUS CLEANING UP THE
DRINKING WATER SUPPLY

     * Members of the United Nations estimate that if
the world took half of what it currently spends on
bottled water ($100 billion annually) and invested it
in water infrastructure and treatment, everyone in the
world could have access to clean drinking water.
     * But bottled water is cleaner, right? Actually,
the U.S. EPA sets more stringent quality standards for
tap water than the FDA does for bottled beverages, and
roughly 40% of bottled water is actually just tap
water.
     * 1.5 billion barrels of oil are consumed each
year to produce the plastic for water bottles, enough
to fuel 100,000 cars.
     * According to the Container Recycling Institute,
only 14 percent of plastic water bottles are recycled.
     * A water bottle in a landfill or lying around as
litter will take over 1,000 years to biodegrade.

http://www.organicconsumers.org/foodsafety/Bottled020606.cfm

***************************************************************
Toilet paper environmental facts to know.
Love the Planet =96 Using Recyclable Toilet Paper:

Do you know that virgin forests are cut down every day
to make toilet paper ? Here=92s what we can do to stop
it.

Toilet Paper Fact:

If every household in the United States replaced just
one roll of virgin fiber toilet paper (500 sheets)
with 100% recycled ones, we could save 423,900 trees.

_________________________________________________

Toilet Paper Companies________% Recycled %
Post-Consumer Bleaching Process

365 (Whole Foods) _ 100 >80 PCF

Ambiance 100 80 PCF

April Soft 100 80 PCF

Best Value _ 100 <40 PCF

Earth First _ 100 80 PCF

Fiesta 100 80 PCF

Marcal _ 100 40 PCF

Planet 100 80 PCF

Pert 100 <40 PCF

Seventh Generation 100 80 PCF

Sofpac _ 100 40 PCF

Charmin AVOID _ 0 0 ECF

Cottonelle AVOID _ 0 0 ECF

Note: You can also save trees by using recycled facial
tissues, paper towels, and paper napkins which are
also produced by many of the same brands above.

Three Reminders You Can Do To Help Save Our Forests:

1. Buy paper products with recycled content=97
especially post-consumer fibers.

Look for products that have a high recycled content,
including high post-consumer content. Post-consumer
fibers are recovered from paper that was previously
used by consumers and would otherwise have been dumped
into a landfill or an incinerator.

2. Buy paper products made with clean, safe processes.

Paper products are bleached to make them whiter and
brighter, but chlorine used in many bleaching
processes contributes to the formations of harmful
chemicals that wind up in our air and water and are
highly toxic to people and fish. Look for products
labeled totally chlorine-free (TCF) or processed
chlorine-free (PCF). In some cases, elemental
chlorine-free (ECF) may be acceptable.

3. Tell tissue manufacturers to stop using virgin wood
for throwaway products.

If a brand you buy for your home doesn=92t have any
recycled content, contact the manufacturer. Tell the
company to use more recycled fibers, to avoid sourcing
from ecologically valuable forests such as those in
the Cumberland Plateau and Canadian boreal, and to
ensure any virgin fibers used are certified by the
Forest Stewardship Council. Saving forests also helps
reduce global warming pollution.

Source: The Natural Resources Defense Council. To
learn more, go to www.nrdc.org.



http://www.jcthedj.com
http://www.kzsu.org/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

There is a terrorist who has killed more Americans and other
innocent people than any other terrorist on the planet and he
resides at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW.

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Thanks George. ; D
 
And HAHA, you called me 'Lida. Only my second family (oh, and Osby,  
actually) calls me that. : )
 
So I'm not so concerned about the SFRP aspect, since as far as I can tell  
she was considerate enough to not use that name this time, but the underlying  
problem remains, much of which was what I was upset about in the first place  
last time around. I wasn't *so* concerned with the fact that she was using SFRP 
 before (there's nothing inherent about the use of it that bothers me, since 
it's  not ours to own), it was the way she took the name without addressing 
its  members as a whole to let us know about it *and* the way she was conducting 
 herself in planning the party. For example, once again the event is 
restricted  to 21+. How does that accurately reflect the SFR crowd and its history? A  
21+ party is pretty exclusive.
 
Bottom line though, this was all said before and it was pretty well  
established that what Karina was doing was a bit SFR-unethical and a number of  people 
spoke to her about it. It's just baffling to me that she would do it  again.
 
I mean, I'm with Brandon on this, though- I want to give her (or whoever is  
running it) a chance to explain of course, which is why I didn't come out  
throwing punches and instead posed a few simple questions. They shouldn't  be a 
problem for her to answer if her intentions are good and if  perhaps there's 
some magical way we all managed to forget that the list was  addressed when 
planning this party. *shrug*
 
heart,
Alida

If this is all true and verifiable law like it appears to be... then
damn!!!

Any legal experts know of any other loopholes BushCo may try to slip throug=
h
on this one?


When Greg Palast, an investigator of corporate fraud and racketeering,
turned his skills to journalism, he was quickly recognized as, "The most
important investigative reporter of our time" [Tribune Magazine] in Britain=
,
where his first reports appeared on BBC
television<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/default.stm>and
in the
Guardian <http://www.guardian.co.uk/> newspapers.


<http://www.gregpalast.com/>
GANGSTER GOVERNMENT
A LEAKY PRESIDENT RUNS AFOUL OF 'LITTLE RICO'

By Greg Palast A leaky president run afoul of "Little Rico"

It's a crime. No kidding. But the media has it all wrong. As usual.

'Scooter' Libby finally outed 'Mr. Big,' the perpetrator of the heinous
disclosure of the name of secret agent Valerie Plame. It was the President
of United States himself=97in conspiracy with his Vice-President. Now the
pundits are arguing over whether our war-a-holic President had the legal
right to leak this national security information. But, that's a fake debate
meant to distract you.

OK, let's accept the White House alibi that releasing Plame's identity was
no crime. But if that's true, they've committed a BIGGER crime: Bush and
Cheney knowingly withheld vital information from a grand jury investigation=
,
a multimillion dollar inquiry the perps themselves authorized. That's akin
to calling in a false fire alarm or calling the cops for a burglary that
never happened=97but far, far worse. Let's not forget that in the hunt for =
the
perpetrator of this non-crime, reporter Judith Miller went to jail.

Think about that. While Miller sat in a prison cell, Bush and Cheney were
laughing their sick heads off, knowing the grand jury testimony, the specia=
l
prosecutor's subpoenas and the FBI's terrorizing newsrooms were nothing but
fake props in Bush's elaborate charade, Cheney's Big Con.

On February 10, 2004, our not-so-dumb-as-he-sounds President stated,
"Listen, I know of nobody =96 I don't know of anybody in my administration =
who
leaked classified information. If somebody did leak classified information,
I'd like to know it, and we'll take the appropriate action. And this
investigation is a good thing. ...And if people have got solid information,
please come forward with it."

Notice Bush's cleverly crafted words. He says he can't name anyone who
leaked this "classified" info=97knowing full well he'd de-classified it. Fa=
r
from letting Bush off the hook, it worsens the crime. For years, I worked a=
s
a government investigator and, let me tell you, Bush and Cheney withholding
material information from the grand jury is a felony. Several felonies,
actually: abuse of legal process, fraud, racketeering and, that old standby=
,
obstruction of justice.

If you or I had manipulated the legal system this way, we'd be breaking
rocks on a chain gang. We wouldn't even get a trial =96 most judges would
consider this a "fraud upon the court" and send us to the slammer in minute=
s
using the bench's power to administer instant punishment for contempt of th=
e
judicial system.

Why'd they do it? The White House junta did the deed for the most evil of
motives: to hoodwink the public during the 2004 election campaign, to
pretend that evil anti-Bush elements were undermining the Republic, when it
was the Bush element itself at the center of the conspiracy. (Notably,
elections trickery also motivated Richard Nixon's "plumbers" to break into
the Watergate, then the Democratic Party campaign headquarters.)

Let me draft the indictment for you as I would have were I still a
government gumshoe:

"Perpetrator Lewis Libby (alias, 'Scooter') contacted Miller; while John Do=
e
1 contacted perpetrators' shill at the Washington Post, Bob Woodward, in
furtherance of a scheme directed by George Bush (alias 'The POTUS') and Dic=
k
Cheney (alias, 'The Veep') to release intelligence information fraudulently
proffered as 'classified,' and thereinafter, knowingly withheld material
evidence from a grand jury empanelled to investigate said disclosure.
Furthermore, perpetrator 'The POTUS' made material statements designed to
deceive investigators and knowingly misrepresent his state of knowledge of
the facts."

Statements aimed at misleading grand jury investigators are hard-time
offenses. It doesn't matter that Bush's too-clever little quip was made to
the press and not under oath. I've cited press releases and comments in the
New York Times in court as evidence of fraud. By not swearing to his
disingenuous statement, Bush gets off the perjury hook, but he committed a
crime nonetheless, "deliberate concealment."

Here's how the law works (and hopefully, it will). The Bush gang's use of
the telephone in this con game constituted wire fraud. Furthermore, while
presidents may leak ("declassify") intelligence information, they may not
obstruct justice; that is, send a grand jury on a wild goose chase. Under
the 'RICO' statute (named after the Edward G. Robinson movie mobster,
'Little Rico'), the combination of these crimes makes the Bush executive
branch a "racketeering enterprise."

So, book'm, Dan-o. Time to read The POTUS and The Veep their rights.

After setting their bail (following the impeachments and removals, of
course), a judge will have a more intriguing matter to address. The RICO la=
w
requires the Feds to seize all "ill-gotten gains" of a racketeering
enterprise, even before trial. Usually we're talking fast cars and diamond
bling. But in this case, the conspirators' purloined booty includes a stole=
n
election and a fraudulently obtained authorization for war. I see no reason
why a judge could not impound the 82d Airborne as "fruits of the fraud " =
=96
lock, stock and gun barrels =96 and bring the boys home.

And if justice is to be done we will will also have to run yellow tape
across the gates at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue =96 "CRIME SCENE =96 DO NOT EN=
TER"
=96 and return the White House to its rightful owners, the American people,
the victims of this gangster government.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 4/13: Thursdays at @lpha with Eric Riggsbee 

--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_28262_1144792703_0
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

The week is almost over! Come join us, and start your
weekend early with resident DJs Evinrude, Dirt, Nugz,
m.d.K, Dru, E-Rok, G.A.M.M.A., and special guests. 

This week, 4/13, we're proud to feature Eric Riggsbee
[Breakthru SF]. A true turntable veteran, Eric has
been spinning breaks since 1998, and was the man
behind the Blue Harvest and Mystic parties. He has
rocked such dancefloors as 1015 Folsom, The DNA
Lounge, and 550 Barneveld - come watch him rock the
house at our little spot.

Thursdays are always free, the first beat drops at
9pm, and we go 'til 2am. @lpha bar is located at 3848
Geary, at the corner of 3rd Ave. We'll see you there!
--NextPart_Webmail_9m3u9jl4l_28262_1144792703_0--

welcome to the nearly last 6 years of hell. 

Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote: If this is all true and verifiable law like it appears to be... then
damn!!!

Any legal experts know of any other loopholes BushCo may try to slip through
on this one?


When Greg Palast, an investigator of corporate fraud and racketeering,
turned his skills to journalism, he was quickly recognized as, "The most
important investigative reporter of our time" [Tribune Magazine] in Britain,
where his first reports appeared on BBC
televisionand
in the
Guardian  newspapers.



GANGSTER GOVERNMENT
A LEAKY PRESIDENT RUNS AFOUL OF 'LITTLE RICO'

By Greg Palast A leaky president run afoul of "Little Rico"

It's a crime. No kidding. But the media has it all wrong. As usual.

'Scooter' Libby finally outed 'Mr. Big,' the perpetrator of the heinous
disclosure of the name of secret agent Valerie Plame. It was the President
of United States himselfï¿½in conspiracy with his Vice-President. Now the
pundits are arguing over whether our war-a-holic President had the legal
right to leak this national security information. But, that's a fake debate
meant to distract you.

OK, let's accept the White House alibi that releasing Plame's identity was
no crime. But if that's true, they've committed a BIGGER crime: Bush and
Cheney knowingly withheld vital information from a grand jury investigation,
a multimillion dollar inquiry the perps themselves authorized. That's akin
to calling in a false fire alarm or calling the cops for a burglary that
never happenedï¿½but far, far worse. Let's not forget that in the hunt for the
perpetrator of this non-crime, reporter Judith Miller went to jail.

Think about that. While Miller sat in a prison cell, Bush and Cheney were
laughing their sick heads off, knowing the grand jury testimony, the special
prosecutor's subpoenas and the FBI's terrorizing newsrooms were nothing but
fake props in Bush's elaborate charade, Cheney's Big Con.

On February 10, 2004, our not-so-dumb-as-he-sounds President stated,
"Listen, I know of nobody ï¿½ I don't know of anybody in my administration who
leaked classified information. If somebody did leak classified information,
I'd like to know it, and we'll take the appropriate action. And this
investigation is a good thing. ...And if people have got solid information,
please come forward with it."

Notice Bush's cleverly crafted words. He says he can't name anyone who
leaked this "classified" infoï¿½knowing full well he'd de-classified it. Far
from letting Bush off the hook, it worsens the crime. For years, I worked as
a government investigator and, let me tell you, Bush and Cheney withholding
material information from the grand jury is a felony. Several felonies,
actually: abuse of legal process, fraud, racketeering and, that old standby,
obstruction of justice.

If you or I had manipulated the legal system this way, we'd be breaking
rocks on a chain gang. We wouldn't even get a trial ï¿½ most judges would
consider this a "fraud upon the court" and send us to the slammer in minutes
using the bench's power to administer instant punishment for contempt of the
judicial system.

Why'd they do it? The White House junta did the deed for the most evil of
motives: to hoodwink the public during the 2004 election campaign, to
pretend that evil anti-Bush elements were undermining the Republic, when it
was the Bush element itself at the center of the conspiracy. (Notably,
elections trickery also motivated Richard Nixon's "plumbers" to break into
the Watergate, then the Democratic Party campaign headquarters.)

Let me draft the indictment for you as I would have were I still a
government gumshoe:

"Perpetrator Lewis Libby (alias, 'Scooter') contacted Miller; while John Doe
1 contacted perpetrators' shill at the Washington Post, Bob Woodward, in
furtherance of a scheme directed by George Bush (alias 'The POTUS') and Dick
Cheney (alias, 'The Veep') to release intelligence information fraudulently
proffered as 'classified,' and thereinafter, knowingly withheld material
evidence from a grand jury empanelled to investigate said disclosure.
Furthermore, perpetrator 'The POTUS' made material statements designed to
deceive investigators and knowingly misrepresent his state of knowledge of
the facts."

Statements aimed at misleading grand jury investigators are hard-time
offenses. It doesn't matter that Bush's too-clever little quip was made to
the press and not under oath. I've cited press releases and comments in the
New York Times in court as evidence of fraud. By not swearing to his
disingenuous statement, Bush gets off the perjury hook, but he committed a
crime nonetheless, "deliberate concealment."

Here's how the law works (and hopefully, it will). The Bush gang's use of
the telephone in this con game constituted wire fraud. Furthermore, while
presidents may leak ("declassify") intelligence information, they may not
obstruct justice; that is, send a grand jury on a wild goose chase. Under
the 'RICO' statute (named after the Edward G. Robinson movie mobster,
'Little Rico'), the combination of these crimes makes the Bush executive
branch a "racketeering enterprise."

So, book'm, Dan-o. Time to read The POTUS and The Veep their rights.

After setting their bail (following the impeachments and removals, of
course), a judge will have a more intriguing matter to address. The RICO law
requires the Feds to seize all "ill-gotten gains" of a racketeering
enterprise, even before trial. Usually we're talking fast cars and diamond
bling. But in this case, the conspirators' purloined booty includes a stolen
election and a fraudulently obtained authorization for war. I see no reason
why a judge could not impound the 82d Airborne as "fruits of the fraud " ï¿½
lock, stock and gun barrels ï¿½ and bring the boys home.

And if justice is to be done we will will also have to run yellow tape
across the gates at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue ï¿½ "CRIME SCENE ï¿½ DO NOT ENTER"
ï¿½ and return the White House to its rightful owners, the American people,
the victims of this gangster government.

tration
> who

> information,

d it.

> as

> withholding
> material information from the grand jury is a felony. Several felonies,
> actually: abuse of legal process, fraud, racketeering and, that old
> standby,
> obstruction of justice.

> If you or I had manipulated the legal system this way, we'd be breaking
> rocks on a chain gang. We wouldn't even get a trial =EF=BF=BD most judges=

> minutes
> using the bench's power to administer instant punishment for contempt of
> the
> judicial system.

o

> Doe

f
> the facts."

o

> the
> New York Times in court as evidence of fraud. By not swearing to his

>

> obstruct justice; that is, send a grand jury on a wild goose chase. Under

> 'Little Rico'), the combination of these crimes makes the Bush executive

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  The Sisters present Perpetual Indulgence in the Park

--=====================_19323140==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The Sisters present Perpetual Indulgence in the Park

Sunday, April 16th

11:00am - 4:00pm-ish

Free

----/ Event Description /-----------------------------------------------

Continuing their mission to promulgate Universal Joy, the Sisters of  
Perpetual Indulgence are proud to announce "Perpetual Indulgence" in  
the Park, an Easter picnic and celebration. This very San Francisco  
event brings together children, families, friends, artists and community activists all on  
one lawn to celebrate the Sisters' 27th Anniversary and enjoy a day  
in Dolores Park. This event is free to the public. "Perpetual  
Indulgence" in the Park promises to be lively and vivacious  
incorporating stage performances, children's activities and two cash- 
prize contests.

Sister MaryMae Himm, this year's chair of "Perpetual Indulgence" in  
the Park, says "We have all of the old favorites, the Hunky Jesus  
Contest, the Bonnet Contest, Grants Giveaways and Saintings, but we  
are planning a lot of surprises and fun new tricks. The best thing  
about the Sisters' Birthday Celebration is that there is something  
for everyone. It's a true family day, from the kids events in the  
morning, picnicking in the park and ending with the more risqu?  
things like the Hunky Jesus and Bonnet Contests. It's one of the few  
times you really can make everyone happy."

At 1p, participants will line up to parade across the stage in their  
Easter finest for our Bonnet Contest. Later, at 3:15p, this year's  
Hunky Jesus will be chosen. Both winners will receive a $100 cash prize.

In addition to providing an afternoon of merriment, the Sisters also  
hope to raise money for a whole year of grants awards.


More information at http://www.thesisters.org

----/ Venue Info /------------------------------------------------------

Dolores Park
Dolores & 19th Streets
San Francisco



MUNI via the 22, 33, and J. Also just a hop, hop and a hop away from  
Church Street Station (we didn't plan it that way, honest).

----/ Additional Info /-------------------------------------------------

viva@thesisters.org
415-939-0849
http://www.thesisters.org




------------------------------



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Message-ID: <BAY103-F142847ECF336BF10D54C1A85C20@phx.gbl>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] This is the end...

Well...as much as this is tearing me up to post this, I have to suck it up 
and do it.

I'm selling off my record collection. I have a shitload of vinyl, so I'm not 
going to take the time to catalog it all and list it. I'm going to open up 
times at my apartment where you all can come and dig thru my stacks, listen, 
and god willing - purchase stuff.

Some VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS....I *cannot* do deals - either for bulk or for 
visual wear & tear issues. My financial situation is positively dire, so 
please don't give me shit about prices or try haggling - this is literally 
everything I own that's worth anything, and it's killing me to part with 
them.

The vast majority of my records have been well cared for. They may needs 
some cleaning, but all in all they're in great condition.

I have everything from breakbeat, to house, tech-house, drum & bass, trance 
and more. I have a ton of older stuff that's rare or hard to find, or just 
plain obscenely expensive due to rarity or popularity.

After the vinyl, my mixer will go - it's a Vestax PMC 250, used, but works 
great. I think I can even get an extra cross fader for you from a friend of 
mine (but I'll have to check on that).

I'll be holding back one bag's worth of records for what will most likely be 
my last gig @ 1015 on the 21st of this month - after that night, those 
records will be for sale as well.

Anyone who has heard me knows I have good records...so please, if you know 
folks who are looking, let me know.

I seriously feel sick posting this - but my life went to hell over the last 
month, and there's no end in sight. I have tried to find a 2nd job, but 
every opportunity has fallen through, my rent is late, my bank is way 
overdrawn, when my next paycheck comes in, it'll be decimated within minutes 
then I'll be back in the red. I have about 10 things poised to go to 
collections, and no way to recover. I've tried to look for a loan of some 
kind, but my credit is just shitty enough to make sure that'll never happen. 
I'd ask my folks for money, but I don't come from a well off family, so 
that's also a dead end. This is my last resort...I hope you guys can help 
me.

Thanks for all the support everyone has given me in my DJing...it's really 
meant the world to me. I wish there was another way for me to get around 
this dilemma - as DJing has been my sanctuary for the last 5 years. Maybe 
some day in the future I'll be back, but for now, it's time to face the 
music one last time.

~Marco

Subject: RE: [sfraves] This is the end...

Day job doesn't pay enough, and I can't really adjust my schedule to 
accomodate another position unless the hours are uber flexible or just 
reserved to weekends. I tried taking a job driving an escort which promised 
to pay well, but woulda had me working my day job from 9am to 6pm, then 
driving her from 8pm to 6am - and I honestly woulda been all over it had she 
not flaked out on me.

And you're right Chris - music has been my life since I can't tell you when. 
When my last band fucked me over and took all my shit and split town (back 
in DC), I found my way to DJing, and it's been my life ever since - it's 
right uip there with food, air, sleep and the other essential bullshit for 
me. But, there's a time when you have to suck it up and do what you need to 
do to survive. Truth be told, unless I get a good price on m,y stuff, this 
might barely serve to keep me afloat - but it's the only chance I have right 
now, and I'm not about to have my wages garnished because I didn't lift a 
finger to help myself.

If I could sell my ass right now and not hate myself for it, I would do that 
way before this...but that's just not my thing.

As far as my resume - my tech experience is limited to desktop support 
pretty much (which I've been doing the last year or more), a glorified 
customer service rep at best. I mean, I HAVE a decent chunk of skills - but 
nothing I can really take to a part time position anywhere. I have no certs, 
no degree, and the last few years I was contracting mostly, so it looks like 
I'm the biggest flake on earth. I guess in hindsight , given my current 
position, that's not too far off from the truth...

ANyway...if you can think of anything that would keep me from selling off my 
babies...I sure as shit wouldn't scoff at the opportunity!

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: [KONTROL] Sat.Apr.15 with PAN/TONE (Cologne) performing LIVE!

Saturday, April 15th

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 3rd Saturday at Rx Gallery


Featuring from Cologne, Germany

PAN/TONE - LIVE PA
Sub_Static . Background . Sender/Kompakt
Ladomat 2000 . Onitor . 240 Volts . Revolver

Whether answering to Sid LeRock, Gringo Grinder, or Shelbono
"Barracuda" del Monte, this Toronto native now living in Cologne is a
man of wry charm and multiple musical masks.  Under his Pan/Tone
alais, the two time MUTEK veteran takes sweaty minimal techno and
injects gnarling basslines, distorted synths, and a whisky-soaked
party vibe to create his signature "Rockno" sound.  Come see for your
self why the Germans call him "The Craziest Woodsman in Canada!"


with resident DJs:
ALLAND BYALLO ( liebe*detail . kvadrat produkt . mo's ferry )
SAMMY D  ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( concept sf . esdjco )


Digital video art by ECON.net
Drink specials by JINRO soju

________________________________________________

Rx Gallery
132 Eddy @ Mason, SF / 415.474.7973
9pm-2am / 21+ / $10
________________________________________________

Check our website for full bios and lots FREE music!
http://www.kontrolsf.com

UPDATE: The photo gallery is finally up!
Also, download speeds are much faster now!

View the flyer here:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K11W.jpg

________________________________________________


The life and times of the former Sheldon Thompson, aka PAN/TONE:

Native to the northern regions of Ontario where ice fishing and
ski-doos are all the rage, Shelbono LeRoche currently lives in
Cologne, Germany with at least 20 bars in walking distance (the
closest one is where you might suspect to find him.) With over 20
releases, 3 albums in 2004-2005 alone, the man with many faces is
bouncing and crashing his way around the world to bring new breath of
sounds to dancefloors under the alias's of PAN/TONE (sub-static,
sender/kompakt, 240 Volts), SID LeROCK (Ladomat2000, Mute) and GRINGO
GRINDER (Onitor). With a steady output of releases, he has seen one of
his busiest years unfold with great success, coming with the privilege
of seeing many new cities and meeting many like minded individuals.
With more production under way for future releases under all names,
Shelbono has been commited to detoxing himself to better health to
prepare himself again for 2006. The neighbours now find themselves
lucky to be next to a producer preparing for his next album(s) in the
midnight hours.

A warning to the promoters: Please make sure to tell him who he is
performing as in advance...things become a little fuzzy after a few
drinks...make sure to repeat, then send him on his way and all will be
fine...the music and the moment will meet its maker. Music will then
be very LOUD and the boys will be screaming like little girls and the
girls will be dancing all over your nice furniture... piss drunk like
a sailor.... which is exactly what happened at all of the following
clubs and/or festivals:

CANADA: MUTEK festival/montreal, footwork/toronto, element
club/toronto. ENGLAND (UK): london/FABRIC, london/foreign muck.
FRANCE: MUTEK festival/marseille, zoo bizarre/bordeaux,
montpellier/villa rouge, paris/the rex, paris/le pulp. GERMANY:
everywhere! HOLLAND: amsterdam/club paradiso, den haag/transmediale
festival. ITALY: Torino/the loft, Torino/cacao, Bologna/cassero.
JAPAN: tokyo/the womb, tokyo/magnet club. PORTUGAL: coimbra/via
latina, lisbon/op-art. RUSSIA: moscow/mix club. SPAIN: barcelona/the
loft club, barcelona/city hall, valencia/bencassim festival,
madrid/rumble, granada/moshi club. SWITZERLAND: zurich/dackcantine.
TURKEY: istanbul/rock n coke festival. USA: detroit/the shelter, new
york/centro-fly.


LINKS:

http://www.pantone-music.com/

http://www.discogs.com/artist/Pan%2FTone

http://www.sidlerock.com/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] This is the end...

I'm with Chris on this...selling your records is just the wrong thing to do.  I've been down and out financially myself not very long ago.  Selling your records is the wrong way to go.
 
 
 Here's some other ideas.  
 
 1. 14th anniversary benefit SFR party with some unknown charity?  That's pretty lame.  Sorry Karina, but it is.  There's a good cause right here to help one of our own.  Someone should set up a benefit party in the next two weeks to help Marco keep his records.  I'll be there supporting if someone can pull it off.  Moreover, I might be able to help with some of the expenses of making it happen.  Bam?  Anyone?  I'm serious here.  I'm not rich, but I'll contribute what I can to make this happen.
 
 2. Everyone and anyone that might be able to help with employment, its time to come forward.  I've posted some jobs previously, but Marco go over to the Stanford website and check out the employment section.  If you find anything at all there that might help you I can have my wife put in the word for you.  Unfortunately, my company isn't hiring until the summer at the earliest.  Marco you should take Chris up on his offer even if you think you are underqualified!
 
 3. Everyone on the list contact Marco directly and find out what he needs that you can help with.  A few free meals can go a long way to paying the PGE bill.  A little bit of herb can ease the tensions.  An old BART ticket you don't need anymore can help with transport.  A part time gig, even if the pay sucks, might make the difference.  Etc.  Etc.
 
 I'm about to head out of town until Monday, but I will try to check my e-mail and see what's happening with this.  I think we as a community can really help here if we try.  And this way we get to keep hearing Marco's music so you are helping yourself and the scene too.
 
 Feel free to contact me directly about this everyone.
 
 Regards,
 
 Peter

-----Original Message-----
From: Van Mundegaarde [mailto:electrofunk138@hotmail.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, April 11, 2006 6:15 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] This is the end...
Importance: High

Well...as much as this is tearing me up to post this, I have to suck it up 
and do it.

I'm selling off my record collection. I have a shitload of vinyl, so I'm not

going to take the time to catalog it all and list it. I'm going to open up 
times at my apartment where you all can come and dig thru my stacks, listen,

and god willing - purchase stuff.

Some VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS....I *cannot* do deals - either for bulk or for 
visual wear & tear issues. My financial situation is positively dire, so 
please don't give me shit about prices or try haggling - this is literally 
everything I own that's worth anything, and it's killing me to part with 
them.

The vast majority of my records have been well cared for. They may needs 
some cleaning, but all in all they're in great condition.

I have everything from breakbeat, to house, tech-house, drum & bass, trance 
and more. I have a ton of older stuff that's rare or hard to find, or just 
plain obscenely expensive due to rarity or popularity.

After the vinyl, my mixer will go - it's a Vestax PMC 250, used, but works 
great. I think I can even get an extra cross fader for you from a friend of 
mine (but I'll have to check on that).

I'll be holding back one bag's worth of records for what will most likely be

my last gig @ 1015 on the 21st of this month - after that night, those 
records will be for sale as well.

Anyone who has heard me knows I have good records...so please, if you know 
folks who are looking, let me know.

I seriously feel sick posting this - but my life went to hell over the last 
month, and there's no end in sight. I have tried to find a 2nd job, but 
every opportunity has fallen through, my rent is late, my bank is way 
overdrawn, when my next paycheck comes in, it'll be decimated within minutes

then I'll be back in the red. I have about 10 things poised to go to 
collections, and no way to recover. I've tried to look for a loan of some 
kind, but my credit is just shitty enough to make sure that'll never happen.

I'd ask my folks for money, but I don't come from a well off family, so 
that's also a dead end. This is my last resort...I hope you guys can help 
me.

Thanks for all the support everyone has given me in my DJing...it's really 
meant the world to me. I wish there was another way for me to get around 
this dilemma - as DJing has been my sanctuary for the last 5 years. Maybe 
some day in the future I'll be back, but for now, it's time to face the 
music one last time.

~Marco

You're the kind of bull who's put the animal in me]

I eat cannibal
Feed on animal
Your love is so edible to me
I eat cannibals

I eat cannibal
It's incredible
You bring out the animal in me
I eat cannibals

Roastin', toastin', you're the one I'm boastin'
Eat me, eat you, incredibly delicious too
Gourmet, flambe, serve you up an entree
Intake, home bake, you're the icing on the cake

Eat me, eat you, incredibly delicious too
Gourmet, flambe, serve you up an entree
Intake, home bake, you're the icing on the cake
Full up, can't stop, dicing on a chop chop

------

> Importance: High
> 
> Well...as much as this is tearing me up to post
> this, I have to suck it up 
> and do it.
> 
> I'm selling off my record collection. I have a
> shitload of vinyl, so I'm not
> 
> going to take the time to catalog it all and list
> it. I'm going to open up 
> times at my apartment where you all can come and dig
> thru my stacks, listen,
> 
> and god willing - purchase stuff.
> 
> Some VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS....I *cannot* do deals -
> either for bulk or for 
> visual wear & tear issues. My financial situation is
> positively dire, so 
> please don't give me shit about prices or try
> haggling - this is literally 
> everything I own that's worth anything, and it's
> killing me to part with 
> them.
> 
> The vast majority of my records have been well cared
> for. They may needs 
> some cleaning, but all in all they're in great
> condition.
> 
> I have everything from breakbeat, to house,
> tech-house, drum & bass, trance 
> and more. I have a ton of older stuff that's rare or
> hard to find, or just 
> plain obscenely expensive due to rarity or
> popularity.
> 
> After the vinyl, my mixer will go - it's a Vestax
> PMC 250, used, but works 
> great. I think I can even get an extra cross fader
> for you from a friend of 
> mine (but I'll have to check on that).
> 
> I'll be holding back one bag's worth of records for
> what will most likely be
> 
> my last gig @ 1015 on the 21st of this month - after
> that night, those 
> records will be for sale as well.
> 
> Anyone who has heard me knows I have good
> records...so please, if you know 
> folks who are looking, let me know.
> 
> I seriously feel sick posting this - but my life
> went to hell over the last 
> month, and there's no end in sight. I have tried to
> find a 2nd job, but 
> every opportunity has fallen through, my rent is
> late, my bank is way 
> overdrawn, when my next paycheck comes in, it'll be
> decimated within minutes
> 
> then I'll be back in the red. I have about 10 things
> poised to go to 
> collections, and no way to recover. I've tried to
> look for a loan of some 
> kind, but my credit is just shitty enough to make
> sure that'll never happen.
> 
> I'd ask my folks for money, but I don't come from a
> well off family, so 
> that's also a dead end. This is my last resort...I
> hope you guys can help 
> me.
> 
> Thanks for all the support everyone has given me in
> my DJing...it's really 
> meant the world to me. I wish there was another way
> for me to get around 
> this dilemma - as DJing has been my sanctuary for
> the last 5 years. Maybe 
> some day in the future I'll be back, but for now,
> it's time to face the 
> music one last time.
> 
> ~Marco

Subject: Re: [sfraves] This is the end...

Babs and I will personally come out there and kill you if you sell off
your records.

If either of us could afford it.

:-(

I got tons of work at Stanford through Manpower in Palo Alto with
about the same skillset you describe here.

Had bunches of chances to go full time there which i passed on because
it was in the midst of the gold-rush frenzy, which I'm kicking myself
for now, but oh, well.

This is The Year of The Dog and if 1994 is any indication it's gonna
be another slog for everybody this year, but take heart next year is
the year of The Pig which is suppossed to be a prosperous one.

Keep us posted, sounds like you've made lots of friends since you've
been out there, so it doesn't sound like you're going to starve, for
one.

A recent caller to Jerry Springer's AirAmerica Radio said that it took
him a while, but he finally figured out that...

"my Net worth has nothing at all to do with my Self-Worth"

That one has been carrying me for a while now.

Peace,

nic

I agree,

there are other solutions. I have had to sell off my records a half dozen time or so because I was broke but at the end of the day I could have found other ways to make the money and have had to replace the good track over the years which has been a pain in the ass. 

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: I'm with Chris on this...selling your records is just the wrong thing to do.  I've been down and out financially myself not very long ago.  Selling your records is the wrong way to go.
 
 
 Here's some other ideas.  
 
 1. 14th anniversary benefit SFR party with some unknown charity?  That's pretty lame.  Sorry Karina, but it is.  There's a good cause right here to help one of our own.  Someone should set up a benefit party in the next two weeks to help Marco keep his records.  I'll be there supporting if someone can pull it off.  Moreover, I might be able to help with some of the expenses of making it happen.  Bam?  Anyone?  I'm serious here.  I'm not rich, but I'll contribute what I can to make this happen.
 
 2. Everyone and anyone that might be able to help with employment, its time to come forward.  I've posted some jobs previously, but Marco go over to the Stanford website and check out the employment section.  If you find anything at all there that might help you I can have my wife put in the word for you.  Unfortunately, my company isn't hiring until the summer at the earliest.  Marco you should take Chris up on his offer even if you think you are underqualified!
 
 3. Everyone on the list contact Marco directly and find out what he needs that you can help with.  A few free meals can go a long way to paying the PGE bill.  A little bit of herb can ease the tensions.  An old BART ticket you don't need anymore can help with transport.  A part time gig, even if the pay sucks, might make the difference.  Etc.  Etc.
 
 I'm about to head out of town until Monday, but I will try to check my e-mail and see what's happening with this.  I think we as a community can really help here if we try.  And this way we get to keep hearing Marco's music so you are helping yourself and the scene too.
 
 Feel free to contact me directly about this everyone.
 
 Regards,
 
 Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Chris Jackson 
To: Van Mundegaarde ; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, April 11, 2006 7:08:55 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] This is the end...

Holy fuck man!!  This does NOT sound like a very good idea.  I hardly know
you Marco..but this doesn't sit very well with me.  You seem extremely
passionate about music, and to sell off the things that make you tick?  Are
you sure there isn't another way you can get by??  What is your work
skillset?  If I can help, I will.  Shoot me your resume.  I have a couple
great friends who work in high tech recruitment positions.  Is it that your
day job isn't paying enough, or are the bills just racking up to a point
that a second job is the only option??  If I can help, I will.  Get in
touch.  Please.

CJ   

-----Original Message-----
From: Van Mundegaarde [mailto:electrofunk138@hotmail.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, April 11, 2006 6:15 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] This is the end...
Importance: High

Well...as much as this is tearing me up to post this, I have to suck it up 
and do it.

I'm selling off my record collection. I have a shitload of vinyl, so I'm not

going to take the time to catalog it all and list it. I'm going to open up 
times at my apartment where you all can come and dig thru my stacks, listen,

and god willing - purchase stuff.

Some VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS....I *cannot* do deals - either for bulk or for 
visual wear & tear issues. My financial situation is positively dire, so 
please don't give me shit about prices or try haggling - this is literally 
everything I own that's worth anything, and it's killing me to part with 
them.

The vast majority of my records have been well cared for. They may needs 
some cleaning, but all in all they're in great condition.

I have everything from breakbeat, to house, tech-house, drum & bass, trance 
and more. I have a ton of older stuff that's rare or hard to find, or just 
plain obscenely expensive due to rarity or popularity.

After the vinyl, my mixer will go - it's a Vestax PMC 250, used, but works 
great. I think I can even get an extra cross fader for you from a friend of 
mine (but I'll have to check on that).

I'll be holding back one bag's worth of records for what will most likely be

my last gig @ 1015 on the 21st of this month - after that night, those 
records will be for sale as well.

Anyone who has heard me knows I have good records...so please, if you know 
folks who are looking, let me know.

I seriously feel sick posting this - but my life went to hell over the last 
month, and there's no end in sight. I have tried to find a 2nd job, but 
every opportunity has fallen through, my rent is late, my bank is way 
overdrawn, when my next paycheck comes in, it'll be decimated within minutes

then I'll be back in the red. I have about 10 things poised to go to 
collections, and no way to recover. I've tried to look for a loan of some 
kind, but my credit is just shitty enough to make sure that'll never happen.

I'd ask my folks for money, but I don't come from a well off family, so 
that's also a dead end. This is my last resort...I hope you guys can help 
me.

Thanks for all the support everyone has given me in my DJing...it's really 
meant the world to me. I wish there was another way for me to get around 
this dilemma - as DJing has been my sanctuary for the last 5 years. Maybe 
some day in the future I'll be back, but for now, it's time to face the 
music one last time.

~Marco

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: The Panda Rejects III - The Monkey At-tax

i know a lot of people on this list don't go out much anymore...and if
you do, you tend to go to the same places and hang out with the same
people.

if you haven't been checking out what's been going down in the local
breaks slash burner scene, i'd highly recommend this party.

ps.  i'm not playing breaks.  i'm playing old school hip hop and 80s.


The Panda Rejects III - The Monkey At-tax
April 15th, 2006
11pm-8am
$10


It's finally time for us Panda rejects to throw another party. And
recently it has come to our attention that one of our fellow panda's
has been having a difficult time with the IRS. So we decided to get
together and throw another kick-ass party, but this time make it a
benefit for our poor little panda in need. And what better day to do
this than to do it on tax day. So here we go again, Panda vs Monkey
this time.

We will also be giving out a mp3 cd compilation of the panda dj's to
the best dressed pandas and monkeys for the night. We will be selling
these cd's @ the door for only $10 to help raise a little bit more
money for those of you that don't feel the urge to dress up. The disc
will have 5+ hours of music with a complete set from each of the panda
dj's, and it is very limited edition.

We also wanted to thank all the dj's for donating their time for a
good cause, and we would like to thank everyone for coming out and
supporting the show in advance. Because we know you will, you can't
resist us cause we're cute and fuzzy.


The Panda dj's:

Kapt'n Kirk (panda #01)
Aaron Jae (panda #73)
Ernie Trevino (panda #1138)
Donna Matrix (panda #cos(pi)root2/(2(pi))squared)
Alxndr (panda #69)


Our Panda-rific friends:

dj Bella (Florida)
Mancub
Tung
Dov
Rodman
Goldilox
Mozaic
Bam
J9


PandaRiffic RefresHment Servers Serving UP fine refeshments for all
our pandarejects!!

pandas serving you will be:
Lilc (Panda #43)
Hilife (Panda #16)
Shannon (Panda #07)
and special panda guest

And I heard there might be some kind of crazy breakfest goin on. Bacon
and Corndogs??

info?
www.evilbreaks.com

--
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 30th:  Broke Ass Thursdays @ Alpha Bar
April 1st:  Undercover w/ Chris Carter, Kid Kenobi @ Whisper
April 15th:  Pandamoaneum
April 21st:  Robbie Hardkiss @ 1015
Aprl 22nd:  Evil Ferrets @ Alpha Bar - Aaron Jae's Birthday Crackup
May 20th:  DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's
July 21st:  Mighty Breaks

>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Van Mundegaarde [mailto:electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
> Sent: Tuesday, April 11, 2006 6:15 PM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] This is the end...
> Importance: High
>
> Well...as much as this is tearing me up to post this, I have to suck it u=
p
> and do it.
>
> I'm selling off my record collection. I have a shitload of vinyl, so I'm =
not
>
> going to take the time to catalog it all and list it. I'm going to open u=
p
> times at my apartment where you all can come and dig thru my stacks, list=
en,
>
> and god willing - purchase stuff.
>
> Some VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS....I *cannot* do deals - either for bulk or f=
or
> visual wear & tear issues. My financial situation is positively dire, so
> please don't give me shit about prices or try haggling - this is literall=
y
> everything I own that's worth anything, and it's killing me to part with
> them.
>
> The vast majority of my records have been well cared for. They may needs
> some cleaning, but all in all they're in great condition.
>
> I have everything from breakbeat, to house, tech-house, drum & bass, tran=
ce
> and more. I have a ton of older stuff that's rare or hard to find, or jus=
t
> plain obscenely expensive due to rarity or popularity.
>
> After the vinyl, my mixer will go - it's a Vestax PMC 250, used, but work=
s
> great. I think I can even get an extra cross fader for you from a friend =
of
> mine (but I'll have to check on that).
>
> I'll be holding back one bag's worth of records for what will most likely=
 be
>
> my last gig @ 1015 on the 21st of this month - after that night, those
> records will be for sale as well.
>
> Anyone who has heard me knows I have good records...so please, if you kno=
w
> folks who are looking, let me know.
>
> I seriously feel sick posting this - but my life went to hell over the la=
st
> month, and there's no end in sight. I have tried to find a 2nd job, but
> every opportunity has fallen through, my rent is late, my bank is way
> overdrawn, when my next paycheck comes in, it'll be decimated within minu=
tes
>
> then I'll be back in the red. I have about 10 things poised to go to
> collections, and no way to recover. I've tried to look for a loan of some
> kind, but my credit is just shitty enough to make sure that'll never happ=
en.
>
> I'd ask my folks for money, but I don't come from a well off family, so
> that's also a dead end. This is my last resort...I hope you guys can help
> me.
>
> Thanks for all the support everyone has given me in my DJing...it's reall=
y
> meant the world to me. I wish there was another way for me to get around
> this dilemma - as DJing has been my sanctuary for the last 5 years. Maybe
> some day in the future I'll be back, but for now, it's time to face the
> music one last time.
>
> ~Marco

Dat bumbaklaat calendar is dun years old mon.  You come'un wayside, no=20
sense a'all in dem 'ed.  Dem pritty deh come, dem get wha de 'serve. =20
Like dem switchblade, I bring it in dem night.  Past dem light, past dem=20
scream, where the eir change from dangerous to haunted.  You know who I am=
=20
but you never known how much der is left to go.  Dem weak fall, dem weak=20
an cry, dem ask are we der yet, em strong know we march.  Rarely da=20
woryah, but always a souljah.

As for dem guesslist, jus words.  As for the women, jus fren.  As fo=20
mixah, just a lightswitch that turns on music.  You call me magician but=20
I play no trickery, seen?  You give me some rope and I tie it for you.

That is all.

4-1-5-2-0-5-1-0-4-5
andyw

> > well off family, so

and smile that you have pulled yourself up over the obsticles and are doing

oscillator off you can always go back up.

> > sucks, might make the difference.  Etc.  Etc.
> >

Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

you do, you tend to go to the same places and hang out with the same

if you haven't been checking out what's been going down in the local
breaks slash burner scene, i'd highly recommend this party.

ps. i'm not playing breaks. i'm playing old school hip hop and 80s.


The Panda Rejects III - The Monkey At-tax
April 15th, 2006
11pm-8am
$10


It's finally time for us Panda rejects to throw another party. And
recently it has come to our attention that one of our fellow panda's
has been having a difficult time with the IRS. So we decided to get
together and throw another kick-ass party, but this time make it a
benefit for our poor little panda in need. And what better day to do
this than to do it on tax day. So here we go again, Panda vs Monkey
this time.

We will also be giving out a mp3 cd compilation of the panda dj's to
the best dressed pandas and monkeys for the night. We will be selling
these cd's @ the door for only $10 to help raise a little bit more
money for those of you that don't feel the urge to dress up. The disc
will have 5+ hours of music with a complete set from each of the panda
dj's, and it is very limited edition.

We also wanted to thank all the dj's for donating their time for a
good cause, and we would like to thank everyone for coming out and
supporting the show in advance. Because we know you will, you can't
resist us cause we're cute and fuzzy.


The Panda dj's:

Kapt'n Kirk (panda #01)
Aaron Jae (panda #73)
Ernie Trevino (panda #1138)
Donna Matrix (panda #cos(pi)root2/(2(pi))squared)
Alxndr (panda #69)


Our Panda-rific friends:

dj Bella (Florida)
Mancub
Tung
Dov
Rodman
Goldilox
Mozaic
Bam
J9


PandaRiffic RefresHment Servers Serving UP fine refeshments for all
our pandarejects!!

pandas serving you will be:
Lilc (Panda #43)
Hilife (Panda #16)
Shannon (Panda #07)
and special panda guest

And I heard there might be some kind of crazy breakfest goin on. Bacon
and Corndogs??

info?
www.evilbreaks.com

--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 30th: Broke Ass Thursdays @ Alpha Bar

Subject: RE: [sfraves] This is the end...

ah man...  i'm sorry.  I don't know you, but your posts are always 
good ones to read.  I was facing something similar last month - I'm 
in here in london, my work visa was running out, I couldn't get a 
tech job (plenty of interviews, but I was fumbling through them - 
mind going blank when they'd ask me stupid questions a recent 
graduate would know (though.. what are they doing insulting me like 
that (14 years experience in IT))    probably some age discrimination 
issues...  or i should have been applying for the
more management jobs (but that's not really in my resume explicitly) 
and I hate political crap

really, I was struggling with the sort of conscious knowledge that I 
didn't really want to do IT anymore, or at least not the grueling 
focused work for a corp stuff - so my unconscious was @#### with me. 
I went to film school a few years ago and have been sitting on that, 
worrying more about the money thing (IT does pay too good...)

did I mention there was a hoseup with my US bank account and I've had 
to live off my credit card for 2 months?  the ATM machine ate my card 
because my bank was merging with another company and killing all the 
bank account functions.   I have to come back to SF May 1st to 
straighten out this mess.

and couldn't apply for the visa extension till i got a job....  so it 
was looking like i'd have to return to the
states, which any sane person would be horrified of...

but...  i idly applied for an intern position with a film production 
company doing <whatever>, planning
on killing time till I have to come back.  As it turns out, they 
needed an IT guy to build a website for displaying content they have 
the rights for to potential buyers, so i got hired 24 hours later. 
forcibly  :)

then I got the visa extension in less than a week, despite missing 
the deadline for applying [the british
are careless in general - customer service, the bureaucracy, the 
trains...]    the boss said to go ahead and apply...

yeah, I'm doing IT, but I am getting an intro to the real world of 
film as well - the business side at least.
The work environment is bare bones, but enjoyable - I had an 
interview scheduled with Google over here, but really, google (and 
other companies) pamper you to make you forget you are a slave.

And I get 10% of whatever profit the website makes - that does NOT 
happen in the IT world.  Engineers get paid a pittance and MBAs / 
management make all the money.  enough of that crap!

so in summary, hang in there.   try and figure out what your bliss 
really is and keep an eye on that or
out for opportunities to merge your current skillset with the bliss 
thing.   this prod co i'm with wants to get into multimedia / merge 
of tech and entertainment (like cellphones with TV stuff) and I'm 
damn perfect for that - tech knowledge _and_ I went to film school.

and the boss is dragging everyone to sicily next month for some shoot 
or something  :)

doug


At 7:18 PM -0700 4/11/06, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>Day job doesn't pay enough, and I can't really adjust my schedule to 
>accomodate another position unless the hours are uber flexible or 
>just reserved to weekends. I tried taking a job driving an escort 
>which promised to pay well, but woulda had me working my day job 
>from 9am to 6pm, then driving her from 8pm to 6am - and I honestly 
>woulda been all over it had she not flaked out on me.
>
>And you're right Chris - music has been my life since I can't tell 
>you when. When my last band fucked me over and took all my shit and 
>split town (back in DC), I found my way to DJing, and it's been my 
>life ever since - it's right uip there with food, air, sleep and the 
>other essential bullshit for me. But, there's a time when you have 
>to suck it up and do what you need to do to survive. Truth be told, 
>unless I get a good price on m,y stuff, this might barely serve to 
>keep me afloat - but it's the only chance I have right now, and I'm 
>not about to have my wages garnished because I didn't lift a finger 
>to help myself.
>
>If I could sell my ass right now and not hate myself for it, I would 
>do that way before this...but that's just not my thing.
>
>As far as my resume - my tech experience is limited to desktop 
>support pretty much (which I've been doing the last year or more), a 
>glorified customer service rep at best. I mean, I HAVE a decent 
>chunk of skills - but nothing I can really take to a part time 
>position anywhere. I have no certs, no degree, and the last few 
>years I was contracting mostly, so it looks like I'm the biggest 
>flake on earth. I guess in hindsight , given my current position, 
>that's not too far off from the truth...
>
>ANyway...if you can think of anything that would keep me from 
>selling off my babies...I sure as shit wouldn't scoff at the 
>opportunity!
>

stay here and live and love in the community I now call my home. You guys 
have really done nothing but prove to me how truly amazing folks are out 
here, and reinforced why I live here...
