> I think I saw this guy at some Harmony part at 2nd and Jax.  Was good.
>
> n i c o
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
> To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>;
> <breakssf@topica.com>
> Sent: Wednesday, April 19, 2006 10:49 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Robbie Hardkiss, this friday
>
>
> ROBBIE HARDKISS
> With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie Hardkiss
> is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
> musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the Hardkiss
> brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and outdoor
> party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as "3
> Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the psychedelic
> West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
> legendary status within the realm of electronic music was immortalized
> with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
>
> Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
> without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John, Freestylers,
> Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals, Q-Burn, God
> Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
>
> Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the underground
> San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
> trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
> run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
> myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
> Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
> early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love firsthand
> while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
> promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
> moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
> Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves Hardkiss,
> the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
> few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
> compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
> Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
> compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush, All
> Music Guide
>
>
> ELEKTRO-PHONIK
> 1015 Folsom St
> Doors at 10pm
> $10 all night
>
> with your special guests for the evening:
>
> Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/ www.robbiehardkiss.com
>
> Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
> Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
> Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)
> Marc(O) - Otherworld / The Midnightsons / Ill Behavior/
> www.illectrofunk.com (DC/CA)
> Edison - Lovelab /GRM / Elektro-Phonik.com (DC)
>
> www.elektro-phonik.com for more info!!!!
>
>
>
> --

> < Brandon / DJ Bam >
>
> DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> http://www.evilbreaks.com
>

> April 1st:  Undercover w/ Chris Carter, Kid Kenobi @ Whisper

>> > <breakssf@topica.com>
>> > Sent: Wednesday, April 19, 2006 10:49 AM
>> > Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Robbie Hardkiss, this friday
>> >
>> >
>> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
>> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie Hardkiss
>> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
>> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the Hardkiss
>> > brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and outdoor
>> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as "3
>> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the psychedelic
>> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
>> > legendary status within the realm of electronic music was immortalized
>> > with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
>> >
>> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
>> > without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John, Freestylers,
>> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals, Q-Burn, God
>> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
>> >
>> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the underground
>> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
>> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
>> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
>> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
>> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
>> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love firsthand
>> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
>> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
>> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
>> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves Hardkiss,
>> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
>> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
>> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
>> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
>> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush, All
>> > Music Guide
>> >
>> >
>> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
>> > 1015 Folsom St
>> > Doors at 10pm
>> > $10 all night
>> >
>> > with your special guests for the evening:
>> >
>> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/ 
>> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
>> >
>> > Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
>> > Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
>> > Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)
>> > Marc(O) - Otherworld / The Midnightsons / Ill Behavior/
>> > www.illectrofunk.com (DC/CA)
>> > Edison - Lovelab /GRM / Elektro-Phonik.com (DC)
>> >
>> > www.elektro-phonik.com for more info!!!!
>> >

> >> >
> >> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the undergroun=
d
> >> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
> >> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
> >> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
> >> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
> >> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
> >> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love firsthan=
d
> >> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
> >> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
> >> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
> >> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves Hardkis=
s,
> >> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
> >> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
> >> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
> >> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
> >> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush, All
> >> > Music Guide
> >> >
> >> >
> >> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
> >> > 1015 Folsom St
> >> > Doors at 10pm
> >> > $10 all night
> >> >
> >> > with your special guests for the evening:
> >> >
> >> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/
> >> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
> >> >
> >> > Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
> >> > Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
> >> > Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)
> >> > Marc(O) - Otherworld / The Midnightsons / Ill Behavior/
> >> > www.illectrofunk.com (DC/CA)

> >> >

>>> >
>>> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
>>> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie Hardkiss
>>> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
>>> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the Hardkiss
>>> > brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and outdoor
>>> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as "3
>>> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the psychedelic
>>> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
>>> > legendary status within the realm of electronic music was immortalized
>>> > with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
>>> >
>>> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
>>> > without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John, Freestylers,
>>> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals, Q-Burn, God
>>> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
>>> >
>>> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the underground
>>> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
>>> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
>>> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
>>> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
>>> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
>>> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love firsthand
>>> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
>>> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
>>> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
>>> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves Hardkiss,
>>> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
>>> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
>>> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
>>> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
>>> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush, All
>>> > Music Guide
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
>>> > 1015 Folsom St
>>> > Doors at 10pm
>>> > $10 all night
>>> >
>>> > with your special guests for the evening:
>>> >
>>> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/ 
>>> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
>>> >

> > >> >
> > >> >
> > >> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
> > >> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie
> Hardkiss
> > >> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
> > >> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the Hardkiss
> > >> > brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and outdoor
> > >> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as "3
> > >> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the
> psychedelic
> > >> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
> > >> > legendary status within the realm of electronic music was
> immortalized
> > >> > with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
> > >> >
> > >> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
> > >> > without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John, Freestylers,
> > >> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals, Q-Burn,
> God
> > >> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
> > >> >
> > >> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the
> underground
> > >> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
> > >> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
> > >> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
> > >> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
> > >> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
> > >> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love
> firsthand
> > >> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
> > >> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
> > >> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
> > >> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves
> Hardkiss,
> > >> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
> > >> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
> > >> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
> > >> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
> > >> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush,
> All
> > >> > Music Guide
> > >> >
> > >> >
> > >> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
> > >> > 1015 Folsom St
> > >> > Doors at 10pm
> > >> > $10 all night
> > >> >
> > >> > with your special guests for the evening:
> > >> >
> > >> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/
> > >> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
> > >> >
> > >> > Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
> > >> > Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
> > >> > Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)

>> >> > Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Robbie Hardkiss, this friday
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
>> >> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie
>> Hardkiss
>> >> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
>> >> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the Hardkiss
>> >> > brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and outdoor
>> >> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as "3
>> >> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the
>> psychedelic
>> >> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
>> >> > legendary status within the realm of electronic music was
>> immortalized
>> >> > with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
>> >> >
>> >> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
>> >> > without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John, Freestylers,
>> >> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals, Q-Burn,
>> God
>> >> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
>> >> >
>> >> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the
>> underground
>> >> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
>> >> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers also
>> >> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves plus
>> >> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's God
>> >> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in the
>> >> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love
>> firsthand
>> >> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
>> >> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but later
>> >> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as well.
>> >> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves
>> Hardkiss,
>> >> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label. Though
>> >> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
>> >> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
>> >> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
>> >> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush,
>> All
>> >> > Music Guide
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
>> >> > 1015 Folsom St
>> >> > Doors at 10pm
>> >> > $10 all night
>> >> >
>> >> > with your special guests for the evening:
>> >> >
>> >> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/
>> >> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
>> >> >
>> >> > Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
>> >> > Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
>> >> > Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)
>> >> > Marc(O) - Otherworld / The Midnightsons / Ill Behavior/
>> >> > www.illectrofunk.com (DC/CA)
>> >> > Edison - Lovelab /GRM / Elektro-Phonik.com (DC)
>> >> >
>> >> > www.elektro-phonik.com for more info!!!!
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> >

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Soma-Tech (4.22) and The End Up (5.4)

Greets,

Well, first off I would like to thank everyone that made it out to the EGR 
8 year at the beginning of April. That was quite an event with a diverse 
crowd, so I was very happy. The out of town guests were excited as well and 
all of us got a chance to hang out and communicate about the state of 
techno in the US and world wide.  I plan on finally getting the EGR 8 year 
mix out this weekend..

Now to the upcoming events...

Soma-Tech  Sat April 22nd by Natural Productions / Good Bad Guy

To my knowledge this is a relatively new crew around here hosting a free 
techno event. I understand the sound system is large and things will be 
bumping from 9pm to 4am at an underground downtown SF location.  Email 
soma-tech@hotmail.com for directions and more info.

Lineup:
Blithe - House (805, LA)
Lorax - Minimal (Good Bad Guy, Mexico)
Catharsis - Industrial-Techno (EGR Records, SF)
Christian Fuller - Techno (Natural Productions, Holland)
Snoek - Techno (Good Bad Guy, Holland)


Also... On Thursday May 4th EGR Records hits The End Up in SF.
DJ Dice (Straylight/JSA)
Catharsis (EGR)
Majere (Elektrosorcery)
http://www.theendup.com/

I'm on from midnight to 2am and plan to bring as much dark techno out as I 
can get the dance floor to handle...

Hope to see you guys out...

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

> > >> >
> > >> >
> > >> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
> > >> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin
> Hardkiss, Robbie Hardkiss
> > >> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss
> family of DJs and
> > >> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San
> Francisco, the Hardkiss
> > >> > brothers were instrumental in developing the
> U.S. rave and outdoor
> > >> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering
> Hardkiss tunes such as "3
> > >> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery"
> helped define the psychedelic
> > >> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to
> grow today. Their
> > >> > legendary status within the realm of
> electronic music was immortalized
> > >> > with the release of their double album,
> Delusions of Grandeur.
> > >> >
> > >> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to
> remix songs (with and
> > >> > without his brothers) for artists such as
> Elton John, Freestylers,
> > >> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid,
> The Sandals, Q-Burn, God
> > >> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
> > >> >
> > >> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss
> brothers, ruled the underground
> > >> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s
> with a mixture of acid,
> > >> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs
> all, the brothers also
> > >> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing
> material as themselves plus
> > >> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the
> Moon and Scott's God
> > >> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who
> formed the group in the
> > >> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989
> Summer of Love firsthand
> > >> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the
> States, the two began
> > >> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the
> East Coast, but later
> > >> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe
> with the West as well.
> > >> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and
> christening themselves Hardkiss,
> > >> > the trio began recording material for their
> eponymous label. Though
> > >> > few releases appeared on anything other than
> vinyl, the label
> > >> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a
> good primer to the
> > >> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have
> each released
> > >> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as
> well. ~ John Bush, All
> > >> > Music Guide
> > >> >
> > >> >
> > >> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
> > >> > 1015 Folsom St
> > >> > Doors at 10pm
> > >> > $10 all night
> > >> >
> > >> > with your special guests for the evening:
> > >> >
> > >> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy +

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: A Very Special 4-20 Mellow Beats and Boardgames with Tycho (Merck)

A Very Special 4-20 Mellow Beats and Boardgames with Tycho (Merck)

---------------------------------------------------------

Tycho is song writer / producer Scott Hansen. After a string of  
underground offerings, Tycho's first widely available work was  
released: 2002's "The Science of Patterns". A 4 track EP, this early  
work laid the foundations for Tycho's now signature sound. In the  
year that followed, Tycho, along with Chachi Jones, Dusty Brown,  
Fruitbat, and Park Avenue formed the Command Collective, a group of  
musicians and visual artists who defined the electronic music scene  
of Sacramento, CA in the early 2000's.

After a year of experimentation and studio reconfigurations, Tycho  
set to work on a full length release to follow up the Science of  
Patterns EP. The result was 2004's "Sunrise Projector", Tycho's first  
full-length offering. The 13 tracks of Sunrise Projector further  
defined Tycho's continuously evolving sound, garnering praise from  
critics and fans alike.

2006 finds Tycho at work on two full length releases, one for Miami- 
based Merck Records and another for Quebec's Cyclop Media label.

for more information on Tycho check out: www.tychomusic.com
---------------------------------------------------------

The Canvas Gallery
Mellow Beats & Board Games
Every Thursday from 7pm - 12am
1200 9th Ave. SF CA 94122
FREE
presented by The Extra Credit :
http://www.theextracredit.com

Get rid of your work-week aggression by listening Downtempo DJs while
playing Twister, Bingo or Musical Chairs--winners get free pitchers of
beer!! Not feeling competitive? Check out one of the many board games  
in our
game library to play with your friends.

Also, be sure to check out last weeks podcast of Slidecamp.
Available through www.theextracredit.com
---------------------------------------------------------

- matt

Subject: [sfraves] What does 420 mean?

------=_Part_3286_5839432.1145574063267
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Just found this article at parentingteens.com     Damn, could it be that
we'll be this clueless when we get older???



What Does '420' Mean? From Denise
Witmer<http://parentingteens.about.com/mbiopage.htm>
,
Your Guide to Parenting of Adolescents <http://parentingteens.about.com/>.
*FREE* Newsletter. Sign Up
Now!<http://parentingteens.about.com/gi/pages/mmail.htm>
A discussion on our Parenting Advice and Support
Forum<http://forums.about.com/ab-parentteens/messages/?%20msg=3D3271.1&lgnF=
=3Dy>,
had this Guide in puzzlement. I had reported years ago that the term
420(pronounced four twenty, not four hundred and twenty), was police code
for smoking marijuana in a feature on pager codes that teenagers use to
"talk" to each other. I began researching the number again and it seems I
was wrong. Read on to learn the myths, the truth about the origin and what
this term means for parents.

*Known Myths*


   - *Police dispatch code for smoking pot is 420. * The number 420 is
   not police radio code for anything, anywhere. Checks of criminal codes
   suggest that the origin is neither Californian nor federal. For instance=
,
   California Penal Code 420 defines as a misdemeanor the hindrance of use =
of
   public lands.
   - *There are approximately 420 active chemicals in marijuana.
*Actually, there are approximately 315 active chemicals in marijuana.
This
   number goes up and down depending on which plant is used.
   - *April 20th is National Pot Smokers Day. * Well, it is now; but that
   wasn't the origin.
   - *April 20th is Hitler's birthday. * Yes, it is his birthday. But, as
   420 started out as a time, not a date, his birthday had nothing to do wi=
th
   it.
   - * April 20th is the date of the Columbine school shootings. * This
   happened after the term was already in use.
   - * 4:20 is tea time for pot-smokers in Holland. * Tea time in Holland
   is at 5:30 pm, or is it 2:30 pm? Seems no one is quite sure when the
   wonderful people of Holland drink their tea.

*The Origin Revealed*

According to Steven Hager, editor of High Times, the term 420 originated at
San Rafael High School, in 1971, among a group of about a dozen pot-smoking
wiseacres who called themselves the Waldos, who are now pushing 50. The ter=
m
was shorthand for the time of day the group would meet, at the campus statu=
e
of Louis Pasteur, to smoke pot. Intent on developing their own discreet
language, they made 420 code for a time to get high, and its use spread
among members of an entire generation. While our teens feel that they know
something we don't, you can let them in on the fact that it was your
generation that came up with the numbers.

A quote from one of the Waldos in the High Times article states, "We did
discover we could talk about getting high in front of our parents without
them knowing by using the phrase 420." Fortunately, your teenagers will not
have that same option.

*Whatever! *
Simply put, 420 is a symbol of cannabis and its culture. Today, April 20th
events are international, and 4:20 pm has become sort of a world wide "burn
time". It certainly doesn't matter too much where the term came from becaus=
e
for us parents, it's a flag, a warning sign that our teenagers may be into
something that could harm their future. When you see the symbol 420, be
aware of what it represents.



--
Acid Totem Upcoming Events

What Does '420' Mean? From Denise
Witmer<http://parentingteens.about.com/mbiopage.htm>
,
Your Guide to Parenting of Adolescents <http://parentingteens.about.com/>.
*FREE* Newsletter. Sign Up
Now!<http://parentingteens.about.com/gi/pages/mmail.htm>

Forum<http://forums.about.com/ab-parentteens/messages/?%20msg=3271.1&lgnF=y>
,
had this Guide in puzzlement. I had reported years ago that the term
420(pronounced four twenty, not four hundred and twenty), was police code
for smoking marijuana in a feature on pager codes that teenagers use to
"talk" to each other. I began researching the number again and it seems I
was wrong. Read on to learn the myths, the truth about the origin and what
this term means for parents.

*Known Myths*


   - *Police dispatch code for smoking pot is 420. * The number 420 is
   not police radio code for anything, anywhere. Checks of criminal codes
   suggest that the origin is neither Californian nor federal. For instance,
   California Penal Code 420 defines as a misdemeanor the hindrance of use
of
   public lands.
   - *There are approximately 420 active chemicals in marijuana.
*Actually, there are approximately 315 active chemicals in marijuana.
This
   number goes up and down depending on which plant is used.
   - *April 20th is National Pot Smokers Day. * Well, it is now; but that
   wasn't the origin.
   - *April 20th is Hitler's birthday. * Yes, it is his birthday. But, as
   420 started out as a time, not a date, his birthday had nothing to do
with
   it.
   - * April 20th is the date of the Columbine school shootings. * This
   happened after the term was already in use.
   - * 4:20 is tea time for pot-smokers in Holland. * Tea time in Holland
   is at 5:30 pm, or is it 2:30 pm? Seems no one is quite sure when the
   wonderful people of Holland drink their tea.

*The Origin Revealed*

According to Steven Hager, editor of High Times, the term 420 originated at
San Rafael High School, in 1971, among a group of about a dozen pot-smoking
wiseacres who called themselves the Waldos, who are now pushing 50. The term
was shorthand for the time of day the group would meet, at the campus statue
of Louis Pasteur, to smoke pot. Intent on developing their own discreet
language, they made 420 code for a time to get high, and its use spread
among members of an entire generation. While our teens feel that they know
something we don't, you can let them in on the fact that it was your
generation that came up with the numbers.

A quote from one of the Waldos in the High Times article states, "We did
discover we could talk about getting high in front of our parents without
them knowing by using the phrase 420." Fortunately, your teenagers will not
have that same option.

*Whatever! *
Simply put, 420 is a symbol of cannabis and its culture. Today, April 20th
events are international, and 4:20 pm has become sort of a world wide "burn
time". It certainly doesn't matter too much where the term came from because
for us parents, it's a flag, a warning sign that our teenagers may be into
something that could harm their future. When you see the symbol 420, be
aware of what it represents.

From sfraves-return-130926-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 20 23:33:04 2006
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-130926-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ICQ?

ICQ is a messenger client like yahoo, msn or aim.  it was started by 
Mirabilis, which has since been bought by AOL.  The letters aren't an 
acronym, but a homonym - "I seek you".  The id's are uniquie numbers, 
like a serial number.  The number of digits indicates how old the 
account is.  For example:  my first beta number was four digits long, 
my first real one was five, and the current one I use has 6.


sarilion

392307

Subject: [sfraves] Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai 

--=====================_29242875==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

April 20, 2006
Critic's Notebook


Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai 

By <http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/kelefa_sanneh/index.html?inline=nyt-per>KELEFA SANNEH

Early in the 1970's, Tom Moulton found a way to defy the laws of mathematics: he made songs longer by a process of subtraction. By stretching out the emptiest parts of his favorite records ­ the rhythmic breaks, where verses and choruses gave way to beats and grooves ­ he helped turn R&B hits like "Do It ('Til You're Satisfied)" into disco classics. His hugely influential mixes are collected on a great new double-CD compilation called "A Tom Moulton Mix" (Soul Jazz); in it, you can hear the birth of modern dance music.

Dance-music producers have been subtracting ever since, finding out that less music can often move dancers more. You can hear decades' worth of subtracting when you play "A Love Moderne" (Forcetracks), a skeletal but surprisingly seductive new CD by the Swedish producer known as Unai. It's an early contender for electronic-music album of the year, and it makes Mr. Moulton's work sound positively baroque.

In 1974, Mr. Moulton did something that would soon become commonplace: he made a mix. He spent 80 hours turning some club-friendly records into a 45-minute reel-to-reel tape, which eventually became a hit at the Sandpiper, a center of Fire Island's night life. He took the same principle ­ keep the beat going so the dancers keep dancing ­ into the recording studio, and made a series of danceable remixes and re-edits.

His discovery seems obvious now: he realized that the thumping, dance-floor-friendly soul records of the early 70's would sound that much better, and thumpinger, if he made them longer. (Apparently brevity isn't the soul of soul.) He can claim to have invented the 12-inch single, although he stumbled upon the format by mistake: an engineer had run out of 7-inch vinyl. 

"A Tom Moulton Mix" gathers 16 tracks, starting with "Keep On Truckin' (Part 1)," the 1973 hit by Eddie Kendricks, the former Temptation. The song lasts eight minutes on Kendricks's self-titled album; a radio edit whittled it down to three and a half. But Mr. Moulton went in the other direction: the version here lasts more than 11 minutes, and if anything it ends too soon. When that glorious beat ­ thundering drums, squelchy guitar, a string section darting in and out ­ finally gives way to the timpani heartbeat that serves as a coda, you may be expecting, or even hoping, that the song will come roaring back to life one more time.

Many of his mixes seem relatively unobtrusive, especially compared with the radical disco producers who emerged in the mid-70's. Walter Gibbons and Shep Pettibone, for example, took Mr. Moulton's approach further: they loved to turn songs into wild, weird, drum-driven experiments. But part of the joy in this compilation is the gentleness of Mr. Moulton's approach; he's invisible, unless you're paying attention. Whether he's toying with B.T. Express's "Peace Pipe" or extending the sublime novelty hit "Moonboots," by Orlando Riva Sound, Mr. Moulton makes mixes that hint at what came before and what would come after. You can hear soul songs morphing into machine music.

In the 70's, "disco" evolved from a place into a genre, and in the 80's, house and techno producers focused even more intently on rhythm tracks. It sometimes seems that dance-music producers are doing their best to finish what Mr. Moulton and others started: stripping away the songs until almost nothing's left.

Maybe the job is just about done. Certainly, some of the best electronic dance music these days is also some of the sparsest. In Germany and elsewhere, producers and D.J.'s have figured out ways to evoke disco's propulsion by using little more than hums and clicks and snippets and squiggles. It's just an extension of the Moulton doctrine: a relatively simple track, slowly mutating over 5 or 10 or even (in an age of CD's and laptops) 30 minutes, can drive dancers crazy.

Erik Moller, the Swede who records as Unai, is often counted as one of the minimalists; he's known for subtle, twitchy tracks that occasionally hint at dub reggae. "A Love Moderne," his second full-length CD, is to be released in America next month, and it's a slight departure. There are more melodies, more singing (his own), more songs. His fans will probably claim that this is his pop album, but beware: Unai fans probably have a different definition of pop than you do. (That's why they're Unai fans.) 

Make no mistake: this is ghostly, sometimes eerie music. Mr. Moller is clearly still obsessed with subtle electronic textures and smudgy bass lines that could almost be computer glitches. And yet he has filled this album with strong, melancholy melodies, and unlike most of his contemporaries, he doesn't embarrass himself when he tries to sing. He often hides behind electronic filters; it's as if he recorded his voice and then erased it, leaving only a trace behind. 

One track, "Heart Is to the Left," is about as close as Unai gets to a swaggering disco track. There's a sharp, unrelenting beat and an old-fashioned love lyric: "Truly I believe in you," he sings, although his voice soon disappears into the mix. And in "Modern Love," the music transforms itself through sudden cuts and gradual fades; it's a woozy composition made of gauzy synthesizers, wobbly beats, muscular bass lines, half-decayed backing vocals.

There's something pleasantly perverse about what Mr. Moller is doing: after years of making skeletal dance music, he's adding flesh to the bones he so carefully stripped. But not too much ­ the whole trick, in fact, is to make these skinny songs sound fleshier than they are. Whether they mean to or not, producers like him are heading back toward the disco mixes of the 1970's, only from the other side. Once it was a thrill to hear pop songs turning into electronic tracks. But it can be just as much fun to hear the process in reverse.

http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/20/arts/music/20sann.html?_r=5&oref=login&pagewanted=print

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_29242875==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What does 420 mean?

Only if you choose to be Ben. 
 
 I remember a couple of years ago my current wife and I had dinner with my ex-girlfriend from college and her husband.  They live in a nice suburban house in Thousand Oaks California where I had visited her a few months earlier.  She was going on about how the city was much "dirtier" than she remembered it.  She used to live in the city back in the early eighties and I grew up in the area, and went to high school over in the Haight (Urban School).  I was pretty amazed to hear this, because my recollection of the Haight and Mission (where we were having dinner at a fancy restaraunt) from those times was that they used to be much dirtier, there was more crime, and no nice shops or restaraunts at all.  The conversation went on with her complaining about the "weirdos" and so forth.
 
 When she lived in the city she was one of those weirdos.  She lived near union street and we used to frequently walk through the tenderloin when were going out drinking.  It hasn't changed much, it was full of addicts, and transvestite hookers, and so forth.  We fit in.  I don't recall the name of the bar we used to stop at in the tenderloin on our way over to North Beach, but it was way shadier than any place I frequent these days.
 
 I guess she didn't want her husband to think she had been one of those weirdos back in the day.  He seemed like a nice guy and I doubt he would have divorced her if he had known she was a bisexual pot smoking leather wearing bar crawler 20+ years ago.  But once you start caring about what people will think, you have to start conforming your history to their beliefs too.  If you do this long enough, you'll not only forget what it was really like back in the day but possibly even who you really were/are.
 
 Personally I still have the leather jacket I used to war back then even if it doesn't fit quite as well as it used to.
 
 Regards,
 
 Peter

-----Original Message-----

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai

------=_Part_13567_26470672.1145627359381
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Tom Moulton is amazing, and he still produces incredible stuff today.




On 4/21/06, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
>
> April 20, 2006
> Critic's Notebook
>
>
> Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai
>
> By <
> http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/kelefa_sanne=
h/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>KELEFA
> SANNEH
>
> Early in the 1970's, Tom Moulton found a way to defy the laws of
> mathematics: he made songs longer by a process of subtraction. By stretch=
ing
> out the emptiest parts of his favorite records =AD the rhythmic breaks, w=
here
> verses and choruses gave way to beats and grooves =AD he helped turn R&B =
hits
> like "Do It ('Til You're Satisfied)" into disco classics. His hugely
> influential mixes are collected on a great new double-CD compilation call=
ed
> "A Tom Moulton Mix" (Soul Jazz); in it, you can hear the birth of modern
> dance music.
>
> Dance-music producers have been subtracting ever since, finding out that
> less music can often move dancers more. You can hear decades' worth of
> subtracting when you play "A Love Moderne" (Forcetracks), a skeletal but
> surprisingly seductive new CD by the Swedish producer known as Unai. It's=
 an
> early contender for electronic-music album of the year, and it makes Mr.
> Moulton's work sound positively baroque.
>
> In 1974, Mr. Moulton did something that would soon become commonplace: he
> made a mix. He spent 80 hours turning some club-friendly records into a
> 45-minute reel-to-reel tape, which eventually became a hit at the Sandpip=
er,
> a center of Fire Island's night life. He took the same principle =AD keep=
 the
> beat going so the dancers keep dancing =AD into the recording studio, and=
 made
> a series of danceable remixes and re-edits.
>
> His discovery seems obvious now: he realized that the thumping,
> dance-floor-friendly soul records of the early 70's would sound that much
> better, and thumpinger, if he made them longer. (Apparently brevity isn't
> the soul of soul.) He can claim to have invented the 12-inch single,
> although he stumbled upon the format by mistake: an engineer had run out =
of
> 7-inch vinyl.
>
> "A Tom Moulton Mix" gathers 16 tracks, starting with "Keep On Truckin'
> (Part 1)," the 1973 hit by Eddie Kendricks, the former Temptation. The so=
ng
> lasts eight minutes on Kendricks's self-titled album; a radio edit whittl=
ed
> it down to three and a half. But Mr. Moulton went in the other direction:
> the version here lasts more than 11 minutes, and if anything it ends too
> soon. When that glorious beat =AD thundering drums, squelchy guitar, a st=
ring
> section darting in and out =AD finally gives way to the timpani heartbeat=
 that
> serves as a coda, you may be expecting, or even hoping, that the song wil=
l
> come roaring back to life one more time.
>
> Many of his mixes seem relatively unobtrusive, especially compared with
> the radical disco producers who emerged in the mid-70's. Walter Gibbons a=
nd
> Shep Pettibone, for example, took Mr. Moulton's approach further: they lo=
ved
> to turn songs into wild, weird, drum-driven experiments. But part of the =
joy
> in this compilation is the gentleness of Mr. Moulton's approach; he's
> invisible, unless you're paying attention. Whether he's toying with B.T.
> Express's "Peace Pipe" or extending the sublime novelty hit "Moonboots," =
by
> Orlando Riva Sound, Mr. Moulton makes mixes that hint at what came before
> and what would come after. You can hear soul songs morphing into machine
> music.
>
> In the 70's, "disco" evolved from a place into a genre, and in the 80's,
> house and techno producers focused even more intently on rhythm tracks. I=
t
> sometimes seems that dance-music producers are doing their best to finish
> what Mr. Moulton and others started: stripping away the songs until almos=
t
> nothing's left.
>
> Maybe the job is just about done. Certainly, some of the best electronic
> dance music these days is also some of the sparsest. In Germany and
> elsewhere, producers and D.J.'s have figured out ways to evoke disco's
> propulsion by using little more than hums and clicks and snippets and
> squiggles. It's just an extension of the Moulton doctrine: a relatively
> simple track, slowly mutating over 5 or 10 or even (in an age of CD's and
> laptops) 30 minutes, can drive dancers crazy.
>
> Erik Moller, the Swede who records as Unai, is often counted as one of th=
e
> minimalists; he's known for subtle, twitchy tracks that occasionally hint=
 at
> dub reggae. "A Love Moderne," his second full-length CD, is to be release=
d
> in America next month, and it's a slight departure. There are more melodi=
es,
> more singing (his own), more songs. His fans will probably claim that thi=
s
> is his pop album, but beware: Unai fans probably have a different definit=
ion
> of pop than you do. (That's why they're Unai fans.)
>
> Make no mistake: this is ghostly, sometimes eerie music. Mr. Moller is
> clearly still obsessed with subtle electronic textures and smudgy bass li=
nes
> that could almost be computer glitches. And yet he has filled this album
> with strong, melancholy melodies, and unlike most of his contemporaries, =
he
> doesn't embarrass himself when he tries to sing. He often hides behind
> electronic filters; it's as if he recorded his voice and then erased it,
> leaving only a trace behind.
>
> One track, "Heart Is to the Left," is about as close as Unai gets to a
> swaggering disco track. There's a sharp, unrelenting beat and an
> old-fashioned love lyric: "Truly I believe in you," he sings, although hi=
s
> voice soon disappears into the mix. And in "Modern Love," the music
> transforms itself through sudden cuts and gradual fades; it's a woozy
> composition made of gauzy synthesizers, wobbly beats, muscular bass lines=
,
> half-decayed backing vocals.
>
> There's something pleasantly perverse about what Mr. Moller is doing:
> after years of making skeletal dance music, he's adding flesh to the bone=
s
> he so carefully stripped. But not too much =AD the whole trick, in fact, =
is to
> make these skinny songs sound fleshier than they are. Whether they mean t=
o
> or not, producers like him are heading back toward the disco mixes of the
> 1970's, only from the other side. Once it was a thrill to hear pop songs
> turning into electronic tracks. But it can be just as much fun to hear th=
e
> process in reverse.
>
>
> http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/20/arts/music/20sann.html?_r=3D5&oref=3Dlo=
gin&pagewanted=3Dprint
>
>
>
>
> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
> Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>
> http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as yo=
u
> think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  Thi=
s
> question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me abo=
ut
> it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understa=
nd
> it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this pat=
h
> have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no
> use."
> -Don Juan
>
> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> -Edward R. Murrow
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually becom=
e
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
>
>

 >> > >> > To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>;
 >> > >> > <breakssf@topica.com>
 >> > >> > Sent: Wednesday, April 19, 2006 10:49 AM
 >> > >> > Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Robbie Hardkiss, this friday
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > ROBBIE HARDKISS
 >> > >> > With his brothers Scott Hardkiss and Gavin Hardkiss, Robbie
 >> Hardkiss
 >> > >> > is a central figure in the infamous Hardkiss family of DJs and
 >> > >> > musicians. Working in their hometown of San Francisco, the
 >> Hardkiss
 >> > >> > brothers were instrumental in developing the U.S. rave and
 >> outdoor
 >> > >> > party scene in the early '90s. Pioneering Hardkiss tunes such as
 >> "3
 >> > >> > Nudes In A Purple Garden" and "Rainery" helped define the
 >> psychedelic
 >> > >> > West Coast breakbeat sound that continues to grow today. Their
 >> > >> > legendary status within the realm of electronic music was
 >> immortalized
 >> > >> > with the release of their double album, Delusions of Grandeur.
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > Since then, Robbie Hardkiss has gone on to remix songs (with and
 >> > >> > without his brothers) for artists such as Elton John,
 >> Freestylers,
 >> > >> > Spacetime Continuum, The Grid, Lords of Acid, The Sandals,
 >> Q-Burn,
 >> God
 >> > >> > Within (aka Scott Hardkiss), and Hawke.
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > Scott, Gavin and Robbie, the Hardkiss brothers, ruled the
 >> underground
 >> > >> > San Francisco club scene during the 1990s with a mixture of acid,
 >> > >> > trance and breakbeat techno. World-class DJs all, the brothers
 >> also
 >> > >> > run their own Hardkiss label, releasing material as themselves
 >> plus
 >> > >> > myriad other artists, including Rabbit in the Moon and Scott's
 >> God
 >> > >> > Within project. It was Scott and Gavin who formed the group in
 >> the
 >> > >> > early '90s after experiencing Britain's 1989 Summer of Love
 >> firsthand
 >> > >> > while studying in Europe. Returning to the States, the two began
 >> > >> > promoting and organizing massive raves on the East Coast, but
 >> later
 >> > >> > moved out to San Francisco to share the vibe with the West as
 >> well.
 >> > >> > Hooking up with old friend Robbie and christening themselves
 >> Hardkiss,
 >> > >> > the trio began recording material for their eponymous label.
 >> Though
 >> > >> > few releases appeared on anything other than vinyl, the label
 >> > >> > compilation Delusions of Grandeur serves as a good primer to the
 >> > >> > Hardkiss sound. Scott, Robbie and Gavin have each released
 >> > >> > compilations detailing their mixing skills as well. ~ John Bush,
 >> All
 >> > >> > Music Guide
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > ELEKTRO-PHONIK
 >> > >> > 1015 Folsom St
 >> > >> > Doors at 10pm
 >> > >> > $10 all night
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > with your special guests for the evening:
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > Robbie Hardkiss - Classic / Sunburn / Boozy + Swan/
 >> > >> > www.robbiehardkiss.com
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > Kidd Linus - boogiebeatrecords.com / Elektro-Phonik.com (SF)
 >> > >> > Jason Kincaid - grooves-in-the-park / culture
 >> > >> > Bam - Evil Breaks / Invibe (SF)
 >> > >> > Marc(O) - Otherworld / The Midnightsons / Ill Behavior/
 >> > >> > www.illectrofunk.com (DC/CA)
 >> > >> > Edison - Lovelab /GRM / Elektro-Phonik.com (DC)
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > www.elektro-phonik.com for more info!!!!
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > --
 >> > >> > --------------------------
 >> > >> > < Brandon / DJ Bam >
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
 >> > >> > http://www.evilbreaks.com
 >> > >> >
 >> > >> > March 30th:  Broke Ass Thursdays @ Alpha Bar
 >> > >> > April 1st:  Undercover w/ Chris Carter, Kid Kenobi @ Whisper
 >> > >> > April 15th:  Pandamoaneum
 >> > >> > April 21st:  Robbie Hardkiss @ 1015
 >> > >> > Aprl 22nd:  Evil Ferrets @ Alpha Bar - Aaron Jae's Birthday
 >> Crackup
 >> > >> > May 20th:  DIRTY w/ Circuitbreaker @ Jelly's
 >> > >> > July 21st:  Mighty Breaks

>Only if you choose to be Ben.
>
>  I remember a couple of years ago my current wife and I had dinner 
>with my ex-girlfriend from college and her husband.  They live in a 
>nice suburban house in Thousand Oaks California where I had visited 
>her a few months earlier.  She was going on about how the city was 
>much "dirtier" than she remembered it.  She used to live in the city 
>back in the early eighties and I grew up in the area, and went to 
>high school over in the Haight (Urban School).  I was pretty amazed 
>to hear this, because my recollection of the Haight and Mission 
>(where we were having dinner at a fancy restaraunt) from those times 
>was that they used to be much dirtier, there was more crime, and no 
>nice shops or restaraunts at all.  The conversation went on with her 
>complaining about the "weirdos" and so forth.
>

with stupid crap.   But being judgmental?
I was on the tail end of that too much....

as for dirty, SF is a damn dirty city.    Vancouver is soooo clean (I 
was there for a year)  Even London
seems cleaner, even in the rotten parts where they throw warehouse 
parties.  Some trash, but my memory of SF implies there's more there.

doug

On Apr 21, 2006, at 6:49 AM, Ben Haus wrote:

> Tom Moulton is amazing, and he still produces incredible stuff today.

It's Xmas in April!!!  ....new releases/compilations coming out for  
DJ's and producers from the past: Nicky Siano's "THE GALLERY", Tom  
Moulton "A TOM MOULTON MIX", and now Larry's 2-cd set "Journey Into  
Paradise: The Larry Levan Story."

Apollo


>
>
>
>
> On 4/21/06, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> April 20, 2006
> Critic's Notebook
>
>
> Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai
>
> By < http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/ 
> kelefa_sanneh/index.html?inline=nyt-per>KELEFA SANNEH
>
> Early in the 1970's, Tom Moulton found a way to defy the laws of  
> mathematics: he made songs longer by a process of subtraction. By  
> stretching out the emptiest parts of his favorite records  the  
> rhythmic breaks, where verses and choruses gave way to beats and  
> grooves  he helped turn R&B hits like "Do It ('Til You're  
> Satisfied)" into disco classics. His hugely influential mixes are  
> collected on a great new double-CD compilation called "A Tom  
> Moulton Mix" (Soul Jazz); in it, you can hear the birth of modern  
> dance music.
>
> Dance-music producers have been subtracting ever since, finding out  
> that less music can often move dancers more. You can hear decades'  
> worth of subtracting when you play "A Love Moderne" (Forcetracks),  
> a skeletal but surprisingly seductive new CD by the Swedish  
> producer known as Unai. It's an early contender for electronic- 
> music album of the year, and it makes Mr. Moulton's work sound  
> positively baroque.
>
> In 1974, Mr. Moulton did something that would soon become  
> commonplace: he made a mix. He spent 80 hours turning some club- 
> friendly records into a 45-minute reel-to-reel tape, which  
> eventually became a hit at the Sandpiper, a center of Fire Island's  
> night life. He took the same principle  keep the beat going so the  
> dancers keep dancing  into the recording studio, and made a series  
> of danceable remixes and re-edits.
>
> His discovery seems obvious now: he realized that the thumping,  
> dance-floor-friendly soul records of the early 70's would sound  
> that much better, and thumpinger, if he made them longer.  
> (Apparently brevity isn't the soul of soul.) He can claim to have  
> invented the 12-inch single, although he stumbled upon the format  
> by mistake: an engineer had run out of 7-inch vinyl.
>
> "A Tom Moulton Mix" gathers 16 tracks, starting with "Keep On  
> Truckin' (Part 1)," the 1973 hit by Eddie Kendricks, the former  
> Temptation. The song lasts eight minutes on Kendricks's self-titled  
> album; a radio edit whittled it down to three and a half. But Mr.  
> Moulton went in the other direction: the version here lasts more  
> than 11 minutes, and if anything it ends too soon. When that  
> glorious beat  thundering drums, squelchy guitar, a string section  
> darting in and out  finally gives way to the timpani heartbeat that  
> serves as a coda, you may be expecting, or even hoping, that the  
> song will come roaring back to life one more time.
>
> Many of his mixes seem relatively unobtrusive, especially compared  
> with the radical disco producers who emerged in the mid-70's.  
> Walter Gibbons and Shep Pettibone, for example, took Mr. Moulton's  
> approach further: they loved to turn songs into wild, weird, drum- 
> driven experiments. But part of the joy in this compilation is the  
> gentleness of Mr. Moulton's approach; he's invisible, unless you're  
> paying attention. Whether he's toying with B.T. Express's "Peace  
> Pipe" or extending the sublime novelty hit "Moonboots," by Orlando  
> Riva Sound, Mr. Moulton makes mixes that hint at what came before  
> and what would come after. You can hear soul songs morphing into  
> machine music.
>
> In the 70's, "disco" evolved from a place into a genre, and in the  
> 80's, house and techno producers focused even more intently on  
> rhythm tracks. It sometimes seems that dance-music producers are  
> doing their best to finish what Mr. Moulton and others started:  
> stripping away the songs until almost nothing's left.
>
> Maybe the job is just about done. Certainly, some of the best  
> electronic dance music these days is also some of the sparsest. In  
> Germany and elsewhere, producers and D.J.'s have figured out ways  
> to evoke disco's propulsion by using little more than hums and  
> clicks and snippets and squiggles. It's just an extension of the  
> Moulton doctrine: a relatively simple track, slowly mutating over 5  
> or 10 or even (in an age of CD's and laptops) 30 minutes, can drive  
> dancers crazy.
>
> Erik Moller, the Swede who records as Unai, is often counted as one  
> of the minimalists; he's known for subtle, twitchy tracks that  
> occasionally hint at dub reggae. "A Love Moderne," his second full- 
> length CD, is to be released in America next month, and it's a  
> slight departure. There are more melodies, more singing (his own),  
> more songs. His fans will probably claim that this is his pop  
> album, but beware: Unai fans probably have a different definition  
> of pop than you do. (That's why they're Unai fans.)
>
> Make no mistake: this is ghostly, sometimes eerie music. Mr. Moller  
> is clearly still obsessed with subtle electronic textures and  
> smudgy bass lines that could almost be computer glitches. And yet  
> he has filled this album with strong, melancholy melodies, and  
> unlike most of his contemporaries, he doesn't embarrass himself  
> when he tries to sing. He often hides behind electronic filters;  
> it's as if he recorded his voice and then erased it, leaving only a  
> trace behind.
>
> One track, "Heart Is to the Left," is about as close as Unai gets  
> to a swaggering disco track. There's a sharp, unrelenting beat and  
> an old-fashioned love lyric: "Truly I believe in you," he sings,  
> although his voice soon disappears into the mix. And in "Modern  
> Love," the music transforms itself through sudden cuts and gradual  
> fades; it's a woozy composition made of gauzy synthesizers, wobbly  
> beats, muscular bass lines, half-decayed backing vocals.
>
> There's something pleasantly perverse about what Mr. Moller is  
> doing: after years of making skeletal dance music, he's adding  
> flesh to the bones he so carefully stripped. But not too much  the  
> whole trick, in fact, is to make these skinny songs sound fleshier  
> than they are. Whether they mean to or not, producers like him are  
> heading back toward the disco mixes of the 1970's, only from the  
> other side. Once it was a thrill to hear pop songs turning into  
> electronic tracks. But it can be just as much fun to hear the  
> process in reverse.
>
> http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/20/arts/music/20sann.html? 
> _r=5&oref=login&pagewanted=print
>
>
>
>
> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
> Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k> http:// 
> people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:   http://livingart.com/raving/articles/ 
> housemusic101.htm
>
> "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times  
> as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one  
> question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My  
> benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was  
> too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I  
> will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it  
> does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
> -Don Juan
>
> "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> -Edward R. Murrow
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead  
> of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

On 4/21/06, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
>
>
> On Apr 21, 2006, at 6:49 AM, Ben Haus wrote:
>
> Tom Moulton is amazing, and he still produces incredible stuff today.
>
>
> It's Xmas in April!!!  ....new releases/compilations coming out for DJ's
> and producers from the past: Nicky Siano's "THE GALLERY", Tom Moulton "A =
TOM
> MOULTON MIX", and now Larry's 2-cd set "Journey Into Paradise: The Larry
> Levan Story."
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 4/21/06, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> >
> > April 20, 2006
> > Critic's Notebook
> >
> >
> > Dance Music Then and Now, From Tom Moulton and Unai
> >
> > By <http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/kelefa=
_sanneh/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>KELEFA
> > SANNEH
> >
> > Early in the 1970's, Tom Moulton found a way to defy the laws of
> > mathematics: he made songs longer by a process of subtraction. By stret=
ching
> > out the emptiest parts of his favorite records =AD the rhythmic breaks,=
 where
> > verses and choruses gave way to beats and grooves =AD he helped turn R&=
B hits
> > like "Do It ('Til You're Satisfied)" into disco classics. His hugely
> > influential mixes are collected on a great new double-CD compilation ca=
lled
> > "A Tom Moulton Mix" (Soul Jazz); in it, you can hear the birth of moder=
n
> > dance music.
> >
> > Dance-music producers have been subtracting ever since, finding out tha=
t
> > less music can often move dancers more. You can hear decades' worth of
> > subtracting when you play "A Love Moderne" (Forcetracks), a skeletal bu=
t
> > surprisingly seductive new CD by the Swedish producer known as Unai. It=
's an
> > early contender for electronic-music album of the year, and it makes Mr=
.
> > Moulton's work sound positively baroque.
> >
> > In 1974, Mr. Moulton did something that would soon become commonplace:
> > he made a mix. He spent 80 hours turning some club-friendly records int=
o a
> > 45-minute reel-to-reel tape, which eventually became a hit at the Sandp=
iper,
> > a center of Fire Island's night life. He took the same principle =AD ke=
ep the
> > beat going so the dancers keep dancing =AD into the recording studio, a=
nd made
> > a series of danceable remixes and re-edits.
> >
> > His discovery seems obvious now: he realized that the thumping,
> > dance-floor-friendly soul records of the early 70's would sound that mu=
ch
> > better, and thumpinger, if he made them longer. (Apparently brevity isn=
't
> > the soul of soul.) He can claim to have invented the 12-inch single,
> > although he stumbled upon the format by mistake: an engineer had run ou=
t of
> > 7-inch vinyl.
> >
> > "A Tom Moulton Mix" gathers 16 tracks, starting with "Keep On Truckin'
> > (Part 1)," the 1973 hit by Eddie Kendricks, the former Temptation. The =
song
> > lasts eight minutes on Kendricks's self-titled album; a radio edit whit=
tled
> > it down to three and a half. But Mr. Moulton went in the other directio=
n:
> > the version here lasts more than 11 minutes, and if anything it ends to=
o
> > soon. When that glorious beat =AD thundering drums, squelchy guitar, a =
string
> > section darting in and out =AD finally gives way to the timpani heartbe=
at that
> > serves as a coda, you may be expecting, or even hoping, that the song w=
ill
> > come roaring back to life one more time.
> >
> > Many of his mixes seem relatively unobtrusive, especially compared with
> > the radical disco producers who emerged in the mid-70's. Walter Gibbons=
 and
> > Shep Pettibone, for example, took Mr. Moulton's approach further: they =
loved
> > to turn songs into wild, weird, drum-driven experiments. But part of th=
e joy
> > in this compilation is the gentleness of Mr. Moulton's approach; he's
> > invisible, unless you're paying attention. Whether he's toying with B.T=
.
> > Express's "Peace Pipe" or extending the sublime novelty hit "Moonboots,=
" by
> > Orlando Riva Sound, Mr. Moulton makes mixes that hint at what came befo=
re
> > and what would come after. You can hear soul songs morphing into machin=
e
> > music.
> >
> > In the 70's, "disco" evolved from a place into a genre, and in the 80's=
,
> > house and techno producers focused even more intently on rhythm tracks.=
 It
> > sometimes seems that dance-music producers are doing their best to fini=
sh
> > what Mr. Moulton and others started: stripping away the songs until alm=
ost
> > nothing's left.
> >
> > Maybe the job is just about done. Certainly, some of the best electroni=
c
> > dance music these days is also some of the sparsest. In Germany and
> > elsewhere, producers and D.J.'s have figured out ways to evoke disco's
> > propulsion by using little more than hums and clicks and snippets and
> > squiggles. It's just an extension of the Moulton doctrine: a relatively
> > simple track, slowly mutating over 5 or 10 or even (in an age of CD's a=
nd
> > laptops) 30 minutes, can drive dancers crazy.
> >
> > Erik Moller, the Swede who records as Unai, is often counted as one of
> > the minimalists; he's known for subtle, twitchy tracks that occasionall=
y
> > hint at dub reggae. "A Love Moderne," his second full-length CD, is to =
be
> > released in America next month, and it's a slight departure. There are =
more
> > melodies, more singing (his own), more songs. His fans will probably cl=
aim
> > that this is his pop album, but beware: Unai fans probably have a diffe=
rent
> > definition of pop than you do. (That's why they're Unai fans.)
> >
> > Make no mistake: this is ghostly, sometimes eerie music. Mr. Moller is
> > clearly still obsessed with subtle electronic textures and smudgy bass =
lines
> > that could almost be computer glitches. And yet he has filled this albu=
m
> > with strong, melancholy melodies, and unlike most of his contemporaries=
, he
> > doesn't embarrass himself when he tries to sing. He often hides behind
> > electronic filters; it's as if he recorded his voice and then erased it=
,
> > leaving only a trace behind.
> >
> > One track, "Heart Is to the Left," is about as close as Unai gets to a
> > swaggering disco track. There's a sharp, unrelenting beat and an
> > old-fashioned love lyric: "Truly I believe in you," he sings, although =
his
> > voice soon disappears into the mix. And in "Modern Love," the music
> > transforms itself through sudden cuts and gradual fades; it's a woozy
> > composition made of gauzy synthesizers, wobbly beats, muscular bass lin=
es,
> > half-decayed backing vocals.
> >
> > There's something pleasantly perverse about what Mr. Moller is doing:
> > after years of making skeletal dance music, he's adding flesh to the bo=
nes
> > he so carefully stripped. But not too much =AD the whole trick, in fact=
, is to
> > make these skinny songs sound fleshier than they are. Whether they mean=
 to
> > or not, producers like him are heading back toward the disco mixes of t=
he
> > 1970's, only from the other side. Once it was a thrill to hear pop song=
s
> > turning into electronic tracks. But it can be just as much fun to hear =
the
> > process in reverse.
> >
> > http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/20/arts/music/20sann.html?_r=3D5&oref=3D=
login&pagewanted=3Dprint
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
> >
> > Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>
> > http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
> >
> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >
> > House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.ht=
m
> >
> > "Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as
> > you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one
> > question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My
> > benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too
> > vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell=
 you
> > what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good=
.  If
> > it doesn't, it is of no use."
> > -Don Juan
> >
> > "A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
> > -Edward R. Murrow

ome

Just kindsa wanted to give you all an update on my situation since so =
many people really jumped to help me last week when my life went to =
doodoo...

1st off - before I get into it, let me once again sincerely thank you =
all for the help you either supplied and/or offered. It is so sincerely =
appreciated, I honestly can't express how thankful I am.=20

So anyway - I wish I could say my situation has improved. Sadly, if =
anything it's worse at this point. There's way too much that's happened =
for me to go into detail - but suffice it to say, despite me getting =
rent paid and my cell bill decreased to next to nothing (thank you SO =
much Tala), the majority of my debtors are sending me to collections, =
and have PURPOSEFULLY sent through debit attempts to my bank, knowing =
full well there was no money to retrieve. One company literally did it =
on purpose so they could charge me and extra late fee, return payment =
fee, and rack up another 2 NSF fees in my bank account. My bank =
basically said "tough titty" to me when I begged for assistance. I guess =
since they're cleaning house with me on NSF fees, they could care less.=20

On top of all this shit, our servers have been down at work, and the =
people running them are so freaking incompetent, they couldn't migrate =
any of the info on the servers to the right spots, and my work week has =
been a hell of financial planners, securities agents and insurance =
agents freaking out and cancelling service w/ my company. PLUS, our =
company decided to drop our 100% paid PPO insurance plan, to get an 80% =
paid HMO plan - so an extra $100 gets axed from my paychecks each month =
unless I decide to just go without insurance. $100 I already don't have. =
*sigh*

So...I unfortunately have to sell off more records. I'm not dipping into =
the prized stash yet, but it's not far off at this point...I'll most =
likely post a list of stuff for sale later today or this weekend, so if =
ANY OF YOU see records you want on the list, PLEASE contact me ASAP. =
I'll do the best deals I can, but please don't haggle with me...

Bla bla bla....enough about my crappy life. I'm gonna try and transcend =
it all tonight and drop a banging set at 1015. It'd make my week if I =
saw a ton of you folks out there tonight, plus, you'll be supporting =
something new and exciting me and my transplant friends from the other =
coast want to push out here.=20

I go on from 12 to 1 right before Robbie Hardkiss....if you care to =
share in the moment.

(and Bam goes on right at 10pm, so get there early and support him too!)

~Marco

p.s. sorry for the "woe is me" post, I know most people don't wanna hear =
this shit - but I also didn't want you folks to get the idea that I =
forgot about your good will, it means the world to me.

1. Creativity and innovation always builds on the past.
2. The past always tries to control the creativity that builds on it.
3. Free societies enable the future by living in the past.
4. Ours is a less and less a free society.

Massive Selector, Club 6,
& The Poleng Lounge present:
THE SUMMIT
[]

LOCATION:
60 6th St.
between Market & Mission
San Francisco, CA
<http://clubsix1.com/directions.php>View a map 
[]

CONTACT US: 
<http://clubsix1.com>http://clubsix1.com
415.531.6593 
<mailto:info@clubsix1.com>info@clubsix1.com
[]



The Summit

Once upon a time, in a galaxy far, far away…

there was a monthly party which crisscrossed all musical genres, showcasing a wide array of talent like Jazzy Jeff, Spinna, Hyper, & Jazzanova (to name a few). From hip hop to house, broken beat to nu-jazz, dancehall to lovers rock, turntablism to live music, this genre-less party celebrated musical diversity for more than three years.

After a 2 year hiatus, Massive Selector and friends return to the newly renovated Club Six reviving this legendary party. On April 21, The Summit resumes its quest to bridge the musical gap with a worldwide eclectic lineup featuring…

The King Britt Experience
(with a 4 piece band)
DJ Muro of Japan
45 King (45King.com)
Haul and Mason (Quality SF/LA)

Alongside with
PantyROBber (Massive Selector)
Proof (Massive Selector)
Malex (Massive Selector)
KingMost & DJ Kero One (Plug Label)
Big Taka (FTC/Reflections)

About King Britt
Rarely will you find a talent whose vision supersedes the boundaries of genre, until you have met King Britt. This Philadelphia native has found a way to escape the boundaries of a single category of music by expressing his creations through deep house, hip-hop, broken beat, nu-jazz, funk and afro-tech.

As a member of Digable Planets and as an artist on San Francisco’s own OM Records label, and having worked with artists such as Questlove from the Roots, Ursula Rucker, Macy Gray, Femi Kuti, and others, King Britt's new style fuses influences from various music genres and comes full circle with a LIVE interpretation of all that he has experienced..

About DJ Muro
A former disciple of DJ Krush. Muro the “King of Diggin” is considered one of Japan’s hip hop royalty. As a Pioneer of Japanese hip hop culture, Muro has produced countless tracks and remixes for such labels as Blue Note, Tommy Boy and Def Jam and has worked with several artist including Lord Finesse and A.G.

About 45 King. (from One Stop Hip Hip)
If you don’t know 45 King, then you don’t know Queen Latifah, DJ Kool, Jay Z, or Eminem. This super-producer has been creating hits since the late 80’s. Most DJs world wide have at least one copy of the classic break beat “900 Number” which was first produced in 1987 and later revisited in DJ Kool’s hit “Let me Clear my Throat”.
45 King blew up in an even bigger way in 1998. Hooking up with Jay-Z, the 45 King produced what was to be the biggest rap song of the summer: "It's a Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)." In 2000, he produced the platinum track "Stan" for Eminem, solidifying his reputation as a top-notch beatmaker. Learn more at 45king.com

About Haul & Mason
Los Angeles based DJ/Producers Haul and Mason are firmly establishing themselves as the party-rocking DJ duo to watch in the coming years. Known for their infamous "2x4 sets," the two So-Cal residents have producing original tracks, playing live with bands, and blowing up dance floors all around the world. Haul & Mason will also re-launch Quality SF @ the Poleng Lounge every 1st Friday of the Month. 


PRICE:
$10 before 10pm
$15 before 11pm
$20 after
limited $15 presale
2 for $25 at
<http://www.massiveselector.com>massiveselector.com

TIME: 9:30pm-2am 

MUSIC: World Rhythms, House, Hip-Hop, and beyond 



MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

The Summit<br><br>
Once upon a time, in a galaxy far, far away…<br><br>
there was a monthly party which crisscrossed all musical genres,
showcasing a wide array of talent like Jazzy Jeff, Spinna, Hyper, &amp;
Jazzanova (to name a few). From hip hop to house, broken beat to nu-jazz,
dancehall to lovers rock, turntablism to live music, this genre-less
party celebrated musical diversity for more than three years.<br><br>
After a 2 year hiatus, Massive Selector and friends return to the newly
renovated Club Six reviving this legendary party. On April 21, The Summit
resumes its quest to bridge the musical gap with a worldwide eclectic
lineup featuring…<br><br>
The King Britt Experience<br>
(with a 4 piece band)<br>
DJ Muro of Japan<br>
45 King (45King.com)<br>
Haul and Mason (Quality SF/LA)<br><br>
Alongside with<br>
PantyROBber (Massive Selector)<br>
Proof (Massive Selector)<br>
Malex (Massive Selector)<br>
KingMost &amp; DJ Kero One (Plug Label)<br>
Big Taka (FTC/Reflections)<br><br>
About King Britt<br>
Rarely will you find a talent whose vision supersedes the boundaries of
genre, until you have met King Britt. This Philadelphia native has found
a way to escape the boundaries of a single category of music by
expressing his creations through deep house, hip-hop, broken beat,
nu-jazz, funk and afro-tech.<br><br>
As a member of Digable Planets and as an artist on San Francisco’s own OM
Records label, and having worked with artists such as Questlove from the
Roots, Ursula Rucker, Macy Gray, Femi Kuti, and others, King Britt's new
style fuses influences from various music genres and comes full circle
with a LIVE interpretation of all that he has experienced..<br><br>
About DJ Muro<br>
A former disciple of DJ Krush. Muro the “King of Diggin” is considered
one of Japan’s hip hop royalty. As a Pioneer of Japanese hip hop culture,
Muro has produced countless tracks and remixes for such labels as Blue
Note, Tommy Boy and Def Jam and has worked with several artist including
Lord Finesse and A.G.<br><br>
About 45 King. (from One Stop Hip Hip)<br>
If you don’t know 45 King, then you don’t know Queen Latifah, DJ Kool,
Jay Z, or Eminem. This super-producer has been creating hits since the
late 80’s. Most DJs world wide have at least one copy of the classic
break beat “900 Number” which was first produced in 1987 and later
revisited in DJ Kool’s hit “Let me Clear my Throat”.<br>
45 King blew up in an even bigger way in 1998. Hooking up with Jay-Z, the
45 King produced what was to be the biggest rap song of the summer:
&quot;It's a Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem).&quot; In 2000, he produced
the platinum track &quot;Stan&quot; for Eminem, solidifying his
reputation as a top-notch beatmaker. Learn more at 45king.com<br><br>
About Haul &amp; Mason<br>
Los Angeles based DJ/Producers Haul and Mason are firmly establishing
themselves as the party-rocking DJ duo to watch in the coming years.
Known for their infamous &quot;2x4 sets,&quot; the two So-Cal residents
have producing original tracks, playing live with bands, and blowing up
dance floors all around the world. Haul &amp; Mason will also re-launch
Quality SF @ the Poleng Lounge every 1st Friday of the Month. <br><br>
