events for our headliners any more - expect the best, no less! Pre-sale
tickets will be available soon.

Wednesday, August 02, 2006 * BOOM FESTIVAL Magic *

Date & Time:  Wednesday, August 2, 2006 - Wednesday, August 9, 2006 4:00 AM
Heya, All! We would like to share with you information about a very special
global arts, music and culture-gathering that incarnates biannually in
Portugal. Boom Festival takes place in a stunning outdoor location on the
shore of the Lake Idanha-a-Nova, approximately 2 hours North-West from
Lisboa. Bringing together the latest in psychedelic sights & sounds,
phantastic art installations & workshops, this week-long event is a harmonic
convergence of people, energy, information, and philosophies, from planet
Earth & beyond. Synchronized multi-dimensionally with the full moon of
August, the next Boom-Festival is taking a bio-dynamic approach by
incorporating a variety of sustainable techniques, and Earth-based forms
throughout its infrastructure. Reflecting a harmonic balance of the organic
and the cyber-technologic, Boom 2006 maps the metaphysical framework in
accordance with Peace, Love, Unity and Respect. A very magical event indeed!
5000 BOOM Festival 2006 Early Bird Tickets are available now. They are only
70 Euro for 7 days. Getting there is no big deal. Reasonable flights to
Lisboa can be purchased on most of the European Budget Airlines, and
Transatlantic flights from America are also quite cheap. The Boom has
organized busses that take you directly from the international airport to
the sacred womb of the vacation party paradise. This year, Boom-festival has
extended its length to ONE WEEK! Great news about the timing of BOOM 2006 is
that it's not happening in conjunction with Burning Man, so the devoted
"Burners" have a chance to partake on European creative community
expression. BOOM is similar to Burning Man, but with a lake & great sounds!
Not to be missed ... For more info, please visit: www.boomfestival.org

------------------------------------------------- 
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week. To subscribe to the
list, send a message to: sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

If you have events to add to the SFRaves calendar, please publish them by
Friday @ Noon to be included in the SFR Calendar Weekly Edition Mailing.

SFRaves is a not for profit entity serving the Bay Area & all forms of
electronic music for 14 years.

Mexico's Congress Legalizes Drugs for Personal Use

Friday , April 28, 2006

[]
 

MEXICO CITY ­ Mexico's Congress approved a bill Friday decriminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana, ecstasy, cocaine and heroin for personal use ­ a measure sure to raise questions in Washington about Mexico's commitment to the war on drugs.

The only remaining step was the signature of President Vicente Fox, whose office indicated he would sign it.

Supporters said the law would let police focus on drug smuggling, rather than on busting casual users. The bill also would stiffen many drug-related penalties: for trafficking, for possession near schools, and for possession of even small quantities by government employees.

Criminal penalties for drug sales would remain on the books.

"We can't close our eyes to this reality," said Sen. Jorge Zermeno, of Fox's conservative National Action Party. "We cannot continue to fill our jails with people who have addictions."

The administration of U.S. President George W. Bush scrambled to come up with a response.

"We're still studying the legislation, but any effort to decriminalize illegal drugs would not be helpful," a U.S. diplomat said on condition of anonymity.

The bill, passed by Mexico's Senate on a 53-26 vote with one abstention, had already been quietly approved in the lower house of Congress and was sent Friday to the president's desk. Presidential spokesman Ruben Aguilar indicated Fox would sign it.

"This law gives police and prosecutors better legal tools to combat drug crimes that do so much damage to our youth and children," he said.

If signed into law, the bill could have an impact on Mexico's relationship with the United States ­ and on the vast numbers of vacationing students who visit Mexico, often to take advantage of its rarely enforced drinking age of 18.

The bill says criminal charges will no longer be brought for possession of up to 25 milligrams of heroin, five grams of marijuana ­ about one-fifth of an ounce, or about four joints ­ and half a gram of cocaine ­ about half the standard street-size quantity, which is enough for several lines of the drug.

"No charges will be brought against ... addicts or consumers who are found in possession of any narcotic for personal use," the Senate bill reads. It also lays out allowable quantities for a large array of other drugs, including LSD, MDA, ecstasy ­ about two pills' worth ­ and amphetamines.

Some of the amounts are eye-popping: Mexicans would be allowed to possess a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of peyote, the button-sized hallucinogenic cactus used in some native Indian religious ceremonies.

Mexican law now leaves open the possibility of dropping charges against people caught with drugs if they are considered addicts and if "the amount is the quantity necessary for personal use." But the exemption isn't automatic.

The new bill drops the "addict" requirement ­ automatically allowing any "consumers" to have drugs ­ and sets out specific allowable quantities.

Sale of all drugs would remain illegal under the proposed law, unlike the Netherlands, where the sale of marijuana for medical use is legal and it can be bought with a prescription in pharmacies.

While Dutch authorities look the other way regarding the open sale of cannabis in designated coffee shops ­ something Mexican police seem unlikely to do ­ the Dutch have zero tolerance for heroin and cocaine. In both countries, commercial growing of marijuana is outlawed.

In Colombia, a 1994 court ruling decriminalized personal possession of small amounts of cocaine, heroin and other drugs. But President Alvaro Uribe, who is almost assured of re-election next month, wants to change that with a constitutional amendment.

"Allowing the personal dosage of drugs is inconsistent with a country committed to fighting the war on drugs," Uribe said at a campaign stop.

The effects could be significant, given that Mexico is rapidly becoming a drug-consuming nation as well as a shipment point for traffickers, and given the number of U.S. students who flock to border cities or resorts like Cancun and Acapulco on vacation.

"This is going to increase addictions in Mexico," said Ulisis Bon, a drug treatment expert in Tijuana, where heroin use is rampant. "A lot of Americans already come here to buy medications they can't get up there ... Just imagine, with heroin."

U.S. legalization advocates greeted the bill with glee.

Ethan Nadelmann, director of the New York-based Drug Policy Alliance, called it "a very good move," saying it removed "a huge opportunity for low-level police corruption." In Mexico, police often release people detained for minor drug possession in exchange for bribes.

"Look at every path closely and deliberately.  Try it as many times as you think necessary.  Then ask yourself and yourself alone one question.  This question is one that only a very old man asks.  My benefactor told me about it once when I was young and my blood was too vigorous for me to understand it.  Now I do understand it.  I will tell you what it is:  'Does this path have a heart?' If it does the path is good.  If it doesn't, it is of no use."
-Don Juan

"A nation of sheep will beget a government of wolves."
-Edward R. Murrow

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

</font><font size=5><b>Mexico's Congress Legalizes Drugs for Personal
Use<br><br>
</font><font size=3>Friday , April 28, 2006<br><br>
</b>
<img src="cid:7.0.1.0.2.20060429014647.0295ea08@speakeasy.org.0" width=93 height=17 alt="[]">
</b>&nbsp;<br><br>
MEXICO CITY ­ Mexico's Congress approved a bill Friday decriminalizing
possession of small amounts of marijuana, ecstasy, cocaine and heroin for
personal use ­ a measure sure to raise questions in Washington about
Mexico's commitment to the war on drugs.<br><br>
The only remaining step was the signature of President <b>Vicente
Fox</b>, whose office indicated he would sign it.<br><br>
Supporters said the law would let police focus on drug smuggling, rather
than on busting casual users. The bill also would stiffen many
drug-related penalties: for trafficking, for possession near schools, and
for possession of even small quantities by government employees.<br><br>
Criminal penalties for drug sales would remain on the books.<br><br>
&quot;We can't close our eyes to this reality,&quot; said Sen. Jorge
Zermeno, of Fox's conservative National Action Party. &quot;We cannot
continue to fill our jails with people who have
addictions.&quot;<br><br>
The administration of U.S. President <b>George W. Bush</b> scrambled to
come up with a response.<br><br>
&quot;We're still studying the legislation, but any effort to
decriminalize illegal drugs would not be helpful,&quot; a U.S. diplomat
said on condition of anonymity.<br><br>
The bill, passed by Mexico's Senate on a 53-26 vote with one abstention,
had already been quietly approved in the lower house of Congress and was
sent Friday to the president's desk. Presidential spokesman Ruben Aguilar
indicated Fox would sign it.<br><br>
&quot;This law gives police and prosecutors better legal tools to combat
drug crimes that do so much damage to our youth and children,&quot; he
said.<br><br>
If signed into law, the bill could have an impact on Mexico's
relationship with the United States ­ and on the vast numbers of
vacationing students who visit Mexico, often to take advantage of its
rarely enforced drinking age of 18.<br><br>
The bill says criminal charges will no longer be brought for possession
of up to 25 milligrams of heroin, five grams of marijuana ­ about
one-fifth of an ounce, or about four joints ­ and half a gram of cocaine
­ about half the standard street-size quantity, which is enough for
several lines of the drug.<br><br>
&quot;No charges will be brought against ... addicts or consumers who are
found in possession of any narcotic for personal use,&quot; the Senate
bill reads. It also lays out allowable quantities for a large array of
other drugs, including <b>LSD</b>, MDA, ecstasy ­ about two pills' worth
­ and amphetamines.<br><br>
Some of the amounts are eye-popping: Mexicans would be allowed to possess
a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of peyote, the button-sized hallucinogenic cactus
used in some native Indian religious ceremonies.<br><br>
Mexican law now leaves open the possibility of dropping charges against
people caught with drugs if they are considered addicts and if &quot;the
amount is the quantity necessary for personal use.&quot; But the
exemption isn't automatic.<br><br>
The new bill drops the &quot;addict&quot; requirement ­ automatically
allowing any &quot;consumers&quot; to have drugs ­ and sets out specific
allowable quantities.<br><br>
Sale of all drugs would remain illegal under the proposed law, unlike the
Netherlands, where the sale of marijuana for medical use is legal and it
can be bought with a prescription in pharmacies.<br><br>
While Dutch authorities look the other way regarding the open sale of
cannabis in designated coffee shops ­ something Mexican police seem
unlikely to do ­ the Dutch have zero tolerance for heroin and cocaine. In
both countries, commercial growing of marijuana is outlawed.<br><br>
In Colombia, a 1994 court ruling decriminalized personal possession of
small amounts of cocaine, heroin and other drugs. But President <b>Alvaro
Uribe</b>, who is almost assured of re-election next month, wants to
change that with a constitutional amendment.<br><br>
&quot;Allowing the personal dosage of drugs is inconsistent with a
country committed to fighting the war on drugs,&quot; Uribe said at a
campaign stop.<br><br>
The effects could be significant, given that Mexico is rapidly becoming a
drug-consuming nation as well as a shipment point for traffickers, and
given the number of U.S. students who flock to border cities or resorts
like Cancun and Acapulco on vacation.<br><br>
&quot;This is going to increase addictions in Mexico,&quot; said Ulisis
Bon, a drug treatment expert in Tijuana, where heroin use is rampant.
&quot;A lot of Americans already come here to buy medications they can't
get up there ... Just imagine, with heroin.&quot;<br><br>
U.S. legalization advocates greeted the bill with glee.<br><br>
Ethan Nadelmann, director of the New York-based Drug Policy Alliance,
called it &quot;a very good move,&quot; saying it removed &quot;a huge
opportunity for low-level police corruption.&quot; In Mexico, police
often release people detained for minor drug possession in exchange for
bribes.<br><br>

yay for the fans!  :)

one of the first places i ever got to spin a copy of
The Parti EP was at a day party in SF and i remember
people responding well when the CZ-101 organ part
starts up on 'Fresh Is...' and at that moment i
thought "Hey!  I made a record!"  :D

anyway, you can see my full mixtapeography listed out
if you go to http://www.abductionproductions.com then
click on "Music Production"  -- if anyone wants mp3s
of any of those mixtapes, just drop me a note and i'll
hook you up (sorry I don't have the tracklistings
online yet -- i'll work on that this week).
